Use a natural form in your language for introducing a situation that could happen. Alternate translation: [Suppose the woman who was experiencing unusual genital bleeding becomes clean from the flow of her blood]
Alternate translation: [then she shall determine a seven-day period]

bsb_verse_text: On the eighth day she is to take two turtledoves or two young pigeons and bring them to the priest at the entrance to the Tent of Meeting.
ult_verse_text: And on the eighth day, she shall take for herself two doves or two sons of a pigeon and she shall bring them to the priest, to the entrance of the tent of meeting.

notes.note: The word **eighth** is the ordinal form of the number eight. If your language does not use ordinal numbers, you could use a cardinal number here or an equivalent expression. Alternate translation: [And on the next day]
See how you translated this expression in [1:14](../01/14.md).

bsb_verse_text: The priest is to sacrifice one as a sin offering and the other as a burnt offering. In this way the priest will make atonement for her before the LORD for her unclean discharge.
ult_verse_text: And the priest shall make one {as} a sin offering and one {as} a burnt offering. And the priest shall make atonement for her to the face of Yahweh from the flow of her uncleanness.

notes.note: See how you handled the abstract noun **atonement** in [1:4](../01/04.md). However, in your translation, be careful not to convey the idea that the woman has sinned and so is in need of atonement. Here, atonement removes from the woman the impurity that she acquired from the blood that she has bled. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers in a footnote or in the text of your translation. Alternate translation: [And the priest shall present these offerings for her purification]
See how you translated this expression in [1:9](../01/09.md).
Alternate translation: [from her flow of blood that made her unclean]

bsb_verse_text: You must keep the children of Israel separate from their uncleanness, so that they do not die by defiling My tabernacle, which is among them.
ult_verse_text: And you shall hold back the sons of Israel from their uncleanness, and they will not die by their uncleanness, by their defiling my Dwelling, which {is} in their midst.

notes.note: Here, **you** is plural. It refers to Aaron and Moses, so use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction.
See how you handled this way of referring to the people of Israel in [1:2](../01/02.md).

Words are being repeated for emphasis. Specifically, the word **uncleanness** comes from a noun that is related to the verb **defiling**. You may be able to use the same construction in your language to express the meaning here. Alternatively, your language may have another way of showing the emphasis.
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **uncleanness**, you can express the same idea with “unclean.” Alternate translation: [from becoming unclean]

Yahweh is not distinguishing this Dwelling in the midst of the Israelites from another Dwelling that in not in their midst. Yahweh is reminding them about the location of his Dwelling with them. Be sure that this is clear in your translation. Alternate translation: [my Dwelling. After all, it is in their midst]

bsb_verse_text: This is the law of him who has a discharge, of the man who has an emission of semen whereby he is unclean,
ult_verse_text: This {is} the law of the flowing {person} and of him from whom a layer of seed goes out to become unclean by it

notes.note: This expression uses the possessive form to describe the **law** that is characterized by its referring to the wide variety of bodily discharges listed in [15:32–33](../15/32.md). If your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could use a generic expression. Alternate translation: [This is the law that has to do with people who have discharges] or [This is the law that pertains to people who have discharges]
See how you handled this expression in [15:16](../15/16.md).
Alternate translation: [and he becomes unclean by it]

bsb_verse_text: of a woman in her menstrual period, of any male or female who has a discharge, and of a man who lies with an unclean woman.’”
ult_verse_text: and of {the woman} who is sick in her menstruation and of the flowing of his flow, whether male or female, and of the man who lies with an unclean {woman}.’”

notes.note: This expression does not imply physical sickness but, rather, a woman’s general experience of menstruation. You could include this information if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and of the woman who experiences menstruation]

Although the word **his** is masculine, here is it being used in a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a phrase that makes this clear. Alternate translation: [and of the flowing of any person’s flow]

Words are being repeated for emphasis. Specifically, the word **flow** translates a noun that is related to the verb **flowing**. If your language can repeat words in a similar way, consider doing so here. If not, consider using a generic expression. Alternate translation: [and of his flowing discharge]

This expression refers in a polite way to sexual relations between a man and a woman. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language, or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [and of the man who has sexual relations with an unclean woman]

bsb_verse_text: Now the LORD spoke to Moses after the death of two of Aaron’s sons when they approached the presence of the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh spoke to Moses after the death of the two sons of Aaron, when they presented {themselves} to the face of Yahweh and they died.

notes.note: The phrase **the two sons of Aaron** refers to Nadab and Abihu, who died because they brought fire to Yahweh that he did not approve ([Leviticus 10:1–2](../10/01.md)).

bsb_verse_text: He is to wear the sacred linen tunic, with linen undergarments. He must tie a linen sash around him and put on the linen turban. These are holy garments, and he must bathe himself with water before he wears them.
ult_verse_text: He shall wear a holy linen tunic, and the undergarments of linen shall be on his flesh, and he shall tie the linen sash, and he shall wrap the linen turban. They are clothes of holiness. And he shall bathe his flesh in the water, and he shall wear them.

notes.note: These **undergarments** were clothing worn next to the skin under the outer clothes.
A **sash** is a piece of cloth that ties around the waist or chest.
A **turban** is a head covering made from wrapped strips of cloth.

bsb_verse_text: Aaron is to present the bull for his sin offering and make atonement for himself and his household.
ult_verse_text: And Aaron shall present the bull of the sin offering, which {is} for himself. And he shall make atonement on his behalf and on behalf of his house.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [as the sin offering for himself]

bsb_verse_text: After Aaron casts lots for the two goats, one for the LORD and the other for the scapegoat,
ult_verse_text: And Aaron shall cast lots concerning the two goats—one lot for Yahweh, and one lot for the scapegoat.

notes.note: Aaron was to have someone set the goat free in the wilderness. Alternate translation: [for the goat that is sent away]

bsb_verse_text: he shall present the goat chosen by lot for the LORD and sacrifice it as a sin offering.
ult_verse_text: And Aaron shall present the goat on which the lot to Yahweh went up, and he shall make it a sin offering.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [which the lot designated]

bsb_verse_text: But the goat chosen by lot as the scapegoat shall be presented alive before the LORD to make atonement by sending it into the wilderness as the scapegoat.
ult_verse_text: But the goat on which the lot for the scapegoat went up shall be made to stand, living, to the face of Yahweh to make atonement on it by sending it away as the scapegoat, to the wilderness.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [But Aaron must bring the goat … still living]

bsb_verse_text: Then he must take a censer full of burning coals from the altar before the LORD, and two handfuls of finely ground fragrant incense, and take them inside the veil.
ult_verse_text: And he shall take the fullness of a censer, coals of fire, from on the altar from before the face of Yahweh, and the fullness of his {two} hands, thin incense of spices, and he shall bring {them} inside of the curtain.

notes.note: A **censer** is a container for fire and incense, used by the priests.

bsb_verse_text: And he is to take some of the bull’s blood and sprinkle it with his finger on the east side of the mercy seat; then he shall sprinkle some of it with his finger seven times before the mercy seat.
ult_verse_text: And he shall take some of the blood of the bull, and he shall sprinkle {it} with his finger on the face of the atonement lid to the east. And to the face of the atonement lid, he shall sprinkle some of the blood with his finger seven times.

notes.note: This is the **blood** Aaron caught with a bowl in [Leviticus 16:11](../16/11.md).
He put the blood on the top part of the **lid** that was toward him as he entered the most holy place.
This could mean: (1) “And below the atonement lid onto the chest” or (2) “And onto the ground in front of the atonement lid.”

bsb_verse_text: Aaron shall then slaughter the goat for the sin offering for the people and bring its blood behind the veil, and with its blood he must do as he did with the bull’s blood: He is to sprinkle it against the mercy seat and in front of it.
ult_verse_text: And he shall slaughter the goat of the sin offering that {is} for the people, and he shall bring its blood to inside of the curtain. And he shall make its blood just as he did to the blood of the bull. And he shall sprinkle it on the atonement lid and to the face of the atonement lid.

notes.note: Aaron sprinkled the blood in the same manner that he did with the bull’s blood. See how you translated the previous instructions in [Leviticus 16:14](../16/14.md).

bsb_verse_text: So he shall make atonement for the Most Holy Place because of the impurities and rebellious acts of the Israelites in regard to all their sins. He is to do the same for the Tent of Meeting which abides among them in the midst of their impurities.
ult_verse_text: And he shall make atonement for the Holy Place from the uncleanness of the sons of Israel and from their rebellion, {in regard} to all their sins. And thus he shall do to the tent of meeting, the one dwelling with them in the midst of their uncleanness.

notes.note: The sins of the people of **Israel** made the **Holy Place** unclean.
The words **uncleanness**, **rebellion**, and **sins** mean basically the same thing. They emphasize that the people have committed all kinds of sins.
Sinful actions which make people unacceptable to Yahweh are spoken of as if they were physically unclean.

The phrase **their uncleanness** represents the people who commit sinful actions. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in the presence of people who commit sinful actions]

bsb_verse_text: Then he shall go out to the altar that is before the LORD and make atonement for it. He is to take some of the bull’s blood and some of the goat’s blood and put it on all the horns of the altar.
ult_verse_text: And he shall go out to the altar that {is} to the face of Yahweh, and he shall make atonement for it. And he shall take some of the blood of the bull and some of the blood of the goat and put {it} on the horns of the altar all around.

notes.note: This is the **altar** of sacrifice just inside the courtyard of the tabernacle.

The **horns of the altar** refers to the corners of the altar. They are shaped like the horns of an ox. See how you translated this in [Leviticus 4:7](../04/07.md). Alternate translation: [the projections at the corners of the altar]
Like the holy place and tent of meeting, the altar is unclean because of the sins of the people.

bsb_verse_text: He is to sprinkle some of the blood on it with his finger seven times to cleanse it and consecrate it from the uncleanness of the Israelites.
ult_verse_text: And he shall sprinkle some of the blood on it with his finger seven times. And he shall cleanse it and make it holy from the uncleanness of the sons of Israel.

notes.note: Making the altar fit to be used for God’s purposes is spoken of as if the priest were physically cleansing it.
The altar being dedicated to Yahweh is spoken of as if it were being physically separated from the sins of the people.
Sinful actions which make people unacceptable to Yahweh are spoken of as if they were physical **uncleanness**.

bsb_verse_text: When Aaron has finished purifying the Most Holy Place, the Tent of Meeting, and the altar, he is to bring forward the live goat.
ult_verse_text: And he shall finish from making atonement {for} the Holy Place and the tent of meeting and the altar, and he shall present the living goat.

notes.note: This **goat** is called the scapegoat in verse [Leviticus 16:10](../16/10.md).

bsb_verse_text: Then he is to lay both hands on the head of the live goat and confess over it all the iniquities and rebellious acts of the Israelites in regard to all their sins. He is to put them on the goat’s head and send it away into the wilderness by the hand of a man appointed for the task.
ult_verse_text: And Aaron shall lay two of his hands on the head of the living goat, and he shall confess over it all the iniquity of the sons of Israel and all their rebellion, to all their sins. And he shall put them on the head of the goat, and he shall send {it} away by the hand of a timely man to the wilderness.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [and confess over the goat]
The words **iniquity**, **rebellion**, and **sins** mean basically the same thing. Aaron is confessing every kind of sin that the people committed.

Aaron’s actions here were a symbolic transfer of the peoples’ sin to the **goat** as a sign that the goat would bear the punishment for their guilt. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote.

bsb_verse_text: Then Aaron is to enter the Tent of Meeting, take off the linen garments he put on before entering the Most Holy Place, and leave them there.
ult_verse_text: And Aaron shall enter into the tent of meeting, and he shall remove the linen clothing that he wore when he entered into the Holy Place. And he shall place them there.

notes.note: This was the special **linen clothing** Aaron wore only when he entered the most holy place.

bsb_verse_text: He is to bathe himself with water in a holy place and put on his own clothes. Then he must go out and sacrifice his burnt offering and the people’s burnt offering to make atonement for himself and for the people.
ult_verse_text: And he shall bathe his flesh in the water in a holy place, and he shall wear his clothes. And he shall go out, and he shall make his burnt offering and the burnt offering of the people. And he shall make atonement on behalf of himself and on behalf of the people.

notes.note: Here, **holy place** does not refer to the tent of meeting. This was a different place set aside for him to **bathe** himself.
These **clothes** were the garments that Aaron wore for his ordinary duties.

bsb_verse_text: He is also to burn the fat of the sin offering on the altar.
ult_verse_text: And the fat of the sin offering he shall cause to become smoke on the altar.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [Aaron must burn]

bsb_verse_text: The man who released the goat as the scapegoat must wash his clothes and bathe himself with water; afterward he may reenter the camp.
ult_verse_text: And the person sending away the goat as scapegoat shall wash his clothes, and he shall bathe his flesh in the water. And after {doing} thus, he shall enter into the camp.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הַֽ⁠מְשַׁלֵּ֤חַ אֶת־הַ⁠שָּׂעִיר֙ לַֽ⁠עֲזָאזֵ֔ל יְכַבֵּ֣ס בְּגָדָ֔י⁠ו וְ⁠רָחַ֥ץ אֶת־בְּשָׂר֖⁠וֹ בַּ⁠מָּ֑יִם
notes.note: The man was unclean because of his contact with the scapegoat, which carried the sin of the people.
See how you translated this in [Leviticus 16:8](../16/08.md). Alternate translation: [that bears the sin of the people]

bsb_verse_text: The bull for the sin offering and the goat for the sin offering, whose blood was brought into the Most Holy Place to make atonement, must be taken outside the camp; and their hides, flesh, and dung must be burned up.
ult_verse_text: And the bull of the sin offering and the goat of the sin offering, whose blood was brought to make atonement into the Holy Place, shall be brought out to {a place} outside of the camp. And they shall burn with fire their skins and their flesh and their dung.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [whose blood Aaron brought in]
If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [someone must carry]
Here, **their** refers to the bull and the goat. Alternate translation: [the skins of the bull and the goat]

bsb_verse_text: This is to be a permanent statute for you: On the tenth day of the seventh month, you shall humble yourselves and not do any work—whether the native or the foreigner who resides among you—
ult_verse_text: And it will be for you an enduring statute: in the seventh month on the tenth day of the month, you shall humble your lives, and you shall not do any work—the native-born {person} and the sojourner, the one sojourning among you—

notes.note: The word **you** is plural and refers to the people of Israel, so use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction.

The **seventh month** and the **tenth day** of the Hebrew calendar is near the end of September on the western calendar. You could convert the Hebrew day and month into an approximate date on the calendar that your culture uses. However, the Jews used a lunar calendar, so if you use a solar calendar, the date will be different every year, and the translation will not be entirely accurate. So you may just want to give the number of the day and the name of the month on the Hebrew calendar and say in a footnote approximately what time of year that is on your calendar.

The words **seventh** and **tenth** are the ordinal forms of “seven” and “ten.” If your language would not represent a number in a form such as **in the seventh month**, you could represent this number in a form that your language would use. Alternate translation: [in month seven on day ten of the month]

bsb_verse_text: because on this day atonement will be made for you to cleanse you, and you will be clean from all your sins before the LORD.
ult_verse_text: for on this day, he will make atonement for you to cleanse you from all your sins; to the face of Yahweh, you will be clean.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Aaron will make atonement for you]

Here, people who are acceptable for God’s purposes are spoken of as if they were physically made **clean**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to purify you … you will be pure]

bsb_verse_text: It is a Sabbath of complete rest for you, that you may humble yourselves; it is a permanent statute.
ult_verse_text: It {is} a sabbath of sabbaths for you, and you shall humble your spirits—an enduring statute.

notes.note: This is not the same as the Sabbath they observed every week on the seventh day. This was a special Sabbath on the Day of Atonement.

bsb_verse_text: The priest who is anointed and ordained to succeed his father as high priest shall make atonement. He will put on the sacred linen garments
ult_verse_text: And the priest whom he anoints him and whom he fills his hand to be priest under his father shall make atonement. And he shall wear his linen clothes, the clothes of holiness.

notes.note: When the high priest died, one of his sons would replace him.
These **clothes of holiness** were special clothes the high priest must wear when he enters the most holy place.

bsb_verse_text: and make atonement for the Most Holy Place, the Tent of Meeting, and the altar, and for the priests and all the people of the assembly.
ult_verse_text: And he shall make atonement {for} the Holy Place of holiness, and he shall make atonement {for} the tent of meeting and the altar. And he shall make atonement for the priests and for all the people of the assembly.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [all the people of Israel]

bsb_verse_text: instead of bringing it to the entrance to the Tent of Meeting to present it as an offering to the LORD before His tabernacle—that man shall incur bloodguilt. He has shed blood and must be cut off from among his people.
ult_verse_text: but to the entrance of the tent of meeting he does not bring it to present an offering to Yahweh to the face of the Dwelling of Yahweh—blood will be reckoned to that man. He has shed blood, and that man shall be cut off from the midst of his people

notes.note: Alternate translation: [before Yahweh’s tabernacle]

A person being excluded from his community is spoken of as if he had been **cut off** from his people, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. See how you translated this in [Leviticus 7:20](../07/20.md). Alternate translation: [that person must be cut off from among his people as a branch is cut from a tree]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you could state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [that person may no longer live among his people] or [you must separate that person from his people]

bsb_verse_text: They must no longer offer their sacrifices to the goat demons to which they have prostituted themselves. This will be a permanent statute for them for the generations to come.’
ult_verse_text: And they shall no longer sacrifice their sacrifices to goat demons, after whom they are prostituting themselves. This will be an enduring statute for them for their generations.”’

notes.note: The people being unfaithful to Yahweh by worshiping false gods is spoken of as if they were prostitutes who sold their bodies for money. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [for which they are unfaithful to Yahweh]
See how you translated this phrase in [Leviticus 3:17](../03/17.md).

bsb_verse_text: but does not bring it to the entrance to the Tent of Meeting to sacrifice it to the LORD, that man must be cut off from his people.
ult_verse_text: but to the entrance of the tent of meeting, he does not bring it to make it to Yahweh, then that man shall be cut off from his people.

notes.note: A person being excluded from his community is spoken of as if he had been **cut off from his people**, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. See how you translated this in [Leviticus 7:20](../07/20.md). Alternate translation: [that person must be cut off from among his people like a branch is cut from a tree]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [that person may no longer live among his people] or [you must separate that person from his people]

bsb_verse_text: If anyone from the house of Israel or a foreigner living among them eats any blood, I will set My face against that person and cut him off from among his people.
ult_verse_text: And a man, a man from the house of Israel or from the sojourner sojourning in their midst, who eats any blood, then I will set my face against the person having eaten blood, and I will cut him off from the midst of his people.

notes.note: Here, **set my face against** is a common expression that means he “firmly decided to oppose.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I have made up my mind to oppose that person]

A person being excluded from his community is spoken of as if he had been **cut off** from **his people**, as one would cut a piece of cloth or a branch from a tree. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will not permit that person to live among his people any longer] or [I will separate that person from his people]

bsb_verse_text: For the life of the flesh is in the blood, and I have given it to you to make atonement for your souls upon the altar; for it is the blood that makes atonement for the soul.
ult_verse_text: For the life of the flesh, it is in the blood, and I myself have given it to you on the altar to make atonement for your lives. For the blood, it makes atonement with the life.

notes.note: This means God uses the **blood** to atone for the sins of the people because the blood is **life**. The people should not consume the blood because it has this special purpose.

bsb_verse_text: Therefore I say to the Israelites, ‘None of you may eat blood, nor may any foreigner living among you eat blood.’
ult_verse_text: Therefore, I said to the sons of Israel, “Every person among you shall not eat blood. And the sojourner, the one sojourning in your midst shall not eat blood.”

notes.note: Here, **I** refers to Yahweh.
Alternate translation: [no one among you may eat meat with blood in it]

bsb_verse_text: And if any Israelite or foreigner living among them hunts down a wild animal or bird that may be eaten, he must drain its blood and cover it with dirt.
ult_verse_text: And a man, a man from the sons of Israel or from the sojourner, the one sojourning in their midst, who hunts a game of animal or wing that will be eaten, then he shall pour out its blood, and he shall cover it with soil,

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [that I have said they may eat]

bsb_verse_text: For the life of all flesh is its blood. Therefore I have told the Israelites, ‘You must not eat the blood of any living thing, because the life of all flesh is its blood; whoever eats it must be cut off.’
ult_verse_text: for the life of all flesh, its blood, its life is in it. And I said to the sons of Israel, “The blood of any flesh you shall not eat, for the life of all flesh, it is its blood. All who eat it shall be cut off.”

notes.note: The implication is that the **blood** enables the creature to live. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear. Alternate translation: [each creature is able to live because of its blood]

A person being excluded from his community is spoken of as if he had been **cut off** from his people, as one would cut a piece of cloth or a branch from a tree. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Whoever eats blood may no longer live among his people] or [Anyone who eats blood must be cut off from his people, as if he were a branch cut from a tree]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Whoever eats blood may no longer live among his people] or [You must separate from his people anyone who eats blood]

bsb_verse_text: And any person, whether native or foreigner, who eats anything found dead or mauled by wild beasts must wash his clothes and bathe with water, and he will be unclean until evening; then he will be clean.
ult_verse_text: And any person who eats an {animal} carcass or a torn animal among the native-born or among the sojourner, then he shall wash his clothes, and he shall bathe in the water, and he will be unclean until the evening. Then he will be clean.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [or one that wild animals have killed]
Alternate translation: [among the Israelites]

The person whom other people may not touch is spoken of as if he were physically **unclean** and the person whom other people may touch is spoken of as if he were physically **clean**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state these meanings plainly.
Alternate translation: [until sunset]

bsb_verse_text: But if he does not wash his clothes and bathe himself, then he shall bear his iniquity.”
ult_verse_text: But if he does not wash or his flesh he does not bathe, then he shall bear his iniquity.’”

notes.note: Here a person’s **iniquity** is spoken of as if it were a physical object that the person carries.

Here the word **iniquity** represents the punishment for that iniquity. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [then he is responsible for his own iniquity] or [then I will punish him for his sin]

bsb_verse_text: You are to practice My judgments and keep My statutes by walking in them. I am the LORD your God.
ult_verse_text: My customs you shall do, and my statutes you shall keep, to walk in them. I {am} Yahweh your God.

notes.note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the people must obey everything that Yahweh has commanded them to do. You can translate this parallelism into one statement that conveys the requirement to keep all of Yahweh’s commands. Alternate translation: [You must obey all of my laws and commandments]

Obeying Yahweh’s commandments is spoken of as if they were a way or path that a person walks along. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [so that you conduct your behavior according to them]

bsb_verse_text: None of you are to approach any close relative to have sexual relations. I am the LORD.
ult_verse_text: A man, a man, you shall not draw near to any body of his flesh to uncover nakedness. I am Yahweh.

notes.note: The phrase **to uncover nakedness** is a polite way of referring to sexual activity. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language, or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [to have sexual relations]

bsb_verse_text: You must not expose the nakedness of your father by having sexual relations with your mother. She is your mother; you must not have sexual relations with her.
ult_verse_text: The nakedness of your father and the nakedness of your mother you shall not uncover. She {is} your mother; you shall not uncover her nakedness.

notes.orig_language_quote: עֶרְוַ֥ת אָבִ֛י⁠ךָ וְ⁠עֶרְוַ֥ת אִמְּ⁠ךָ֖ לֹ֣א תְגַלֵּ֑ה
notes.note: This is a polite way of referring to sexual activity. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language, or you could state this plainly. Alternate translation: [Do not have sexual relations with your father or your mother]
This is a polite way of referring to sexual activity. Alternate translation: [you must not have sexual relations with her]

bsb_verse_text: You must not have sexual relations with your father’s wife; it would dishonor your father.
ult_verse_text: The nakedness of the wife of your father you shall not uncover. It {is} the nakedness of your father.

notes.note: Sometimes men had more than one wife. God did not allow a son to have sexual intercourse with any woman married to his father, even if she was not his mother.
Alternate translation: [You would dishonor your father]

bsb_verse_text: You must not have sexual relations with your sister, either your father’s daughter or your mother’s daughter, whether she was born in the same home or elsewhere.
ult_verse_text: The nakedness of your sister, the daughter of your father or the daughter of your mother, born of {the same} house or born outside {it}, you shall not uncover their nakedness.

notes.orig_language_quote: עֶרְוַ֨ת אֲחֽוֹתְ⁠ךָ֤ בַת־אָבִ֨י⁠ךָ֙ א֣וֹ בַת־אִמֶּ֔⁠ךָ מוֹלֶ֣דֶת בַּ֔יִת א֖וֹ מוֹלֶ֣דֶת ח֑וּץ לֹ֥א תְגַלֶּ֖ה עֶרְוָתָֽ⁠ן
notes.note: This is a polite way of referring to sexual activity. See how this is translated in [Leviticus 18:7](../18/07.md). Alternate translation: [Do not have sexual relations with your sister, the daughter of your father or the daughter of your mother, born at home or born outside]
This means a man cannot have sexual intercourse with his sister even if she has a different mother or father.

bsb_verse_text: You must not have sexual relations with your son’s daughter or your daughter’s daughter, for that would shame your family.
ult_verse_text: The nakedness of the daughter of your son or the daughter of your daughter— you shall not uncover their nakedness, for they {are} your nakedness.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [for you will dishonor yourself as well as them]

bsb_verse_text: You must not have sexual relations with the daughter of your father’s wife, born to your father; she is your sister.
ult_verse_text: The nakedness of the daughter of the wife of your father, the one born of your father, she {is} your sister. You shall not uncover her nakedness.

notes.note: This could mean: 1) “your half-sister” or 2) “your stepsister.” Here the man does not have the same father or mother as the woman. They became brother and sister when their parents married.

bsb_verse_text: You must not have sexual relations with your father’s sister; she is your father’s close relative.
ult_verse_text: The nakedness of the sister of your father, you shall not uncover. She is the flesh of your father.

notes.note: This is a polite way of referring to sexual activity. See how this is translated in [Leviticus 18:7](../18/07.md). Alternate translation: [Do not have sexual relations with your father’s sister]

bsb_verse_text: You must not dishonor your father’s brother by approaching his wife to have sexual relations with her; she is your aunt.
ult_verse_text: The nakedness of the brother of your father, you shall not uncover; to his wife you shall not draw near. She is your aunt.

notes.note: You may have to make explicit the purpose of the approach. Alternate translation: [do not go to his wife in order to have sexual relations with her]

bsb_verse_text: You must not have sexual relations with your daughter-in-law. She is your son’s wife; you are not to have sexual relations with her.
ult_verse_text: The nakedness of your daughter-in-law, you shall not uncover. She is the wife of your son. You shall not uncover her nakedness.

notes.note: This is a polite way of referring to sexual activity. See how this is translated in [Leviticus 18:7](../18/07.md). Alternate translation: [Do not have sexual relations with your daughter-in-law]
This is a polite way of referring to sexual activity. Alternate translation: [You must not have sexual relations with her]

bsb_verse_text: You must not have sexual relations with your brother’s wife; that would shame your brother.
ult_verse_text: The nakedness of the wife of your brother, you shall not uncover. She is the nakedness of your brother.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [If you do that, you will dishonor your brother]

bsb_verse_text: You must not have sexual relations with both a woman and her daughter. You are not to marry her son’s daughter or her daughter’s daughter and have sexual relations with her. They are close relatives; it is depraved.
ult_verse_text: The nakedness of a woman and her daughter, you shall not uncover. The daughter of her son or the daughter of her daughter, you shall not take to uncover her nakedness. They are flesh. It is depravity.

notes.note: This is a polite way of referring to sexual activity. See how this is translated in [Leviticus 18:7](../18/07.md). Alternate translation: [Do not have sexual relations with a woman and her daughter]
Alternate translation: [to have sexual relations with her]

bsb_verse_text: You must not approach a woman to have sexual relations with her during her menstrual period.
ult_verse_text: And to a woman in the menstruation of her uncleanness, you shall not draw near to uncover her nakedness.

notes.note: This refers to the time every month when a woman bleeds from her womb.
Alternate translation: [to have sexual relations with her]

bsb_verse_text: You must not give any of your children to be sacrificed to Molech, for you must not profane the name of your God. I am the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And from your seed, you shall not give {them} to cause {them} to pass over to Molech. And you shall not profane the name of your God. I am Yahweh.

notes.note: The phrase **to pass over to Molech** refers to burning a child in the fire as a sacrifice to the idol Molech. Alternate translation: [You must not burn your children alive for Molech]
Here the word **name** represents God himself, and the word **profane** means “to dishonor.” Alternate translation: [And you must not dishonor your God]

bsb_verse_text: You must not lie with a man as with a woman; that is an abomination.
ult_verse_text: And you shall not lie with a male {as} the lyings of a woman. It is an abomination.

notes.note: This is a polite way of speaking of sexual relations. Use a polite way of referring to this in your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Do not have sexual relations with]
Here, **an abomination** refers to a violation of the natural order of things as Yahweh intended them to be.

bsb_verse_text: You must not lie carnally with any animal, thus defiling yourself with it; a woman must not stand before an animal to mate with it; that is a perversion.
ult_verse_text: And with any animal you shall not give your lying to become unclean by it. And a woman shall not stand to the face of an animal to mate with it. It {is} perversion.

notes.note: This is a polite way of referring to sexual activity. Alternate translation: [to have sexual relations with it]

bsb_verse_text: Do not defile yourselves by any of these practices, for by all these things the nations I am driving out before you have defiled themselves.
ult_verse_text: Do not make yourselves unclean in any of these ways, for in all these ways the nations that I am sending out from your faces make themselves unclean.

notes.note: Here, **the nations** refers to the people groups already living in Canaan. Translate this so the term **nations** is clarified as people. Alternate translation: [the people of the nations … have defiled themselves]

bsb_verse_text: Even the land has become defiled, so I am punishing it for its sin, and the land will vomit out its inhabitants.
ult_verse_text: And the land became unclean, and I visited its iniquity on it. And the land vomited out the ones dwelling {in} it.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [And the people defiled the land]
Yahweh forcibly removing the people from the land is spoken of as if **the land vomited out the ones dwelling in it**. Alternate translation: [I forcibly removed the people from the land]
The **land** is spoken of as if it were a living thing that could vomit.

bsb_verse_text: But you are to keep My statutes and ordinances, and you must not commit any of these abominations—neither your native-born nor the foreigner who lives among you.
ult_verse_text: And you yourselves shall keep my statutes and my customs. And you shall not do any of these abominations—the native-born nor the sojourner, the one sojourning in your midst—

notes.note: Alternate translation: [any of these disgusting things]

bsb_verse_text: So if you defile the land, it will vomit you out as it spewed out the nations before you.
ult_verse_text: And the land will not vomit you out in your making it unclean, just as it vomited out the nation that {was} to your faces.

notes.note: Yahweh forcibly removing the people from the land is spoken of as if the land **vomited** the people out. See how you translated this metaphor in [Leviticus 18:25](../18/25.md).
The land is spoken of as if it were a living thing that could **vomit**. See how you translated these phrases in [Leviticus 18:25](../18/25.md).

bsb_verse_text: Therefore anyone who commits any of these abominations must be cut off from among his people.
ult_verse_text: For anyone who does any of these abominations—the people who do will be cut off from the midst of their people.

notes.note: People who are excluded from the community are spoken of as if they had been **cut off** from their people, as one would cut a branch from a tree. Alternate translation: [the people who do these things must be separated from their people as a branch is cut from a tree]

If your language does not use the passive form, you could express this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you must separate those who do such things from their people]

bsb_verse_text: You must keep My charge not to practice any of the abominable customs that were practiced before you, so that you do not defile yourselves by them. I am the LORD your God.”
ult_verse_text: And you shall keep my watch not to do the statutes, the abominations that are done to your faces, and you shall not make yourselves unclean by them. I {am} Yahweh your God.’”

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form, you could express this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [which the people did here before you came]
Here, **them** refers to the abominations and detestable customs.

bsb_verse_text: Each of you must respect his mother and father, and you must keep My Sabbaths. I am the LORD your God.
ult_verse_text: A man, his mother and his father, you shall fear, and my sabbaths you shall keep. I {am} Yahweh your God.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [and you must observe my sabbaths] or [and you must respect my day of rest]

bsb_verse_text: Do not turn to idols or make for yourselves molten gods. I am the LORD your God.
ult_verse_text: You shall not turn to idols, and gods of cast metal you shall not make for yourselves. I {am} Yahweh your God.

notes.note: The worshiping of **idols** is spoken of as if the people would physically turn toward them. Alternate translation: [Do not begin to worship worthless idols]

bsb_verse_text: When you sacrifice a peace offering to the LORD, you shall offer it for your acceptance.
ult_verse_text: And when you sacrifice a sacrifice of peace offerings to Yahweh, you shall sacrifice it for your acceptance.

notes.note: This could mean: 1) Yahweh will accept the person offering the sacrifice. Alternate translation: [you must offer it properly so that I will accept you] or 2) Yahweh will accept the sacrifice from the person. Alternate translation: [you must offer it properly so that I will accept your sacrifice]

bsb_verse_text: It shall be eaten on the day you sacrifice it, or on the next day; but what remains on the third day must be burned up.
ult_verse_text: On the day of your sacrifice, it shall be eaten, or from tomorrow. And the remainder until the third day shall be burned with fire.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you must eat it]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you must burn up in the fire what is left until the third day]

bsb_verse_text: If any of it is eaten on the third day, it is tainted and will not be accepted.
ult_verse_text: But if, eating, it is eaten on the third day, it {is} defiled. It will not be accepted.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And if you eat any of it]

To eat the offering after the designated time is against God and increases the guilt the offering was to cover. If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [God will not accept it]

bsb_verse_text: Whoever eats it will bear his iniquity, for he has profaned what is holy to the LORD. That person must be cut off from his people.
ult_verse_text: And the person eating it shall bear his iniquity because he profaned the holiness of Yahweh. And that person shall be cut off from his people.

notes.note: A person’s **iniquity** is spoken of as if it were a physical object that the person can lift. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And the person eating it will be guilty]

Here the word **iniquity** represents the punishment for that sin. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your own language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And everyone who eats the sacrifice is responsible for his own sin] or [Yahweh will punish the sin of him who eats the sacrifice]

A person being excluded from his community is spoken of as if he had been cut off from his people, as one would cut a piece of cloth or cut a branch from a tree. See how you translated this in [Leviticus 7:20](../07/20.md). Alternate translation: [And that person must be cut off from among his people as a branch is cut from a tree]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [That person may no longer live among his people] or [You must separate that person from his people]

bsb_verse_text: When you reap the harvest of your land, you are not to reap to the very edges of your field or gather the gleanings of your harvest.
ult_verse_text: And in your harvesting the harvest of your land, you shall not complete the edge of your field to harvest, and the gleaning of your harvest you shall not glean.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּֽ⁠בְ⁠קֻצְרְ⁠כֶם֙ אֶת־קְצִ֣יר אַרְצְ⁠כֶ֔ם לֹ֧א תְכַלֶּ֛ה פְּאַ֥ת שָׂדְ⁠ךָ֖
notes.note: Alternate translation: [And when you gather your crops, do not gather all the way to the edges of your fields]

This refers to the practice of going back over the fields a second time to gather any produce that remained after the first time. The full meaning of this statement can be made explicit. Alternate translation: [and do not go back and pick up all that you left behind]

bsb_verse_text: You must not swear falsely by My name and so profane the name of your God. I am the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And you shall not swear by my name to a lie and profane the name of your God. I {am} Yahweh.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [And do not use my name to swear about something that is not true]

bsb_verse_text: You must not defraud your neighbor or rob him. You must not withhold until morning the wages due a hired hand.
ult_verse_text: You shall not extort your neighbor, and you shall not rob. You shall not retain the wages of a hired {person} with you until morning.

notes.note: Here, **neighbor** means “anyone.” The meaning of this can be made explicit. Alternate translation: [Do not hurt or rob anyone]
Yahweh commands the employer to pay his servant promptly when his work is done that day. The full meaning of this statement can be made clear.

bsb_verse_text: You must not pervert justice; you must not show partiality to the poor or favoritism to the rich; you are to judge your neighbor fairly.
ult_verse_text: You shall not do injustice with judgment. You shall not lift the face of an insignificant {person}, and you shall not honor the face of a great {person}. In righteousness, you shall judge your fellow citizen.

notes.note: The double negative **not … injustice** is used for emphasis. If it would be helpful in your language, you could express the positive meaning. Alternate translation: [Always judge rightly]

notes.orig_language_quote: לֹא־תִשָּׂ֣א פְנֵי־דָ֔ל וְ⁠לֹ֥א תֶהְדַּ֖ר פְּנֵ֣י גָד֑וֹל
notes.note: The words **insignificant person** and **great person** are two extremes, which together mean “anyone.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [You must not show favoritism to anyone based on how much money they have]
Alternate translation: [Judge everyone according to what is right]

bsb_verse_text: You must not go about spreading slander among your people. You must not endanger the life of your neighbor. I am the LORD.
ult_verse_text: You shall not walk {as} a slanderer among your people. You shall not stand against the blood of your neighbor. I {am} Yahweh.

notes.note: A **slanderer** is someone who says untrue and hurtful things about other people.

bsb_verse_text: You must not harbor hatred against your brother in your heart. Directly rebuke your neighbor, so that you will not incur guilt on account of him.
ult_verse_text: You shall not hate your brother with your heart. Reproving, you shall reprove your fellow citizen, and you shall not lift sin on him.

notes.note: Continually hating a person is spoken of as if it were hating a person in the **heart**. Alternate translation: [Do not continually hate your brother]
Alternate translation: [You must correct your fellow Israelite who is sinning]

bsb_verse_text: If a man lies carnally with a slave girl promised to another man but who has not been redeemed or given her freedom, there must be due punishment. But they are not to be put to death, because she had not been freed.
ult_verse_text: And a man, when he lies with a woman, a lying of seed, but she is a {female} slave, a {woman} being assigned to a man, but, being redeemed, she has not been redeemed or freedom has not been given to her, recompense shall occur. They shall not be executed because she had not been freed.

notes.note: This is a polite way of referring to sexual activity. Alternate translation: [he has sexual relations with]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [whom someone promised to give to a man as his wife]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הָפְדֵּה֙ לֹ֣א נִפְדָּ֔תָה א֥וֹ חֻפְשָׁ֖ה לֹ֣א נִתַּן־לָ֑⁠הּ
notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [but whom her future husband has not ransomed or given her freedom]
If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [You must not kill them]

bsb_verse_text: The man, however, must bring a ram to the entrance to the Tent of Meeting as his guilt offering to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And he shall bring his guilt to Yahweh, to the entrance of the tent of meeting—a ram of a guilt offering.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הֵבִ֤יא אֶת־אֲשָׁמ⁠וֹ֙ לַֽ⁠יהוָ֔ה אֶל־פֶּ֖תַח אֹ֣הֶל מוֹעֵ֑ד אֵ֖יל אָשָֽׁם
notes.note: Alternate translation: [And a man must bring a ram as a guilt offering to Yahweh to the entrance of the tent of meeting]

bsb_verse_text: The priest shall make atonement on his behalf before the LORD with the ram of the guilt offering for the sin he has committed, and he will be forgiven the sin he has committed.
ult_verse_text: And the priest will make atonement for him with the ram of the guilt offering to the face of Yahweh for his sin that he sinned. And it will be forgiven to him from his sin that he sinned.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Yahweh will forgive the sin which he has committed]

bsb_verse_text: When you enter the land and plant any kind of tree for food, you shall regard the fruit as forbidden. For three years it will be forbidden to you and must not be eaten.
ult_verse_text: And when you enter into the land, and you plant every tree of food, then you shall leave uncircumcised {as} its foreskin its fruit. Three years it shall be uncircumcised to you. It shall not be eaten.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠עֲרַלְתֶּ֥ם עָרְלָת֖⁠וֹ אֶת־פִּרְי֑⁠וֹ שָׁלֹ֣שׁ שָׁנִ֗ים יִהְיֶ֥ה לָ⁠כֶ֛ם עֲרֵלִ֖ים לֹ֥א יֵאָכֵֽל
notes.note: Yahweh repeats the prohibition in order to emphasize it and to clarify that it is in force for the first three years that the tree bears fruit. Translate this to clarify the period of time the trees must be left alone. Alternate translation: [then you must consider the fruit of the trees to be unclean for the first three years and not eat any of it until after that]
If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [You must not eat it]

bsb_verse_text: You must not defile your daughter by making her a prostitute, or the land will be prostituted and filled with depravity.
ult_verse_text: You shall not profane your daughter by making her practice prostitution, and the land shall not practice prostitution, or the land will fill {itself with} depravity.

notes.note: Here both occurrences of the word **land** represent the people who live there. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [or the people will begin to practice prostitution and many wicked things]

Many people practicing **prostitution** and other **depravity** is spoken of as if the land has become full of those things. Alternate translation: [lest the people begin to practice prostitution and many wicked things]

bsb_verse_text: You must not turn to mediums or spiritists; do not seek them out, or you will be defiled by them. I am the LORD your God.
ult_verse_text: You shall not turn to the mediums, and to the spiritists, you shall not seek to become unclean by them. I {am} Yahweh your God.

notes.note: The **mediums** were people who claimed to speak with dead people. The **spiritists** claimed to be able to predict what would happen in the future. The Israelites were not allowed to have anything to do with these people.
Alternate translation: [do not seek those people out. If you do, they will defile you]

bsb_verse_text: You are to rise in the presence of the elderly, honor the aged, and fear your God. I am the LORD.
ult_verse_text: From the face of gray hair, you shall rise, and you shall honor the face of an elderly {person}. You shall fear your God. I {am} Yahweh.

notes.note: Here, **you shall rise** is a symbolic action that is meant to show respect. Standing up in front of someone is a sign of respect in some cultures. If this would not be clear to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. AT: [you must act respectfully toward them]
A face of **gray-hair** refers to a person whose hair has turned gray from age, or “an old person.”

bsb_verse_text: You must not use dishonest measures of length, weight, or volume.
ult_verse_text: You shall not do injustice with judgment, in measure, in weight, or in volume.

notes.note: This prohibits the practice of intentionally using instruments that give inaccurate readings when measuring things.

bsb_verse_text: You shall maintain honest scales and weights, an honest ephah, and an honest hin. I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt.
ult_verse_text: Scales of righteousness, stones of righteousness, an ephah of righteousness, and a hin of righteousness shall belong to you. I {am} Yahweh your God, who is bringing you from the land of Egypt.

notes.note: An **ephah** was a measurement for grain.
A **hin** was a measurement for liquids.

bsb_verse_text: You must keep all My statutes and all My ordinances and follow them. I am the LORD.”
ult_verse_text: And you shall keep all my statutes and all my customs, and you shall do them. I {am} Yahweh.’”

notes.note: These phrases mean the same thing and emphasize the command for obedience.

bsb_verse_text: Then the LORD said to Moses,
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh spoke to Moses, saying,

notes.note: The word translated **saying** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, use a natural way of introducing direct quotations in your language. It may not be necessary to represent this term explicitly.

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. It may be helpful to begin a new sentence here. Alternate translation (with a period before): [He told Moses to speak to the sons of Israel and say that]

bsb_verse_text: “Tell the Israelites, ‘Any Israelite or foreigner living in Israel who gives any of his children to Molech must be put to death. The people of the land are to stone him.
ult_verse_text: “And to the sons of Israel, you shall say, ‘A man, a man from the sons of Israel or from the sojourner, the one sojourning in Israel, who gives from his seed to Molech—dying, he shall be executed. The people of the land shall stone him with the rock.

notes.note: See how you translated this metaphor in [1:2](../01/02.md).

Here the masculine term **A man, a man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both men and women. For more information, please see the Leviticus 20 Chapter Introduction on repeating words for emphasis. Alternate translation: [Any person]

This expression is an idiom that means to offer one’s children to **Molech** in a sacrifice. Those who worshiped **Molech** often sacrificed their children to him by means of fire. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [who kills any of his children as a sacrifice to Molech]

This expression uses a metaphor to relate the word **seed** to one’s children. Whether semen was thought of to resemble plant seed is unclear, although the same word is used to refer to both. (See [11:37](../11/37.md) and [15:16](../15/16.md) for reference.) If your language uses a similar metaphor, consider using it here. If not consider using a generic expression. Alternate translation: [from his children]

**Molech** is a word borrowed from Hebrew. You will need to decide if you will also borrow this word into your language. If you borrow the word, you could spell it the way it sounds in your language and then put the translation in a footnote. If you choose to translate the term, consider using a generic expression. See how you translated the name of this deity in [18:21](../18/21.md). Alternate translation: [to a false god] or [to an idol]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [dying, the people of Israel shall execute him]

This expression repeats the verb **dying** in order to intensify the idea that it expresses. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the emphasis. Alternate translation: [the person shall certainly be executed] or, to avoid the passive construction, [the people of Israel shall certainly execute him]

This expression refers to a method of public execution by which members of the community throw stones at a person convicted of wrongdoing until the individual dies. As such, the person’s death is public and slow. If your language has a word or phrase for this sort of public execution, consider using it here. If not, consider using a generic expression. Alternate translation: [The people of the land shall put him to death publicly]

The expression **the people of the land** uses the possessive form to describe people who live in the land of Israel, whether foreigner or native-born. If your language would not use the possessive form for this, consider using a generic expression. Alternate translation: [Whoever lives in the land of Israel] or [Everybody]

The expression **the rock** represents “rocks” in general and not a specific rock. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an expression that is more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [shall stone him with rocks]

bsb_verse_text: And I will set My face against that man and cut him off from his people, because by giving his offspring to Molech, he has defiled My sanctuary and profaned My holy name.
ult_verse_text: And I myself will set my face against that man, and I will cut him off from among his people, for he gave his seed to Molech, to make my Holy Place unclean and to profane my holy name.

notes.note: Here, the words **I** and **my** refer to Yahweh, the one speaking to Moses. If it would be helpful in your language, consider making this explicit. Alternate translation: [And I, Yahweh, will set my face]

Here, the expression **that man** refers to the individual who sacrifices his children to worship Molech. If it would be helpful in your language, consider making the referent explicit. Alternate translation: [against the person who sacrifices his children to worship Molech]

The punishment for sacrificing one’s children to worship Molech is spoken of as if Yahweh were literally cutting off the individual from his people. It may be helpful to refer to how you handled the similar expression in [7:20](../07/20.md).
See how you translated the similar phrase in [20:2](../20/02.md). Alternate translation: [because he has sacrificed his child to Molech]

The word translated as **for** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation (with a period before): [I will do this because]

This expression implies that child sacrifice performed in the worship of Molech makes Yahweh’s **Holy Place** unclean, that is, unfit for hosting the holy presence of Yahweh or the worship of him. You could include this information if it would be helpful to your readers. It may be helpful to consult how you handled the idea of something becoming **unclean** in [5:3](../05/03.md).

The word translated as **to** indicate that what follows is a result for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation (with a period before): [He did this in order to]

Here, **name** represents Yahweh and, by extension, Yahweh’s reputation for holiness. So, to **profane** this **name** is to associate Yahweh with that which is not holy, but rather, abominable and detestable, like child sacrifice. If your language has a similar expression, consider using it here. If not, consider using a generic expression. Alternate translation: [and to publicly defame me] or [and to openly denigrate my reputation]

bsb_verse_text: And if the people of the land ever hide their eyes and fail to put to death the man who gives one of his children to Molech,
ult_verse_text: And if, hiding, the people of the land hide their eyes from that man when he gives his seed to Molech, so as not to execute him,

notes.orig_language_quote: הַעְלֵ֣ם יַעְלִימֽוּ֩ עַ֨ם הָ⁠אָ֜רֶץ אֶת־עֵֽינֵי⁠הֶם֙ מִן־הָ⁠אִ֣ישׁ הַ⁠ה֔וּא
notes.note: Here, the **eyes** of a person represents their attention and focus, and the phrase **hiding, the people of the land hide their eyes** is an expression that refers to disregarding or ignoring something. It means that the **people of the land** disregard or ignore what **that man** does. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the people of the land disregard that man] or [the people of the land ignore what that man does]

This expression repeats the verb **hiding** in order to intensify the idea that it expresses. If your language can repeat words for intensification, it would be appropriate to do that here in your translation. If not, your language may have another way of expressing the intensification. Alternate translation: [the people of the land ever hide their eyes]

Here, the expression **that man** refers to the individual who sacrifices his children to worship Molech. You could make this explicit to your readers if it would be helpful in your language. Alternate translation: [the person who sacrifices his children to worship Molech]
See how you translated the similar phrase in [20:2](../20/02.md). Alternate translation: [when he sacrifices his child to Molech]

The words translated as **so as not to** indicate that what follows is a result of what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation: [and, as a result, the man is not executed] or, to avoid the passive: [meaning, they do not execute him]

bsb_verse_text: then I will set My face against that man and his family and cut off from among their people both him and all who follow him in prostituting themselves with Molech.
ult_verse_text: then I myself will set my face against that man and his clan. And I will cut him off and all the people who practice prostitution after him, by prostituting after Molech, from the midst of their people.

notes.note: The words **I**, **myself**, and **my** refer to Yahweh, while the words **that man** refer to the individual who has sacrificed his children to the false god Molech. If this would be helpful in your language, consider making these referents explicit. Alternate translation: [then I, Yahweh, will put my face against the individual who has sacrificed his children to Molech]

Like the expression “I will put my face against that man” in [20:3](../20/03.md), this expression is an idiom that refers to a decision to oppose someone. Here, the word **face** represents the entire person by metonymy. If your language has a similar idiom, consider using it here. If not, consider using a generic expression. Alternate translation: [And I will personally oppose that man] or [And I will make myself the enemy of that man]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הִכְרַתִּ֨י אֹת֜⁠וֹ וְ⁠אֵ֣ת ׀ כָּל־הַ⁠זֹּנִ֣ים אַחֲרָ֗י⁠ו לִ⁠זְנ֛וֹת אַחֲרֵ֥י הַ⁠מֹּ֖לֶךְ מִ⁠קֶּ֥רֶב עַמָּֽ⁠ם
notes.note: The punishment for sacrificing one’s children to worship Molech is spoken of as if Yahweh were literally cutting off the individual from his people. It may be helpful to refer to how you handled the similar expression in [7:20](../07/20.md).

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אֵ֣ת ׀ כָּל־הַ⁠זֹּנִ֣ים אַחֲרָ֗י⁠ו לִ⁠זְנ֛וֹת אַחֲרֵ֥י הַ⁠מֹּ֖לֶךְ
notes.note: Here Yahweh is speaking of those who are unfaithful to him and worship other gods as if they were **people who practice prostitution**. This implies a marriage between Yahweh and the people of Israel, such that Yahweh is like a husband and the people of Israel are like a wife. If your language has a similar metaphor to describe being religiously unfaithful in worship, consider using it here. If not, consider using a generic expression. Alternate translation: [and all the people who are unfaithful to Yahweh by choosing to worship Molech]

bsb_verse_text: Whoever turns to mediums or spiritists to prostitute himself with them, I will also set My face against that person and cut him off from his people.
ult_verse_text: And the person who turns to the mediums or to the spiritists to practice prostitution after them—I will set my face against that person. And I will cut him off from among his people.

notes.note: This expression uses the idiom of turning to **mediums** and **spiritists** to refer to a person who decides to disregard Yahweh and his commandments and consult these means of talking to the dead instead. If your language has a similar idiom for religious disobedience, consider using it here. If not, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And the person who is unfaithful to Yahweh by consulting mediums or spiritists]
See how you how translated these terms in [19:31](../19/31.md).

Here those who are unfaithful to Yahweh and instead worship other gods are compared to prostitutes. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. See how you translated the similar expression in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [by choosing to worship Molech instead]

The punishment for these behaviors is spoken of as if Yahweh were literally cutting off the individual from his people. It may be helpful to refer to how you handled the similar expression in [7:20](../07/20.md).

bsb_verse_text: Consecrate yourselves, therefore, and be holy, because I am the LORD your God.
ult_verse_text: So you shall make yourselves holy and you shall be holy {people}, because I {am} Yahweh your God.

notes.note: The word translated as **because** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation (with a period before): [You should do this because I am Yahweh your God]

bsb_verse_text: And you shall keep My statutes and practice them. I am the LORD who sanctifies you.
ult_verse_text: And you shall keep my statutes, and you shall do them. I {am} Yahweh, the one making you holy.

notes.note: Here, **you** is plural. They refer to the people of Israel, so use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction.

The phrases **you shall keep my statutes** and **you shall do them** mean basically the same thing. They are used together in order to emphasize that the people must obey God. Alternate translation: [You must keep my statutes; indeed, you must do them diligently]

bsb_verse_text: If anyone curses his father or mother, he must be put to death. He has cursed his father or mother; his blood shall be upon him.
ult_verse_text: When a man, a man who curses his father or his mother, dying—he shall be executed. His father and his mother he has cursed; his blood {is} on him.

notes.note: Words are being repeated for emphasis. Specifically, **man** is repeated to refer to any person. Additionally, even though **man** is masculine, it is being used in a generic way that refers to both men and women. If your language can repeat words in a similar way, consider doing so here. If not, consider using a generic expression. See how you translated this repetition in [20:2](../20/02.md). Alternate translation: [any person]

notes.orig_language_quote: אֲשֶׁ֨ר יְקַלֵּ֧ל אֶת־אָבִ֛י⁠ו וְ⁠אֶת־אִמּ֖⁠וֹ & אָבִ֧י⁠ו וְ⁠אִמּ֛⁠וֹ קִלֵּ֖ל
notes.note: Here the act of cursing one’s father or mother refers to speaking dishonorable and harmful words against one’s parents or to uttering a formalized sequence of words intended to bring about harm to one’s parents. Cursing one’s parents enacts a desire to see them harmed instead of a desire to care for them and honor them. (See [19:3](../19/03.md).) If your language has a word for this kind of harmful speech, consider using it here. If not, consider using a generic expression. Alternate translation: [who wishes harm on his father or his mother and so speaks dishonorably toward them … He has spoken harm toward his father and his mother]
See how you handled this expression in [20:2](../20/02.md).

The phrase **his blood** represents the individual’s guilt for the bloodshed or death of the individual’s parents that his curse brings about. Additionally, this guilt is spoken of as being **on** the individual as if it were a burden that he must carry. If your language has a comparable expression that is used to speak of the legal requirement for an individual to be held responsible for their actions, consider using it here. If not, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [he must be held responsible] or, to avoid the passive, [he must bear the bloodguilt he has acquired by his actions]

bsb_verse_text: If a man commits adultery with another man’s wife—with the wife of his neighbor—both the adulterer and the adulteress must surely be put to death.
ult_verse_text: And a man who commits adultery {with} the wife of a man, who commits adultery {with} the wife of his neighbor—dying, the adulterer and the adulteress shall be executed.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אִ֗ישׁ אֲשֶׁ֤ר יִנְאַף֙ אֶת־אֵ֣שֶׁת אִ֔ישׁ אֲשֶׁ֥ר יִנְאַ֖ף אֶת־אֵ֣שֶׁת רֵעֵ֑⁠הוּ
notes.note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that the man has committed **adultery** with another man’s **wife**. You can translate this parallelism into one statement that conveys the seriousness of these actions. Alternate translation: [And who ever commits adultery with another man’s wife, indeed, his neighbor’s wife]
See how you handled this expression in [20:2](../20/02.md).

The words **adulterer** and **adulteress** refer to the man and woman who have committed adultery, respectively. You could state this explicitly in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the man and the woman who have committed adultery]

bsb_verse_text: If a man lies with his father’s wife, he has uncovered his father’s nakedness. Both must surely be put to death; their blood is upon them.
ult_verse_text: And a man who lies with the wife of his father—he has uncovered the nakedness of his father. Dying, both of them shall be executed; their blood {is} on them.

notes.note: This is a polite way of speaking of sexual relations. Depending on what is helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to this in your language, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And a man who sleeps with the wife of his father] or [And a man who has sexual relations with the wife of his father]
See how you handled the similar expression in [18:6](../18/06.md).

See how you handled the similar expression in [20:2](../20/02.md). Alternate translation: [Both of them shall certainly be executed] or, to avoid the passive construction [The people of Israel shall certainly execute both of them]
See how you handled the similar expression in [20:9](../20/09.md).

bsb_verse_text: If a man lies with his daughter-in-law, both must surely be put to death. They have acted perversely; their blood is upon them.
ult_verse_text: And a man who lies with his daughter-in-law—dying, both of them shall be executed. They have done perversion; their blood {is} on them.

notes.note: This is a polite way of speaking of sexual relations. See how you handled the similar expression in the previous verse. Alternate translation: [And a man who sleeps with his daughter-in-law] or [And a man who has sexual relations with his daughter-in-law]
A **daughter-in-law** is the wife of one’s son. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could include this information. Alternate translation: [with his son’s wife]
See how you translated this exact phrase in [20:11](../20/11.md).

Here the abstract noun **perversion** refers to a behavior that is considered to be far outside the bounds of what Yahweh intends for people to do. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **perversion**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [The thing they have done is perverted and disgusting] or [Such behavior is forbidden because it is so disgusting and perverse]
See how you handled the similar expression in [20:9](../20/09.md).

bsb_verse_text: If a man lies with a man as with a woman, they have both committed an abomination. They must surely be put to death; their blood is upon them.
ult_verse_text: And a man who lies with a male, lying as a woman, both of them have done an abomination. Dying, they shall be executed; their blood {is} on them.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אִ֗ישׁ אֲשֶׁ֨ר יִשְׁכַּ֤ב אֶת־זָכָר֙ מִשְׁכְּבֵ֣י אִשָּׁ֔ה
notes.note: The expression **lying as a woman** represents sexual activity. In particular, it refers to a man having sexual relations with another man in the same manner in which he would have sexual relations with a woman. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state this in plain language. Alternate translation: [And a man who lies with a man as he would with a woman]
See how you handled this euphemism in [20:11](../20/11.md).

Here, the abstract noun **abomination** refers to a violation of the way that Yahweh intended his creation to be ordered. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **abomination**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [what both of them have done does not respect the way that God intends his creation to be ordered]
See how you handled the similar expression in [20:2](../20/02.md).
See how you handled the similar expression in [20:9](../20/09.md).

bsb_verse_text: If a man marries both a woman and her mother, it is depraved. Both he and they must be burned in the fire, so that there will be no depravity among you.
ult_verse_text: And a man who takes a wife and her mother—this {is} depravity. They shall burn him and them with fire, and depravity will not be in your midst.

notes.note: The expression **takes a wife and her mother** is either an idiom that refers to a man marrying both a woman and her mother or a euphemism that refers to a man having sexual relations with a woman and her mother. If possible, consider a translation that will allow for both possibilities. Alternate translation: [And a man who marries a woman and her mother] or [And a man who has sexual relations with both a woman and her mother]

The word **depravity** refers to behavior that flagrantly violates the way God has intended family units to function and family members to relate to one another. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **depravity**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [such behavior is surely depraved … and such depraved behavior will not be in your midst] or [such behavior does not reflect the way God wants family members to relate to one another … and such despicable behavior will not be in your midst]

Here the word **They** refers to the people of Israel, while the word **them** refers to the woman and her mother who have had sexual relations with the same man.
