It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [The people of Israel shall burn the man and both women with fire]
Here, **your** is plural. It refers to the people of Israel, so use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction.

bsb_verse_text: If a man lies carnally with an animal, he must be put to death. And you are also to kill the animal.
ult_verse_text: And a man who gives his layer in a livestock—dying, he shall be executed, and you shall kill the livestock.

notes.note: This is a euphemism for sexual activity. See how you translated the similar expressions in [18:20](../18/20.md) and [18:23](../18/23.md). Alternate translation: [And a man who has sexual relations with a livestock so that he ejaculates]
See how you handled the similar expression in [20:2](../20/02.md).
Here, **you** is plural. It refers to the people of Israel, so use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction.

bsb_verse_text: If a woman approaches any animal to mate with it, you must kill both the woman and the animal. They must surely be put to death; their blood is upon them.
ult_verse_text: And a woman who draws near to any livestock to mate with it—then you shall kill the woman and the livestock. Dying, they must be executed; their blood {is} on them.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אִשָּׁ֗ה אֲשֶׁ֨ר תִּקְרַ֤ב אֶל־כָּל־בְּהֵמָה֙ לְ⁠רִבְעָ֣ה אֹתָ֔⁠הּ
notes.note: This is a polite but technical way of speaking of sexual activity between two animals. See how you translated a similar expression in [18:23](../18/23.md). Alternate translation: [And a woman who draws near to any livestock to copulate with it] or [And a woman who draws near to any livestock to have sexual relations with it]

These two phrases mean basically the same thing and emphasize that people of Israel are to execute the woman and kill the animal who engages in this behavior. The first phrase states the idea more explicitly while the second phrase uses a generic expression. You can translate the phrases into one statement that conveys the seriousness of these actions. Alternate translation: [then you must execute the woman, yes, and even execute the livestock]
See how you handled the similar expression in [20:2](../20/02.md).
See how you handled the similar expression in [20:9](../20/09.md).

bsb_verse_text: If a man marries his sister, whether the daughter of his father or of his mother, and they have sexual relations, it is a disgrace. They must be cut off in the sight of their people. He has uncovered the nakedness of his sister; he shall bear his iniquity.
ult_verse_text: And a man who takes his sister, the daughter of his father or the daughter of his mother, and he sees her nakedness, and she herself sees his nakedness—it {is} a disgrace. And they shall be cut off in the eyes of the sons of their people. The nakedness of his sister he has uncovered; he shall bear his iniquity.

notes.note: The expression **takes his sister** is either an idiom that refers to a man marrying his sister or a euphemism that refers to a man having sexual relations with his sister. If possible, consider a translation that will allow for both possibilities. Alternate translation: [And a man who marries his sister] or [And a man who has sexual relations with his sister]

The implication is that a person cannot have sexual intercourse with his sister even if she has a different mother or father. You could include this information if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [your stepsister]

To **see** a person’s **nakedness** expresses a similar idea to uncovering one’s **nakednes**. It is implied that seeing another person’s nakedness disgraces and brings shame on both individuals. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and they see one another naked and so bring shame on one another]

The word **disgrace** refers to behavior that flagrantly violates the way God has intended family units to function and family members to relate to one another. If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **disgrace**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [such behavior is surely disgraceful] or [such behavior does not reflect the way God wants family members to relate to one another]

See how you translated the similar expression in [7:20](../07/20.md). This expression uses the word **eyes** to refer to one’s attention and sight. If your language has a similar expression, consider using it here. If not, consider using a generic expression. Alternate translation: [And they should be excommunicated in the sight of the sons of their people] or, to avoid the passive form, [And the sons of the people should publicly remove them from their sight and refuse to have contact with them]

Here the masculine term **sons** has a generic sense that includes all descendants, male and female. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language that is clearly inclusive of both sons and daughters. Alternate translation: [the children of their people]
See how you handled the similar expression in [18:6](../18/06.md).
See how you handled the similar expression in [5:1](../05/01.md).

bsb_verse_text: If a man lies with a menstruating woman and has sexual relations with her, he has exposed the source of her flow, and she has uncovered the source of her blood. Both of them must be cut off from among their people.
ult_verse_text: And a man who lies with a sick woman—and he has uncovered her nakedness; he has exposed her flow, and she herself has uncovered the flow of her blood. And {the} two of them shall be cut off from among their people.

notes.note: See how you handled this euphemism in [20:11](../20/11.md).

This expression does not refer to physical sickness but rather to a woman’s experience of normal menstruation. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could include this information. See how you translated the similar expression in [15:33](../15/33.md). Alternate translation: [a woman who is experiencing her normal menstruation]
See how you handled the similar expression in [18:6](../18/06.md).

notes.orig_language_quote: אֶת־מְקֹרָ֣⁠הּ הֶֽעֱרָ֔ה וְ⁠הִ֕יא גִּלְּתָ֖ה אֶת־מְק֣וֹר דָּמֶ֑י⁠הָ
notes.note: The expressions **her flow** and the **the flow of her blood** refer to a woman’s genitals during her normal menstruation. Similar to the euphemism “to uncover one’s nakedness,” uncovering a woman’s genitals during menstruation is thought to bring shame on both her and the man involved. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could indicate this explicitly in your translation. Alternate translation: [he has exposed her genitals during her normal menstruation and so shamed her, and she has uncovered the source of her genital bleeding and so brought shame on herself]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:20](../07/20.md).

bsb_verse_text: You must not have sexual relations with the sister of your mother or your father, for it is exposing one’s own kin; both shall bear their iniquity.
ult_verse_text: And the nakedness of the sister of your mother or the sister of your father, you shall not uncover because he would expose his body. They shall carry their iniquity.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠עֶרְוַ֨ת אֲח֧וֹת אִמְּ⁠ךָ֛ וַ⁠אֲח֥וֹת אָבִ֖י⁠ךָ לֹ֣א תְגַלֵּ֑ה
notes.note: See how you handled the similar euphemism in [18:6](../18/06.md).

The word translated as **because** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation (with a period before): [He should not do this because he would expose his relative]
See how you handled the similar expression in [5:1](../05/01.md).
See how you handled the similar expression in [5:1](../05/01.md).

bsb_verse_text: If a man lies with his uncle’s wife, he has uncovered the nakedness of his uncle. They will bear their sin; they shall die childless.
ult_verse_text: And a man who lies with his aunt, he has uncovered the nakedness of his uncle. They will bear their sin; they will die childless.

notes.note: See how you handled this euphemism in [20:11](../20/11.md).
See how you handled the similar expression in [18:6](../18/06.md).

Similar to the expression “to bear one’s iniquity,” this expression speaks of carrying one’s **sin** as if it were a burden to carry. This means being held responsible for one’s wrongdoing. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [They shall be held responsible for their sin] or [They shall bear the guilt of their sin]

bsb_verse_text: If a man marries his brother’s wife, it is an act of impurity. He has uncovered the nakedness of his brother; they shall be childless.
ult_verse_text: And a man who takes the wife of his brother, it is menstruation {impurity}. He has uncovered the nakedness of his brother; they will be childless.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [20:14](../20/14.md).
See how you handled the similar expression in [18:6](../18/06.md).

Unlike the previous verse, in which a man who has sexual relations with his aunt is said to “die childless,” here both the man and the wife of his brother will **be childless**. These two expressions likely have the same meaning: both couples will die before they produce any children together. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [They shall die and not have any children]

bsb_verse_text: You are therefore to keep all My statutes and ordinances, so that the land where I am bringing you to live will not vomit you out.
ult_verse_text: And you shall keep all my statutes and all my judgments. And you shall do them, and the land that I am bringing you there to dwell in it will not vomit you out.

notes.note: Here, **you** is plural. It refers to the people of Israel, so use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction.

Yahweh forcibly removing the people from **the land** is spoken of as if the land itself **vomited** the people out. If your language has a similar metaphor, consider using it here. If not, you could state the meaning plainly. See how you translated this personification of the land in [18:25](../18/25.md). Alternate translation: [and from the land … I will not forcibly remove you]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠לֹא־תָקִ֤יא אֶתְ⁠כֶם֙ הָ⁠אָ֔רֶץ אֲשֶׁ֨ר אֲנִ֜י מֵבִ֥יא אֶתְ⁠כֶ֛ם שָׁ֖מָּ⁠ה לָ⁠שֶׁ֥בֶת בָּֽ⁠הּ
notes.note: Here, **the land** is described as if it were a living thing that could **vomit**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and the land to which I am bringing you will not reject you]

bsb_verse_text: You must not follow the statutes of the nations I am driving out before you. Because they did all these things, I abhorred them.
ult_verse_text: And you shall not walk in the statutes of the nation that I am sending out from before your face, for they do all these things, and I loathe them.’

notes.note: Here and throughout this chapter, the words **you** and **your** are plural. They refer to the people of Israel, so use the plural form in your translation if your language marks that distinction.

Here, the word **walk** is used to describe a habitual lifestyle. In context, to **walk in the statutes of the nation** describes a practice of living that models itself after the practices of the people of the nations who live around Israel. If your language has a similar metaphor, consider using it here. If not, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And you shall not follow the statutes of the nation] or [And you shall not make a practice of living according to the statutes of the nation]

Here, **face** represents the presence of a person. In this expression, Yahweh is removing **the nation** that currently lives in the land from before Israel. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [that I am sending away from your presence] or [that I am sending from before you]

bsb_verse_text: But I have told you that you will inherit their land, since I will give it to you as an inheritance—a land flowing with milk and honey. I am the LORD your God, who has set you apart from the peoples.
ult_verse_text: And I said to you, ‘You yourselves will inherit their land, and I will give it to you to inherit it: a land flowing {with} milk and honey. I am Yahweh your God, who separates you from the peoples.

notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. It may be helpful to begin a new sentence here. Alternate translation (with a period before): [And I told you that you yourselves will inherit their land]

This expression uses the words **yourselves** to emphasize how significant it was that Israel would inherit the promised land. Use a way that is natural in your language to indicate this significance. Alternate translation: [Even you will inherit their land] or [It is you who will inherit their land]

The phrase **a land flowing with milk and honey** is a common expression in that culture that means “a land with productive, fertile soil that produces good and abundant food.” If this expression does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [a very productive land] or [a land that produces abundant food]

bsb_verse_text: You are therefore to distinguish between clean and unclean animals and birds. Do not become contaminated by any animal or bird, or by anything that crawls on the ground; I have set these apart as unclean for you.
ult_verse_text: And you shall separate between the clean animal and the unclean, and between the unclean bird and the clean. And you shall not make your lives detestable with an animal or with a bird or with anything that crawls on the ground, which I separated from you to {be} unclean.

notes.note: See the chapter introduction for guidance on how to translate the word **clean** in this context.
See the chapter introduction for guidance on how to translate the expressions **the unclean** and **the unclean bird** in this context.
See how you translated the similar expression in [11:43](../11/43.md).
See how you translated the similar expression in [11:44](../11/44.md). Alternate translation: [or with any animals that crawl on the ground]

bsb_verse_text: You are to be holy to Me because I, the LORD, am holy, and I have set you apart from the nations to be My own.
ult_verse_text: And you shall be holy {people} for me, because I Yahweh am holy, and I separate you from the peoples to be for me.

notes.note: The word translated as **because** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation: [for I Yahweh am holy]

bsb_verse_text: A man or a woman who is a medium or spiritist must surely be put to death. They shall be stoned; their blood is upon them.’”
ult_verse_text: And a man or woman, when there is among them a medium or spiritist—dying, they shall be executed. They must stone them with stones. Their blood {is} on them.’”

notes.note: See how you translated the words **medium** and **spiritist** in [19:31](../19/31.md).
See how you handled the similar expression in [20:2](../20/02.md).

Here, the word **They** refers to the people of Israel, while the word **them** refers to the people who consult a **medium** or **spiritist**. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [The people of Israel shall stone the people who consult mediums or spiritists with stones]
See how you handled the similar expression in [20:9](../20/09.md).

bsb_verse_text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Speak to Aaron’s sons, the priests, and tell them that a priest is not to defile himself for a dead person among his people,
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh said to Moses, “Say to the priests, the sons of Aaron, and you shall say to them, ‘For a {dead} person, he shall not make himself unclean among his people,

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠יֹּ֤אמֶר יְהוָה֙ אֶל־מֹשֶׁ֔ה אֱמֹ֥ר אֶל־הַ⁠כֹּהֲנִ֖ים בְּנֵ֣י אַהֲרֹ֑ן וְ⁠אָמַרְתָּ֣ אֲלֵ⁠הֶ֔ם
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. It may be helpful to begin a new sentence here. Alternate translation: [Yahweh told Moses to speak to the priests, the sons of Aaron, and to say to them that]

notes.orig_language_quote: אֱמֹ֥ר אֶל־הַ⁠כֹּהֲנִ֖ים בְּנֵ֣י אַהֲרֹ֑ן וְ⁠אָמַרְתָּ֣ אֲלֵ⁠הֶ֔ם
notes.note: The expressions **Say to the priests** and **you shall say to them** mean similar things. These two phrases are used together for emphasis. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [Tell the priests, the sons of Aaron]

Here the words **he** and **himself** and **his** refer to any priest. If it would be helpful in your language, you may clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [No priest should make himself unclean among his people]

bsb_verse_text: except for his immediate family—his mother, father, son, daughter, or brother,
ult_verse_text: except for his flesh, the one close to him, for his mother or for his father or for his son or for his daughter or for his brother

notes.note: Here, the word **his flesh** is being used to refer to someone who shares the same bloodline as someone else. In other words, **his flesh** refers to a close family member. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [for his close family member]

bsb_verse_text: or his unmarried sister who is near to him, since she has no husband.
ult_verse_text: or for his virgin sister, the one close to him, who does not have a husband, for her, he shall make himself unclean.

notes.note: The word translated as **virgin** refers to a young woman of marriageable age who has not yet had sexual relations. If your language has a specific word for a woman of this social group, consider using it here. If not, consider using a generic expression. Alternate translation: [or for his unmarried sister]

bsb_verse_text: He is not to defile himself for those related to him by marriage, and so profane himself.
ult_verse_text: He shall not make himself unclean {as} a husband among his people, to profane himself.

notes.note: The words translated as **to** indicate that what follows is a result of what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a result of what came before. Alternate translation: [with the result that he profanes himself]

bsb_verse_text: Priests must not make bald spots on their heads, shave off the edges of their beards, or make cuts in their bodies.
ult_verse_text: They shall not bald a bald patch on their heads, and the edges of their beard they shall not shave, and they shall not cut a cut in their flesh.

notes.orig_language_quote: לֹֽא־יִקְרְח֤וּ קָרְחָה֙ בְּ⁠רֹאשָׁ֔⁠ם וּ⁠פְאַ֥ת זְקָנָ֖⁠ם לֹ֣א יְגַלֵּ֑חוּ וּ⁠בִ֨⁠בְשָׂרָ֔⁠ם לֹ֥א יִשְׂרְט֖וּ שָׂרָֽטֶת
notes.note: Here and in the next verse, the words **they** and **their** refer to all the priests of Israel. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [The priests of Israel shall not bald a bald patch on their heads, and the edges of their beard they shall not shave, and they shall not cut a cut in their flesh]

notes.orig_language_quote: לֹֽא־יִקְרְח֤וּ קָרְחָה֙ בְּ⁠רֹאשָׁ֔⁠ם וּ⁠פְאַ֥ת זְקָנָ֖⁠ם לֹ֣א יְגַלֵּ֑חוּ
notes.note: These expressions describe the mourning rituals practiced by the people of the nations who surrounded Israel. Because of their role as priests to Yahweh, the priests of Israel were not to mourn like the priests of other nations. Doing so would associate Yahweh’s holy space with the idolatry of the other nations and profane it (as the next verse indicates). If it would be helpful in your language, consider supplying this information in a footnote or in the text of your translation, as the UST models.

Words are being repeated for emphasis. Specifically, the noun **bald patch** comes from the same root as the verb **bald**. If your language can repeat words in a similar way, consider doing so here. If not, consider using a generic expression. Alternate translation: [They shall not shave the crown of their heads]

Words are being repeated for emphasis. Specifically, the noun **cut** comes from the same root as the verb **cut**. If your language can repeat words in a similar way, consider doing so here. If not, consider using a generic expression. Alternate translation: [They shall not cut themselves]

bsb_verse_text: They must be holy to their God and not profane the name of their God. Because they present to the LORD the food offerings, the food of their God, they must be holy.
ult_verse_text: They shall be holy {people} to their God, and they shall not profane the name of their God, for they are presenting gifts of Yahweh, the bread of their God, and they shall be holy.

notes.note: This word **name** is used to represent Yahweh’s character. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [and they must not disgrace God’s reputation] or [and they must not disgrace their God]

The word translated as **for** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation (with a period before): [This is because]

notes.orig_language_quote: אֶת־אִשֵּׁ֨י יְהוָ֜ה לֶ֧חֶם אֱלֹהֵי⁠הֶ֛ם הֵ֥ם מַקְרִיבִ֖ם
notes.note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The phrase **the bread of their God** clarifies the meaning of the phrase **gifts of Yahweh**. You can translate this parallelism into one statement that conveys this relationship. Alternate translation: [they are presenting the gifts of Yahweh, that is, the bread of their God] or [they are presenting the food gifts offered to Yahweh, their God]

This expression uses one kind of food, **bread**, to represent food in general. Furthermore, this expression uses the possessive form to describe bread (that is, food) that is characterized by the fact that it is offered to God. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your culture or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the gifts of food that people offer to their God]
Alternate translation: [and so they must be holy]

bsb_verse_text: A priest must not marry a woman defiled by prostitution or divorced by her husband, for the priest is holy to his God.
ult_verse_text: He shall not take a prostituting or profaned woman, and he shall not take a woman divorced from her husband, for he {is} holy to his God.

notes.orig_language_quote: לֹ֣א יִקָּ֔חוּ & לֹ֣א יִקָּ֑חוּ כִּֽי־קָדֹ֥שׁ ה֖וּא לֵ⁠אלֹהָֽי⁠ו
notes.note: Here and throughout the next few verses, the words **he** and **his** refer to any priest in Israel. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [No priest shall take … nor shall he take … for that priest is holy to his God]

The phrase **He shall not take** is a polite way of referring to sexual relations with a woman, but it is also a common expression that means “to marry.” If this phrase does not have this meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [He shall not marry … nor shall he marry] or [He shall not have sexual relations with … nor shall he have sexual relations with]

The word translated as **for** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation (with a period before): [This is because]

bsb_verse_text: You are to regard him as holy, since he presents the food of your God. He shall be holy to you, because I the LORD am holy—I who set you apart.
ult_verse_text: And you shall make him holy, for he is the one presenting the bread of your God. He shall be holy for you, because holy {am} I, Yahweh, the one making you holy.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠קִדַּשְׁתּ֔⁠וֹ כִּֽי־אֶת־לֶ֥חֶם אֱלֹהֶ֖י⁠ךָ ה֣וּא מַקְרִ֑יב קָדֹשׁ֙ יִֽהְיֶה־לָּ֔⁠ךְ
notes.note: Here, **you** is singular and refers to Moses, the one to whom Yahweh is speaking. The words **he** and **him** refer to a priest. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And you, Moses, shall make the priest holy, for he is the one presenting the bread of your God. That priest shall be holy for you, Moses]
See how you translated this expression in [21:6](../21/06.md).

The word **you** here is plural and refers either to the priests or to the people of Israel. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [because holy am I, Yahweh, the one making the priests holy] or [because holy am I, Yahweh, the one making the people of Israel holy]

The word translated as **because** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation (with a period before): [This is because]

bsb_verse_text: If a priest’s daughter defiles herself by prostituting herself, she profanes her father; she must be burned in the fire.
ult_verse_text: And a daughter of a man, a priest, when she is profaned by prostituting—she is profaning her father. She must be burned with fire.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [And a priests’s daughter]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [when she profanes herself by prostituting herself]

This expression indicates a form of capital punishment whereby an individual is executed by being publicly burned alive. Additionally, it may be helpful to see how you handled the extra information in this expression in [6:30](../06/30.md). Furthermore, if your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [The people of Israel shall publicly burn her to death]

bsb_verse_text: The priest who is highest among his brothers, who has had the anointing oil poured on his head and has been ordained to wear the priestly garments, must not let his hair hang loose or tear his garments.
ult_verse_text: And the great priest from his brothers, on whose head the oil of anointing was poured and whose hand is filled to wear the clothing, his head he shall not let be unbound, and his clothes he shall not tear.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [on whose head the priests poured anointing oil]
See how you translated this expression in [8:2](../08/02.md).

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [whose hand God filled to wear the clothes]

The phrase **whose hand is filled** is a common expression that means to induct someone into the ministry and responsibilities of the priesthood. According to this verse, God has given the high priest the responsibilities of serving and worshiping him. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and to whom I, Yahweh, have given the responsibilities of the priesthood]

notes.orig_language_quote: אֶת־רֹאשׁ⁠וֹ֙ לֹ֣א יִפְרָ֔ע וּ⁠בְגָדָ֖י⁠ו לֹ֥א יִפְרֹֽם
notes.note: Loose hair and torn **clothes** were signs of mourning. The high priests of Yahweh were not to mourn for their dead relatives in any way that would disrupt their duties of offering Israel’s sacrifices. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could state this explicitly in a footnote or in the text of your translation. Alternate translation: [he must not allow himself to be distracted from his priestly duties by mourning for his dead relatives]

Here, **head** represents the hair on the head. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [his hair he shall not let be unbound] or [he shall not let his hair be disheveled]

bsb_verse_text: He must not go near any dead body; he must not defile himself, even for his father or mother.
ult_verse_text: And near any dead person, he shall not go, for his father or for his mother. He shall not make himself unclean.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠עַ֛ל כָּל־נַפְשֹׁ֥ת מֵ֖ת לֹ֣א יָבֹ֑א לְ⁠אָבִ֥י⁠ו וּ⁠לְ⁠אִמּ֖⁠וֹ לֹ֥א יִטַּמָּֽא
notes.note: Here and throughout the next verses, the words **he** and **his** refer to the high priest. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And near any dead person, the high priest shall not go—for his father or for his mother. The high priest shall not make himself unclean]

bsb_verse_text: He must not leave or desecrate the sanctuary of his God, for the consecration of the anointing oil of his God is on him. I am the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And he shall not go out from the Holy Place, and he shall not profane the Holy Place of his God, for the crown of the oil of the anointing of his God {is} on him. I {am} Yahweh.

notes.note: The word translated as **for** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation (with a period before): [This is because]

This expression uses the image of a **crown** to describe the **oil of the anointing of his God** that was poured on the high priest’s head to appoint him as the high priest. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [on his head is the oil of anointing that God used to appoint him, which he should consider to be like a crown]
See how you translated this expression in [8:2](../08/02.md).

bsb_verse_text: The woman he marries must be a virgin.
ult_verse_text: And he himself shall take a wife in her virginity.

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **virginity**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [while she is still a virgin] or [when she has not yet had sexual relations]

bsb_verse_text: so that he does not defile his offspring among his people, for I am the LORD who sanctifies him.”
ult_verse_text: And he shall not profane his seed among his people. For I {am} Yahweh, the one making him holy.’”

notes.note: Here the word **seed** is a reference to one’s children. Whether semen was thought of to resemble plant seed is unclear, although the same word is used to refer to both (see [11:37](../11/37.md) and [15:16](../15/16.md) for reference). This expression implies that by marrying an unholy or ungodly woman, the priest would have children unworthy to be a priest. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And he shall not profane his children among his people]

The word translated as **For** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation: [This is because]

bsb_verse_text: Then the LORD said to Moses,
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh spoke to Moses, saying,

notes.note: The word translated as **saying** introduces a direct quotation. In your translation, consider ways in which you might introduce this quotation naturally in your language.

If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. It may be helpful to begin a new sentence here. Alternate translation (with a period before): [He told Moses to tell Aaron that]

bsb_verse_text: “Say to Aaron, ‘For the generations to come, none of your descendants who has a physical defect may approach to offer the food of his God.
ult_verse_text: “Speak to Aaron, saying, ‘A man from your seed to their generations on whom is a blemish shall not draw near to present the bread of his God.

notes.note: Here the word **seed** is a reference to one’s children. Whether semen was thought of to resemble plant seed is unclear, although the same word is used to refer to both. (See [11:37](../11/37.md) and [15:16](../15/16.md) for reference.) If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [A man from your children] or [One of your male children]

The phrase **to their generations** refers to the descendants of Aaron who will be priests. Use an expression for this that would be natural in your language. Alternate translation: [throughout the generations of the descendants of Aaron who will be priests]

Here the verb **present** comes from the same root as the verb **draw near**. This construction is used for emphasis. You may be able to use the same construction in your language to express the meaning. Alternatively, your language may have another way of showing emphasis. Alternate translation: [shall not ever draw near to present] or [should never approach the altar in order to present]
See how you translated the similar expression in [21:6](../21/06.md).

bsb_verse_text: No man who has any defect may approach—no man who is blind, lame, disfigured, or deformed;
ult_verse_text: For any man on whom {is} a blemish shall not draw near: a man blind or lame or mutilated or extended

notes.note: The word translated as **For** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation: [This is because]

This expression leaves out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You could supply these words from earlier in the sentence if it would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [shall not draw near to the altar to offer a sacrifice]

This expression likely refers to a person who is born with a defect in which one leg is longer than another. If it would be helpful for your readers, you could include this information. Alternate translation: [with an extended leg] or [who has one leg that is longer than the other]

bsb_verse_text: or who is a hunchback or dwarf, or who has an eye defect, a festering rash, scabs, or a crushed testicle.
ult_verse_text: or a hunchback or a dwarf or one with a defect in his eye or a scab or a rash or a crushed testicle.

notes.note: The word **hunchback** refers to a person whose spine is misshapen and so possesses a hunched or bent back. If your language has a specific term for this form of disability, consider using it here. If not, consider using a generic expression. Alternate translation: [a person whose spine is misshapen] or [a person born with a bent back]

The word **dwarf** here refers to a person who is born with a genetic defect that causes them to be considerably shorter than what is considered normal height. This disability can also sometimes cause other health issues. If your language has a specific word for this form of disability, consider using it here. If not, consider using a generic expression. Alternate translation: [a person who is considerably shorter than normal] or [an unusually short person]

bsb_verse_text: No descendant of Aaron the priest who has a defect shall approach to present the food offerings to the LORD. Since he has a defect, he is not to come near to offer the food of his God.
ult_verse_text: Any man on whom {is} a blemish from the seed of Aaron the priest shall not approach to present the gift of Yahweh. A blemish {is} on him. He shall not approach to present the bread of his God.

notes.note: See how you translated the word **seed** in [21:15](../21/15.md). Alternate translation: [from the children of Aaron] or [from the descendants of Aaron]
See how you translated the similar expression in [2:2](../02/02.md).
See how you translated the similar expression in [21:6](../21/06.md).

bsb_verse_text: He may eat the most holy food of his God as well as the holy food,
ult_verse_text: The bread of his God, from the holy things of the holy things and from the holy things, he may eat.

notes.note: See how you translated the similar expression in [21:6](../21/06.md).

Different offering and sacrifices were designated as food for the priests. These portions of food were called **the holy things of the holy things** and **the holy things**. It may be helpful to see how you translated the similar expression in [6:17](../06/17.md). Alternate translation: [from the most holy portions of food or from the holy portions of food]
Here the word **he** refers to the priest with the bodily blemish. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [the priest with a blemish may eat]

bsb_verse_text: but because he has a defect, he must not go near the veil or approach the altar, so as not to desecrate My sanctuaries. For I am the LORD who sanctifies them.’”
ult_verse_text: However, he shall not enter into the curtain, and he shall not draw near to the altar, for a blemish {is} on him. And he shall not profane my Holy Place, for I {am} Yahweh, the one making them holy.’”

notes.note: To **enter into the curtain** means to pass through the curtain dividing the holy place from the most holy place in the sanctuary. No priest with a blemish was permitted to approach God in the most holy place. You could include this information if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [he shall not pass through the curtain into the holy of holies]

The word translated as **for** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation (with a period before): [This is because … This is because]

Here the word **them** refers to the priests who have blemishes and so cannot approach Yahweh’s altar to offer sacrifices. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [the one making holy even the priests who have blemishes]

bsb_verse_text: Moses told this to Aaron and his sons and to all the Israelites.
ult_verse_text: And Moses spoke to Aaron and to his sons and to all the sons of Israel.

notes.note: The word **his** refers to Aaron and not to Moses. If it would be helpful for your readers, consider using Aaron’s name here. Alternate translation: [and to Aaron’s sons]
See how you translated this expression in [4:2](../04/02.md).

bsb_verse_text: Then the LORD said to Moses,
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh spoke to Moses, saying,

notes.note: The word translated as **saying** introduces a direct quotation. Consider natural ways of introducing direct quotations in your language.

bsb_verse_text: “Tell Aaron and his sons to treat with respect the sacred offerings that the Israelites have consecrated to Me, so that they do not profane My holy name. I am the LORD.
ult_verse_text: “Speak to Aaron and to his sons, and they shall be separated from the holy things of the sons of Israel, which they {are} making holy to me, and they shall not profane the name of my holiness. I {am} Yahweh.

notes.note: This expression uses the possessive form to describe **holy things** (sacrificial food offerings) that the **sons of Israel** offer to Yahweh as sacrifices. If your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could use a generic expression. Alternate translation: [the holy things that the sons of Israel offer to Yahweh]
See how you handled this metaphor for the people of Israel in [1:2](../01/02.md).

Here, the word **name** represents Yahweh’s reputation and, by extension, Yahweh himself. So to **profane** this **name** is to associate Yahweh who is holy with that which is not only not holy, but abominable and detestable, like child sacrifice. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. See how you translated this expression in [20:3](../20/03.md). Alternate translation: [and they shall not publicly defame me] or [and they shall not openly denigrate my reputation]

This expression uses the possessive form to describe Yahweh’s **name** (his reputation as God) that is characterized by **holiness**. If your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could use a generic expression. Alternate translation: [my holy name] or [my sacred reputation]

bsb_verse_text: Tell them that for the generations to come, if any of their descendants in a state of uncleanness approaches the sacred offerings that the Israelites consecrate to the LORD, that person must be cut off from My presence. I am the LORD.
ult_verse_text: Say to them, ‘To your generations, any man who draws near from all your seed to the holy things that the sons of Israel have made holy to Yahweh and his uncleanness {is} on him, that person shall be cut off from before my face. I {am} Yahweh.

notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [Tell them that to their generations]

Here, the word **your** is plural and refers to the Israelite priests, the male descendants of Aaron. If you chose to make this verse indirect speech (as the previous note suggested), it may be helpful to change the second-person pronouns to the third person. Alternate translation: [to their generations … from all their seed]
Here the word **man** refers to any male descendant of Aaron who serves as a priest. If it would be helpful in your language, consider making this explicit. Alternate translation: [any priest]

This expression uses the word **seed** to refer to one’s children. Whether semen was thought of to resemble plant seed is unclear, although the same word is used to refer to both (see [11:37](../11/37.md) and [15:16](../15/16.md) for reference). If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. See how you translated this metaphor in [20:2](../20/02.md). Alternate translation: [from all your children] or [from all your descendants]

Here a verb and its object come from the same root. The phrase **have made holy** translates a verb that is related to the noun translated as **holy things**. The repetition of related words adds emphasis to the statement. You may be able to use the same construction in your language to express the meaning here. Alternatively, your language may have another way of showing emphasis. Alternate translation: [to the holy things that the sons of Israel are presenting to Yahweh as holy offerings]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **uncleanness**, you could express the same idea in another way. It may be helpful to see how you translated this abstract noun in [5:3](../05/03.md). Alternate translation: [while he is unclean] or [and he is unclean]
See how you translated the similar expression in [7:20](../07/20.md).

Here, **face** represents the presence of a person. In this expression, the priest who offers sacrifices while he is unclean must be removed from Yahweh’s presence—that is, he must be exiled. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from my presence] or [from the place where I live among the Israelites]

bsb_verse_text: If a descendant of Aaron has a skin disease or a discharge, he may not eat the sacred offerings until he is clean. Whoever touches anything defiled by a corpse or by a man who has an emission of semen,
ult_verse_text: A man, a man from the seed of Aaron, and he {is} skin diseased or flowing, he shall not eat of the holy things until he is clean. And the one touching anything unclean of a person or a man who has go out from him a lying of seed

notes.note: Here the word **man** refers to any priest. See how you handled the repetition of the word **man** in [15:2](../15/02.md). Alternate translation: [Any priest]
See how you handled this metaphor for descendants in [20:2](../20/02.md). Alternate translation: [from the children of Aaron] or [from Aaron’s descendants]

The terms **skin diseased** and **flowing** refer to various kinds of visible, infectious skin diseases. See how you translated the expression **skin diseased** in [13:44](../13/44.md). Similarly, see how you translated the word **flowing** in [15:2](../15/02.md).

This expression refers generally to any priest who touches something **unclean**, not to a specific priest. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a more natural expression. Alternate translation: [And any priest who touches anything unclean]

This expression uses the possessive form to describe **anything unclean** that has a human source, whether an unclean person or a discharge or blood that has come from a person. If your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could use a generic expression. Alternate translation: [anything unclean that has come from a person] or [any unclean person]
See how you translated the similar expression in [15:16](../15/16.md).

bsb_verse_text: or whoever touches a crawling creature or a person that makes him unclean, whatever the uncleanness may be—
ult_verse_text: or a man who touches any swarming {thing} that makes him unclean or a person who makes him unclean, whatever his uncleanness,

notes.note: The expression **or a person who makes him unclean** leaves out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You could supply these words from earlier in the sentence if it would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [or a man who touches a person who makes him unclean] or [or a priest who touches a person who makes him unclean]

Here the word **his** refers to the unclean person whom the priest touches. If it would be helpful in your language, consider making this explicit. Alternate translation: [whatever that person’s uncleanness]
See how you handled the abstract noun **uncleanness** in [5:3](../05/03.md).

bsb_verse_text: the man who touches any of these will remain unclean until evening. He must not eat from the sacred offerings unless he has bathed himself with water.
ult_verse_text: the person who touches it will be unclean until the evening. And he shall not eat from the holy things unless he washes his body with the water.

notes.note: Here the word **it** refers to any of the previously listed unclean things that a priest might touch and become unclean. If it would be helpful in your language, consider making this explicit. Alternate translation: [any of these unclean things]
Here the word **flesh** refers to a person’s body. Additionally, see how you handled the extra information in the similar expression in [1:9](../01/09.md). Alternate translation: [he washes himself]

bsb_verse_text: When the sun has set, he will become clean, and then he may eat from the sacred offerings, for they are his food.
ult_verse_text: And the sun will go, and he will be clean. And afterward, he may eat from the holy things, because it {is} his bread.

notes.note: This is a common expression that refers to the **sun** setting at the end of the day. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And when the sun sets]

The word translated as **because** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation (with a period before): [This is because]

bsb_verse_text: The priests must keep My charge, lest they bear the guilt and die because they profane it. I am the LORD who sanctifies them.
ult_verse_text: And they shall keep my watch, and they shall not bear sin with regard to it and die by it, because they profaned it. I {am} Yahweh, the one making them holy.

notes.note: Here the book of Leviticus switches from describing one hypothetical priest to describing the priesthood as a whole. As such, the words **they** and **them** refer to the Israelite priests. If it would be helpful in your language, consider making this explicit. Alternate translation: [And the priests shall keep … and the priests shall not carry … they profaned it … the one making the priests holy]
See how you translated this expression in [8:35](../08/35.md) and [18:30](../18/30.md).

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠לֹֽא־יִשְׂא֤וּ עָלָי⁠ו֙ חֵ֔טְא וּ⁠מֵ֥תוּ ב֖⁠וֹ כִּ֣י יְחַלְּלֻ֑⁠הוּ
notes.note: Here the word **it** refers to the **watch** of Yahweh, that is, Yahweh’s commands to avoid contact with unclean things while performing sacrificial duties. If it would be helpful to your readers, consider stating this plainly. Alternate translation: [and the priests shall not carry sin with regard to what I have told them to avoid and therefore die because they did what I told them to avoid, thus profaning my commands to them]

Here, **they shall not bear sin** is a common expression that refers to a priest being held responsible for their sin or wrongdoing. If that phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and they shall not sin with regard to it]

The word translated as **because** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation (with a period before): [They would die because]

bsb_verse_text: No one outside a priest’s family may eat the sacred offering, nor may the guest of a priest or his hired hand eat it.
ult_verse_text: But any stranger may not eat the holy thing. A dweller of the priest or a hired {person} may not eat the holy thing.

notes.note: Here, the expression **the holy thing** refers to any gift of food that the Israelites have sacrificed and offered to Yahweh, not to a specific food gift. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a more natural expression. Alternate translation: [any holy thing … any holy thing]

This expression uses the possessive form to describe a **dweller** (that is, a traveling guest) that is characterized by their receiving the hospitality of **the priest**. If your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could use a generic expression. Alternate translation: [A traveling guest of the priest] or [A traveler who is staying at the priest’s home]

bsb_verse_text: But if a priest buys a slave with his own money, or if a slave is born in his household, that slave may eat his food.
ult_verse_text: But a priest, when he buys a person, the property of his silver, he himself may eat it. And one born of his house, they themselves may eat his bread.

notes.note: This expression uses the possessive form to describe a slave who is **property** characterized by their having been bought by the priest’s **silver**, that is, his money. If your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could use a generic expression. Additionally, here, **silver** represents any money or currency by which a priest would purchase a slave. If it would be helpful in your language, consider stating the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [when he buys a person and they become his property that he purchased with his money] or [when he buys a person with his own money and they become his property]

These expressions use the words **himself** and **themselves** to emphasize how significant it was that these slaves are permitted to eat the priest’s holy food. Use a way that is natural in your language to indicate this significance. Alternate translation: [even he may eat … they also may eat]

Here, the word **he** refers to the slave that the priest purchased, not to the priest. If it would be helpful for your readers, consider making this explicit. Alternate translation: [that slave may eat]

Here, the word **his** refers to a priest, while the phrase **the one born of his house** refers to a child who is born from a slave residing in the priest’s household. This expression uses the plural **they** to refer to this slave, perhaps including the mother who gave birth to him or her. If it would be helpful in your language, consider making these explicit. Alternate translation: [And a slave who is born into a priest’s household—he and his parents may eat the priest’s bread]

Here, **bread** represents the sacred portions of food that the priests received from the food gifts that the people of Israel offered to Yahweh. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [his food]

bsb_verse_text: If the priest’s daughter is married to a man other than a priest, she is not to eat of the sacred contributions.
ult_verse_text: And a daughter of a priest, when she becomes the wife of a stranger, she herself may not eat the contribution of the holy things.

notes.note: This expression uses the word **herself** to emphasize how significant it was that the daughter of a priest is not permitted to eat her father’s holy food after her marriage. Use a way that is natural in your language to indicate this significance. Alternate translation: [not even she may eat the contribution of the holy things]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea behind the word **contribution**, you can express the same idea another way. Alternate translation: [the holy things that the people of Israel have contributed]

bsb_verse_text: But if a priest’s daughter with no children becomes widowed or divorced and returns to her father’s house, she may share her father’s food as in her youth. But no outsider may share it.
ult_verse_text: But the daughter of a priest, when she becomes a widow or a divorced {woman}, and there is no seed for her, and she returns to the house of her father as her youth—she may eat from the bread of her father. And any stranger may not eat it.

notes.note: See how you handled this metaphor for descendants in [20:2](../20/02.md). Alternate translation: [and she has no children]

Here, **bread** represents the sacred portions of food that the priests received from the food gifts that the people of Israel offered to Yahweh. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from her father’s food]
Alternate translation: [And no stranger may eat it]

bsb_verse_text: If anyone eats a sacred offering in error, he must add a fifth to its value and give the sacred offering to the priest.
ult_verse_text: And a man, when he eats a holy thing by mistake, then he shall add its fifth on it, and he shall give the holy thing to the priest.

notes.note: Although the term **man** is masculine, here it is used in a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a phrase that makes this clear. Alternate translation: [And a person]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠יָסַ֤ף חֲמִֽשִׁית⁠וֹ֙ עָלָ֔י⁠ו וְ⁠נָתַ֥ן לַ⁠כֹּהֵ֖ן אֶת־הַ⁠קֹּֽדֶשׁ
notes.note: This could mean: 1) that the person had to replace the food that he had eaten with the same kind of food or 2) that the person had to pay money to the priest for the food that he had eaten.

Here, **shall add its fifth on it** is a common expression that refers to adding one–fifth of the monetary value of a sacred food item to its total value. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [then he shall take the total monetary value of the food item plus one–fifth]
The term **its fifth** refers to one part out of five equal parts.

bsb_verse_text: The priests must not profane the sacred offerings that the Israelites present to the LORD
ult_verse_text: And they shall not profane the holy things of the sons of Israel, that which they raise to Yahweh,

notes.note: Here, the pronoun **they** refers to the people of Israel. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And the people of Israel shall not profane … that which the people of Israel raise]
See how you translated this expression in [22:2](../22/02.md).
See how you handled this metaphor for the people of Israel in [1:2](../01/02.md).

Here, the word **raise** refers to the ritual gesture of lifting up an offering to Yahweh. If your language has a word for this kind of ritual gesture, consider using it here. You could also explain the significance of this action in the text or a footnote. Alternate translation: [that which they present] or [that which they offer]
Yahweh is speaking about himself in the third person. If this would not be natural in your language, you could use the first-person form. Alternate translation: [to me, Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: by allowing the people to eat the sacred offerings and thus to bear the punishment for guilt. For I am the LORD who sanctifies them.”
ult_verse_text: or they shall cause themselves to bear the iniquity of guilt by their eating their holy things. For I {am} Yahweh, the one making them holy.’”

notes.note: Here, **to bear the iniquity of guilt** is a common expression that refers to guilt as a physical object that needs to be carried. Because **guilt** in Leviticus can refer to both the legal status of needing to provide restitution for wrongdoing or the punishment by which restitution is provided, this expression could mean: 1) the people of Israel would become guilty and so responsible for their sin. Alternate translation: [or they shall be guilty of the sin that they committed] or 2) the word **guilt** is a metonym for punishment for the sin that they committed. Alternate translation: [or they shall receive the punishment that they deserve when they committed wrongdoing]
Alternate translation: [when they ate their holy things]

The word translated as **For** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation: [This is because]

bsb_verse_text: Then the LORD said to Moses,
ult_verse_text: And Yahweh spoke to Moses, saying,

notes.orig_language_quote: לֵּ⁠אמֹֽר׃ דַּבֵּ֨ר אֶֽל־אַהֲרֹ֜ן וְ⁠אֶל־בָּנָ֗י⁠ו וְ⁠אֶל֙ כָּל־בְּנֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל וְ⁠אָמַרְתָּ֖ אֲלֵ⁠הֶ֑ם
notes.note: If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. It may be helpful to begin a new sentence here. Alternate translation: [Speak to Aaron and to his sons and to all the sons of Israel, and tell them that]

bsb_verse_text: “Speak to Aaron and his sons and all the Israelites and tell them, ‘Any man of the house of Israel or any foreign resident who presents a gift for a burnt offering to the LORD, whether to fulfill a vow or as a freewill offering,
ult_verse_text: “Speak to Aaron and to his sons and to all the sons of Israel, and you shall say to them, ‘A man, a man from the house of Israel or from the sojourner in Israel, who presents his offering, for any of their vows or for any of their freewill offerings, which they present to Yahweh as a burnt offering,

notes.orig_language_quote: דַּבֵּ֨ר אֶֽל־אַהֲרֹ֜ן וְ⁠אֶל־בָּנָ֗י⁠ו וְ⁠אֶל֙ כָּל־בְּנֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֔ל וְ⁠אָמַרְתָּ֖ אֲלֵ⁠הֶ֑ם
notes.note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing but serve different functions. While the first phrase is a command, the second phrase introduces what Moses is to say to Aaron, the priests, and the people of Israel. You can translate this parallelism into one statement that conveys this relationship. Alternate translation: [Tell Aaron and his sons and all the sons of Israel] or [Speak to Aaron and to his sons and to all the sons of Israel, telling them]
See how you handled this metaphor for the people of Israel in [1:2](../01/02.md).

This expression uses **house** to represent the people of Israel. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from the people of Israel]

Here, the word **man** refers generally to any Israelite in general and not to men specifically. See how you handled the repetition of the word **man** in [15:2](../15/02.md). Alternate translation: [Any person]
See how you handled these repeated words in [1:2](../01/02.md).
Yahweh is speaking about himself in the third person. If this would not be natural in your language, you could use the first-person form. Alternate translation: [to me, Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: must offer an unblemished male from the cattle, sheep, or goats in order for it to be accepted on your behalf.
ult_verse_text: for your acceptance, a perfect male among the cattle, among the sheep, or among the goats.

notes.orig_language_quote: לִֽ⁠רְצֹנְ⁠כֶ֑ם תָּמִ֣ים זָכָ֔ר בַּ⁠בָּקָ֕ר בַּ⁠כְּשָׂבִ֖ים וּ⁠בָֽ⁠עִזִּֽים
notes.note: This expression leaves out some of the words that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You could supply these words in the sentence if it would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [for your acceptance, you shall present a perfect male among the cattle, among the sheep, or among the goats]

Here and throughout the rest of this chapter, the word “you” is plural and refers to the people of Israel as a whole and to the priests specifically. If the switch from third-person forms to second-person plural forms would not be natural in your language, consider continuing to use third-person forms. Alternate translation: [for their acceptance]

The expressions **the cattle**, **the sheep**, and **the goats** do not refer to specific groups of animals. They describe any groups of animals that an Israelite might own. Express this in the way that would be most natural in your language. Alternate translation: [among your cattle, your sheep, or your goats that you own or purchase] or, in the third person, [among any of the cattle, sheep, or goats that he owns or purchases]

bsb_verse_text: You must not present anything with a defect, because it will not be accepted on your behalf.
ult_verse_text: Anything on which {is} a blemish you shall not present, because it will not be acceptable for you.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [Any animal on which is a blemish]

The word translated as **because** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation (with a period before): [This is because]

bsb_verse_text: When a man presents a peace offering to the LORD from the herd or flock to fulfill a vow or as a freewill offering, it must be without blemish or defect to be acceptable.
ult_verse_text: And a man, when he presents a sacrifice of peace offerings to Yahweh to fulfill a vow or as a freewill offering among the cattle or among the flock, it shall be perfect for acceptance. Any blemish shall not be on it:

notes.note: Although the term **man** is masculine, here it is used in a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a phrase that makes this clear. Alternate translation: [And a person]
Yahweh is speaking about himself in the third person. If this would not be natural in your language, you could use the first-person form. Alternate translation: [to me, Yahweh]

The expressions **the cattle** and **the flock** do not refer to specific groups of animals. They describe any groups of animals that an Israelite might own. Express this in the way that would be most natural in your language. Alternate translation: [among your cattle or your flock animals that you own or purchase] or, in the third person, [among his cattle or flock animals that he owns or purchases]
Alternate translation: [No blemish shall be on it]

bsb_verse_text: You are not to present to the LORD any animal that is blind, injured, or maimed, or anything with a running sore, a festering rash, or a scab; you must not put any of these on the altar as a food offering to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: blindness or being broken or being maimed or {having} a running {sore} or a scab or a sore—these you shall not present to Yahweh. And a gift you shall not give from them on the altar to Yahweh.

notes.note: Yahweh is speaking about himself in the third person. If this would not be natural in your language, you could use the first-person form. Alternate translation: [to me, Yahweh … to me]
See how you handled the similar idiom in [4:7](../04/07.md).

bsb_verse_text: You may present as a freewill offering an ox or sheep that has a deformed or stunted limb, but it is not acceptable in fulfillment of a vow.
ult_verse_text: But an ox or a lamb, extended or stunted, you may make it {as} a freewill offering, but it will not be accepted for a vow.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [I will not accept it]

bsb_verse_text: You are not to present to the LORD an animal whose testicles are bruised, crushed, torn, or cut; you are not to sacrifice them in your land.
ult_verse_text: But bruised or crushed or torn or cut you shall not present to Yahweh, and in your land, you shall not do.

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠מָע֤וּךְ וְ⁠כָתוּת֙ וְ⁠נָת֣וּק וְ⁠כָר֔וּת לֹ֥א תַקְרִ֖יבוּ לַֽ⁠יהוָ֑ה
notes.note: The words **bruised**, **crushed**, **torn** and **cut** refer to ways in which the owner of a bovine might castrate that animal to remove its testicles. This was a common practice in the ancient world that was believed to increase the quality of the animal’s meat. Such practices are forbidden for animals that will be sacrificed as it introduces a blemish to an animal that Yahweh requires to be whole and perfect. If it would be helpful in your language, consider supplying this information in a footnote or in the text of your translation. Alternate translation: [But you shall not present to Yahweh any animal whose testicles have been bruised or crushed or torn or cut] or [But you shall not present to Yahweh any animal whose owner has bruised or crushed or torn or cut the animal’s testicles]

bsb_verse_text: Neither you nor a foreigner shall present food to your God from any such animal. They will not be accepted on your behalf, because they are deformed and flawed.’”
ult_verse_text: And from the hand of a son of a foreigner, you shall not present the bread of your God from any of these because their being ruined is on them and a blemish is on them. They will not be accepted for you.’”

notes.orig_language_quote: וּ⁠מִ⁠יַּ֣ד בֶּן־נֵכָ֗ר לֹ֥א תַקְרִ֛יבוּ אֶת־לֶ֥חֶם אֱלֹהֵי⁠כֶ֖ם מִ⁠כָּל־אֵ֑לֶּה
notes.note: Here the word **hand** represents the whole person. In context, this expression refers to purchasing an animal from another, specifically a **foreigner**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [And you shall not present the bread of your God that you acquired from the son of a foreigner]

Here, the word **son** refers generically to descendants and not just to male progeny. If your language has a generic word for children, consider using it here. Alternate translation: [a foreigner] or [someone who you consider to be a foreigner]

Here, **bread** represents food in general. Furthermore, this expression uses the possessive form to describe **bread** (that is, food) which is characterized by the fact that it is offered to **God**. If your language would not use the possessive form for this, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you shall not present any food as a gift to your God]

Here, the words **these** and **them** refer to the disabled or deformed animals, not to the **foreigner**. If it would be helpful in your language, consider making this explicit. Alternate translation: [from any of these blemished animals … is on these animals … is on them]

The word translated as **because** indicates that what follows is a reason for what came before. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. Alternate translation (with a period before): [This is because]
Alternate translation: [their ruin is on them] or [their deformity is on them]

If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Yahweh will not accept them from you]

bsb_verse_text: “When an ox, a sheep, or a goat is born, it must remain with its mother for seven days. From the eighth day on, it will be acceptable as a food offering presented to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: “An ox or a lamb or a goat, when it is born, then it shall be seven days under its mother. And from the eighth day and beyond, it may be accepted as an offering, a gift to Yahweh.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [when its mother gives birth to it]

Here, **under its mother** is a common expression that describes a young animal as being with its mother. The use of the word **under** likely describes the mother feeding the young animal. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [with its mother] or [feeding from its mother]
If your language does not use this type of number, you could use a different type of number here or an equivalent expression. Alternate translation: [And after seven days]
If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [I will accept it]
Yahweh is speaking about himself in the third person. If this would not be natural in your language, you could use the first-person form. Alternate translation: [to me, Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: But you must not slaughter an ox or a sheep on the same day as its young.
ult_verse_text: But an ox or a flock {animal}, it and its son you shall not slaughter on one day.

notes.note: Although the term **son** is masculine, here it is used in a generic sense that includes both male and female animals. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a phrase that makes this clear. Alternate translation: [it and its young] or [it and its offspring]

bsb_verse_text: When you sacrifice a thank offering to the LORD, offer it so that it may be acceptable on your behalf.
ult_verse_text: And when you sacrifice a sacrifice of thanks to Yahweh, you shall sacrifice it for your acceptance.

notes.note: Here, **when you sacrifice a sacrifice** is an emphatic construction that uses a verb and its object that come from the same root. You may be able to use the same construction in your language to express the meaning here. Alternatively, your language may have another way of showing the emphasis. Alternate translation: [And whenever you present an animal as a sacrifice of thanks]

bsb_verse_text: It must be eaten that same day. Do not leave any of it until morning. I am the LORD.
ult_verse_text: On that day, it shall be eaten; you must not leave some of it until morning. I {am} Yahweh.

notes.note: If your language does not use the passive form in this way, you can state this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [On that day, you shall eat it] or [On that day, the people of Israel shall eat it]

bsb_verse_text: You are to keep My commandments and practice them. I am the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And you shall keep my commandments, and you shall do them. I {am} Yahweh.

notes.note: Here, the words **keep** and **do** mean similar things. They both emphasize that the people must practice a habitual lifestyle of obeying God’s commands. If it would be clearer for your readers, you could express the emphasis with a single phrase. Alternate translation: [And you shall obey my commandments] or [And you shall keep my commandments so that you do them]

bsb_verse_text: You must not profane My holy name. I must be acknowledged as holy among the Israelites. I am the LORD who sanctifies you,
ult_verse_text: And you shall not profane the name of my holiness, but I will show myself to be holy in the midst of the sons of Israel. I {am} Yahweh, the one making you holy,

Alternate translation: [but I shall be treated as holy]
See how you handled this metaphor for the people of Israel in [1:2](../01/02.md).

bsb_verse_text: “Speak to the Israelites and say to them, ‘These are My appointed feasts, the feasts of the LORD that you are to proclaim as sacred assemblies.
ult_verse_text: “Speak to the sons of Israel, and you shall say to them, ‘The appointed times of Yahweh, which you shall proclaim them {as} assemblies of holiness, these {are} them, my appointed times.

notes.note: See how you handled the beginning of the quote within a quote in [1:2](../01/02.md) and throughout the book.

notes.orig_language_quote: מוֹעֲדֵ֣י יְהוָ֔ה אֲשֶׁר־תִּקְרְא֥וּ אֹתָ֖⁠ם מִקְרָאֵ֣י קֹ֑דֶשׁ אֵ֥לֶּה הֵ֖ם מוֹעֲדָֽ⁠י

Here, **my** refers to Yahweh. Make sure this is clear in your translation. Alternate translation: [these are Yahweh’s appointed times]

bsb_verse_text: For six days work may be done, but the seventh day is a Sabbath of complete rest, a day of sacred assembly. You must not do any work; wherever you live, it is a Sabbath to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: Six days work shall be done, and on the seventh day {is} a sabbath of sabbaths, an assembly of holiness. You shall not do any work. It {is} a sabbath to Yahweh in all your dwellings.

This phrase refers to everywhere people live, including their homes and the surrounding areas. If your language has a way to express this concept of “everywhere,” consider using it here. Alternate translation: [everywhere you live] or [in all your towns and homes]

bsb_verse_text: These are the LORD’s appointed feasts, the sacred assemblies you are to proclaim at their appointed times.

notes.note: This verse repeats the phrase **appointed times** for emphasis. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could combine the phrases and express the emphasis in another way. See how you handled this repetition in [23:2](../23/02.md).

bsb_verse_text: The Passover to the LORD begins at twilight on the fourteenth day of the first month.
ult_verse_text: In the first month, on {day} 14 of the month, between the evenings, {is} the Passover to Yahweh.

notes.note: This refers to the first month of the Hebrew calendar, which occurs in March-April on modern calendars. If it would be helpful in your language, you could include this information. Alternate translation: [In the first month of the year, which is in early spring]

Here, **fourteen** is a cardinal number used where many languages would use an ordinal number. If your language would not use a cardinal number in this context, use an ordinal number instead. Alternate translation: [on the fourteenth day of]

The phrase **between the evenings** was a common expression of the culture that meant “at twilight,” which is the time period between sundown and darkness. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [as the sun goes down] or [at dusk]

bsb_verse_text: On the fifteenth day of the same month begins the Feast of Unleavened Bread to the LORD. For seven days you must eat unleavened bread.
ult_verse_text: And on day 15 of this month {is} the Festival of Unleavened Bread to Yahweh. Seven days you shall eat unleavened bread.

bsb_verse_text: On the first day you are to hold a sacred assembly; you are not to do any regular work.
