bsb_verse_text: “Speak to the Israelites and say, ‘When you enter the land that I am giving you and you reap its harvest, you are to bring to the priest a sheaf of the firstfruits of your harvest.
ult_verse_text: “Speak to the sons of Israel, and you shall say to them, ‘When you enter into the land that I am giving to you and you harvest its harvest, then you shall bring a sheaf of the first of your harvest to the priest.

notes.note: A **sheaf** is a bundle of grain stalks tied together after being cut. If your language does not have a word for this, you could use a descriptive phrase. Alternate translation: [a bundle of harvested grain stalks from] or [a handful of]

bsb_verse_text: And he shall wave the sheaf before the LORD so that it may be accepted on your behalf; the priest is to wave it on the day after the Sabbath.
ult_verse_text: And he shall wave the sheaf to the face of Yahweh for your acceptance. On the day after the Sabbath the priest shall wave it.

notes.note: See how you translated this expression in [1:5](../01/05.md). Alternate translation: [before Yahweh] or [in Yahweh’s presence]
See how you translated this abstract noun in [1:3](../01/03.md). Alternate translation: [so that Yahweh will accept you] or [so that Yahweh will accept your offering]

bsb_verse_text: On the day you wave the sheaf, you shall offer a year-old lamb without blemish as a burnt offering to the LORD,
ult_verse_text: And on the day you raise the sheaf, you shall offer a perfect lamb, a son of its year, as a burnt offering to Yahweh.

notes.note: See how you translated this idiom in [9:3](../09/03.md). Alternate translation: [one year old] or [that is a year old]

bsb_verse_text: along with its grain offering of two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil—a food offering to the LORD, a pleasing aroma—and its drink offering of a quarter hin of wine.
ult_verse_text: And its grain offering {shall be} two-tenths {of an ephah} of flour mixed with oil, a gift to Yahweh, a scent of pleasing, and its drink offering {shall be} wine, a fourth of a hin.

notes.note: See how you translated this idiom in [1:9](../01/09.md). Alternate translation: [an offering that pleases Yahweh] or [a sacrifice that is acceptable to Yahweh]

The fraction **two-tenths** means two parts out of ten equal parts. Languages handle fractions in different ways. Consider how your language expresses fractions and translate accordingly. Alternate translation: [two parts out of ten of an ephah of] or [one-fifth of an ephah of]

The text only says **two-tenths** but implies that the measurement is in ephahs, which was the standard measure for flour. If your language requires the unit to be stated explicitly, you can include it. Alternate translation: [two-tenths of an ephah of]

An ephah is a Hebrew unit of dry measure, about 22 liters or 20 quarts. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a modern equivalent. Alternate translation: [about 4.4 liters of] or [about 4 quarts of]

The fraction **a fourth of** means one part out of four equal parts. Languages handle fractions in different ways. Consider how your language expresses fractions and translate accordingly. Alternate translation: [one part out of four of a hin] or [a quarter of a hin]

A hin is a Hebrew unit of liquid measure, about 3.8 liters or 1 gallon. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a modern equivalent. Alternate translation: [about 1 liter] or [about 1 quart]

bsb_verse_text: You must not eat any bread or roasted or new grain until the very day you have brought this offering to your God. This is to be a permanent statute for the generations to come, wherever you live.
ult_verse_text: And bread and roasted grain and fresh grain you shall not eat until this same day, until you bring the offering of your God. {It is} a statute of eternity for your generations in all your dwellings.

notes.note: This phrase uses possession to describe an offering that belongs to God because it is given to him. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [the offering that you give to your God] or [the offering that belongs to your God]

See how you translated this phrase in [3:17](../03/17.md). Alternate translation: [It is a rule that will continue forever for all your descendants] or [It is a permanent law that all future generations must obey]

bsb_verse_text: From the day after the Sabbath, the day you brought the sheaf of the wave offering, you are to count off seven full weeks.
ult_verse_text: And you shall count for yourselves from the day after the sabbath, from the day you brought the sheaf of the raised offering, seven sabbaths shall be complete.

notes.note: Here, **seven sabbaths** refers to seven weeks, as the sabbath marks the end of each week. Alternate translation: [seven weeks] or [forty-nine days]

bsb_verse_text: You shall count off fifty days until the day after the seventh Sabbath, and then present an offering of new grain to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: Until the day after the seventh sabbath you shall count 50 days, and you shall present a new grain offering to Yahweh.

notes.orig_language_quote: עַ֣ד מִֽ⁠מָּחֳרַ֤ת הַ⁠שַּׁבָּת֙ הַ⁠שְּׁבִיעִ֔ת תִּסְפְּר֖וּ חֲמִשִּׁ֣ים י֑וֹם
notes.note: This verse clarifies that the fifty days include the seven Sabbaths mentioned in the previous verse. You could say that explicitly if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [Count fifty days, ending on the day after the seventh Sabbath]

bsb_verse_text: Bring two loaves of bread from your dwellings as a wave offering, each made from two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour, baked with leaven, as the firstfruits to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: From your dwellings you shall bring bread of raising, two {loaves} of two-tenths {of an ephah}. They shall be {of} flour. They shall be baked {with} leaven, first fruits to Yahweh.

notes.note: Here, **dwellings** refers specifically to the homes where people live, not the broader meaning used earlier in the chapter. Alternate translation: [From your homes] or [From each household]
See how you translated this measurement in [23:13](../23/13.md).

bsb_verse_text: Along with the bread you are to present seven unblemished male lambs a year old, one young bull, and two rams. They will be a burnt offering to the LORD, together with their grain offerings and drink offerings—a food offering, a pleasing aroma to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And you shall present with the bread seven perfect male lambs, sons of a year, and one bull, a son of cattle, and two rams. They shall be a burnt offering to Yahweh, and their grain offering and their drink offerings, a gift, a scent of pleasing to Yahweh.

notes.note: See how you translated this common expression in [9:3](../09/03.md). Alternate translation: [one-year olds] or [that are a year old]

This phrase may contain extra information that would be unnatural to express in your language. If so, you can shorten it. See how you translated this expression in [4:3](../04/03.md). Alternate translation: [and one young bull]
See how you translated this common expression in [23:13](../23/13.md).

bsb_verse_text: You shall also prepare one male goat as a sin offering and two male lambs a year old as a peace offering.
ult_verse_text: And you shall offer one male goat as a sin offering and two lambs, sons of a year, as a sacrifice of peace offerings.

notes.note: See how you translated this common expression in [23:18](../23/18.md).

bsb_verse_text: The priest is to wave the lambs as a wave offering before the LORD, together with the bread of the firstfruits. The bread and the two lambs shall be holy to the LORD for the priest.
ult_verse_text: And the priest shall raise them with the bread of the first fruits {as} a raised offering to the face of Yahweh, with the two lambs. They shall be holy to Yahweh for the priest.

notes.note: Here, **to the face of Yahweh** means to present something directly to Yahweh. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [before Yahweh] or [in Yahweh’s presence]

bsb_verse_text: On that same day you are to proclaim a sacred assembly, and you must not do any regular work. This is to be a permanent statute wherever you live for the generations to come.
ult_verse_text: And you shall proclaim on this same day: it shall be an assembly of holiness for you. You shall not do any work of labor. {It is} a statute of eternity in all your dwellings for your generations.

notes.note: See how you translated this phrase in [23:7](../23/07.md).
See how you translated this phrase in [23:14](../23/14.md).

bsb_verse_text: When you reap the harvest of your land, do not reap all the way to the edges of your field or gather the gleanings of your harvest. Leave them for the poor and the foreign resident. I am the LORD your God.’”
ult_verse_text: And when you harvest the harvest of your land, you shall not finish the edge of your field in your harvesting, and you shall not glean the gleaning of your harvest. For the poor and for the foreigner you shall leave them. I {am} Yahweh your God.’”

notes.orig_language_quote: לֹֽא־תְכַלֶּ֞ה פְּאַ֤ת שָֽׂדְ⁠ךָ֙ בְּ⁠קֻצְרֶ֔⁠ךָ וְ⁠לֶ֥קֶט קְצִירְ⁠ךָ֖ לֹ֣א תְלַקֵּ֑ט
notes.note: This instruction refers to specific harvesting laws. If it would be helpful in your translation, you could add a footnote explaining the purpose of these practices and referring readers to where it was commanded. See [Leviticus 19:9–10](../19/09.md) for the full explanation of this law and its purpose. Alternate translation: [do not harvest all the way to the edges of your field, and do not pick up the grain that falls on the ground]

bsb_verse_text: “Speak to the Israelites and say, ‘On the first day of the seventh month you are to have a day of rest, a sacred assembly announced by trumpet blasts.
ult_verse_text: “Speak to the sons of Israel, saying, ‘In the seventh month, on {day} one of the month, there shall be for you a rest, a memorial of a loud blast, an assembly of holiness.

notes.note: This refers to the seventh month of the Hebrew calendar, which occurs in September-October on modern calendars. If it would be helpful in your language, you could include this information. Alternate translation: [In the seventh month of the year, which is in early autumn]
If your language would not use a number in a form such as **day one**, you could represent this number in a form your language would use. Alternate translation: [on the first day of the month]

If your language does not use abstract nouns for these concepts, you could express the same ideas in other ways. Alternate translation: [a day when you rest from work, shout to remember important events, and gather together to worship in a special way] or [a time for you to stop working, to call out loudly as you recall significant moments, and to come together for a sacred meeting]

bsb_verse_text: You must not do any regular work, but you are to present a food offering to the LORD.’”
ult_verse_text: You shall not do any work of labor, and you shall present a gift to Yahweh.’”

notes.note: See how you translated this phrase in [23:7](../23/07.md).

bsb_verse_text: “The tenth day of this seventh month is the Day of Atonement. You shall hold a sacred assembly and humble yourselves, and present a food offering to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: “Surely on the tenth of this seventh month, it is the Day of Atonement. It shall be an assembly of holiness for you, and you shall humble your souls, and you shall present a gift to Yahweh.

notes.note: See how you translated this abstract noun in [8:9](../08/09.md).
See how you translated this expression in [16:29](../16/29.md). Alternate translation: [and you shall deny yourselves] or [and you shall fast and pray to show your sadness for your sins]

bsb_verse_text: On this day you are not to do any work, for it is the Day of Atonement, when atonement is made for you before the LORD your God.
ult_verse_text: And you shall not do any work on this same day, for it {is} a Day of Atonement, to make atonement for you to the face of Yahweh your God.

notes.note: See how you translated this expression in [1:5](../01/05.md). Alternate translation: [before Yahweh your God] or [in the presence of Yahweh your God]

bsb_verse_text: If anyone does not humble himself on this day, he must be cut off from his people.
ult_verse_text: For any person who is not humbled on this same day shall be cut off from his people.

notes.note: See the Introduction to [chapter 7](../07/01.md) for more information and see how you translated this in [7:20](../07/20.md).

bsb_verse_text: You are not to do any work at all. This is a permanent statute for the generations to come, wherever you live.
ult_verse_text: You shall not do any work. {It is} a statute of eternity for your generations in all your dwellings.

notes.note: See how you translated this phrase in [23:14](../23/14.md) and [23:21](../23/21.md). This phrase emphasizes the enduring nature of the law. Alternate translation: [It is a rule that will continue forever for all your descendants] or [It is a permanent law that all future generations must obey]

bsb_verse_text: It will be a Sabbath of complete rest for you, and you shall humble yourselves. From the evening of the ninth day of the month until the following evening you are to keep your Sabbath.”
ult_verse_text: It {is} a sabbath of sabbaths for you, and you shall humble your souls. On {day} nine of the month in the evening, from evening until evening, you shall observe your sabbath.’”

notes.note: This is an idiom emphasizing that this is a very important sabbath. Alternate translation: [is a special sabbath] or [is an especially important day of rest]

bsb_verse_text: “Speak to the Israelites and say, ‘On the fifteenth day of the seventh month the Feast of Tabernacles to the LORD begins, and it continues for seven days.
ult_verse_text: “Speak to the sons of Israel, saying, ‘On day 15 of this seventh month {is} the Feast of Booths {for} seven days to Yahweh.

notes.orig_language_quote: בַּ⁠חֲמִשָּׁ֨ה עָשָׂ֜ר י֗וֹם לַ⁠חֹ֤דֶשׁ הַ⁠שְּׁבִיעִי֙ הַ⁠זֶּ֔ה
notes.note: If your language would not represent a number in a form such as **day 15**, you could represent this number in a form your language would use. Alternate translation: [On the fifteenth day of this seventh month]

bsb_verse_text: On the first day there shall be a sacred assembly. You must not do any regular work.
ult_verse_text: On the first day is an assembly of holiness. You shall not do any work of labor.

notes.note: See how you translated [23:7](../23/07.md).

bsb_verse_text: For seven days you are to present a food offering to the LORD. On the eighth day you are to hold a sacred assembly and present a food offering to the LORD. It is a solemn assembly; you must not do any regular work.
ult_verse_text: {For} seven days you shall present a gift to Yahweh. On the eighth day there shall be an assembly of holiness for you, and you shall present a gift to Yahweh. It is a holiday. You shall not do any work of labor.

notes.note: This phrase means to do something every day for a week. See how you translated this in [23:8](../23/08.md). Alternate translation: [Each day for seven days] or [Every day for a week]
See how you translated this phrase in [23:2](../23/02.md).
See how you translated this phrase in [23:7](../23/07.md).

bsb_verse_text: These are the LORD’s appointed feasts, which you are to proclaim as sacred assemblies for presenting food offerings to the LORD—burnt offerings and grain offerings, sacrifices and drink offerings, each on its designated day.
ult_verse_text: These {are} the appointed times of Yahweh which you shall proclaim {as} assemblies of holiness, to present a gift to Yahweh: a burnt offering and a grain offering, a sacrifice and drink offerings, the thing of a day on its day,

notes.note: This is a common expression that means to do what is required each day. Alternate translation: [as each day requires] or [what needs to be done on each specific day]

bsb_verse_text: These offerings are in addition to the offerings for the LORD’s Sabbaths, and in addition to your gifts, to all your vow offerings, and to all the freewill offerings you give to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: besides the sabbaths of Yahweh and besides your gifts and besides all your vows and besides all your freewill offerings that you give to Yahweh.

notes.orig_language_quote: מִ⁠לְּ⁠בַ֖ד שַׁבְּתֹ֣ת יְּהוָ֑ה וּ⁠מִ⁠לְּ⁠בַ֣ד מַתְּנֽוֹתֵי⁠כֶ֗ם וּ⁠מִ⁠לְּ⁠בַ֤ד כָּל־נִדְרֵי⁠כֶם֙ וּ⁠מִ⁠לְּ⁠בַד֙ כָּל־נִדְב֣וֹתֵי⁠כֶ֔ם
notes.note: This verse lists several types of offerings that are in addition to the regular festival offerings. If your language has a way to express items in a list that are additional to something else, you could use it here. Alternate translation: [in addition to your regular Sabbath offerings, your other gifts, your vows, and your freewill offerings]

bsb_verse_text: On the fifteenth day of the seventh month, after you have gathered the produce of the land, you are to celebrate a feast to the LORD for seven days. There shall be complete rest on the first day and also on the eighth day.
ult_verse_text: Surely on day 15 of the seventh month, when you gather the produce of the land, you shall celebrate the feast of Yahweh {for} seven days. On the first day {shall be} a sabbath, and on the eighth day {shall be} a sabbath.

notes.note: If your language would not represent a number using the form **day 15**, you could represent this number in a form your language would use. Alternate translation: [on the fifteenth day of the seventh month]

bsb_verse_text: On the first day you are to gather the fruit of majestic trees, the branches of palm trees, and the boughs of leafy trees and of willows of the brook. And you are to rejoice before the LORD your God for seven days.
ult_verse_text: And you shall take for yourselves on the first day the fruit of majestic trees, branches of palm trees, and boughs of leafy trees and willows of the river, and you shall rejoice to the face of Yahweh your God {for} seven days.

notes.note: See how you translated this expression in [1:5](../01/05.md).
See how you translated this phrase in [23:8](../23/08.md). Alternate translation: [each day for seven days] or [every day for a week]

bsb_verse_text: You are to celebrate this as a feast to the LORD for seven days each year. This is a permanent statute for the generations to come; you are to celebrate it in the seventh month.
ult_verse_text: And you shall celebrate it {as} a feast to Yahweh {for} seven days in the year. {It is} a statute of eternity for your generations. In the seventh month you shall celebrate it.

notes.note: See how you translated this phrase in [23:14](../23/14.md).

bsb_verse_text: so that your descendants may know that I made the Israelites dwell in booths when I brought them out of the land of Egypt. I am the LORD your God.’”
ult_verse_text: so that your generations may know that I made the sons of Israel dwell in booths when I brought them out from the land of Egypt. I {am} Yahweh your God.’”

notes.note: Here, **sons of Israel** refers to the Israelite people who came out of Egypt. This represents all the Israelite people by referring to them as sons. Alternate translation: [the Israelite people] or [the people of Israel]

This verse explains why God commanded the people to live in booths during the festival. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this connection more explicit. Alternate translation: [I commanded this so that all your descendants would remember]

bsb_verse_text: “Command the Israelites to bring you pure oil of pressed olives for the light, to keep the lamps burning continually.
ult_verse_text: “Command the sons of Israel, and they shall bring to you pure oil of olive, beaten, for the light, to make a lamp go up continually.

notes.note: The text reports indirectly what the sons of Israel should do. If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this as a direct quotation. Alternate translation: [the sons of Israel, ‘Bring to me]

Here, **to make a lamp go up** is a common expression that means to keep it burning. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [to keep the lamp burning]
If you have translated Exodus, see how you translated these same instructions in [Exodus 27:20–21](../../exo/27/20.md).

bsb_verse_text: Outside the veil of the Testimony in the Tent of Meeting, Aaron is to tend the lamps continually before the LORD from evening until morning. This is to be a permanent statute for the generations to come.
ult_verse_text: From outside of the curtain of the testimony in the tent of meeting, Aaron shall arrange it from evening until morning to the face of Yahweh continually. {It is} a statute of eternity for your generations.

notes.note: In some languages, the word **from** is redundant here. Express this in a way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Outside]
See how you translated this expression in [23:40](../23/40.md). Alternate translation: [in the presence of]
See how you translated this expression in [23:41](../23/41.md). Alternate translation: [It is a permanent law]

bsb_verse_text: He shall tend the lamps on the pure gold lampstand before the LORD continually.
ult_verse_text: On the pure lampstand he shall arrange the lamps to the face of Yahweh continually.

notes.note: See how you translated this expression in [24:3](../24/03.md). Alternate translation: [in the presence of]
The word **he** refers to Aaron. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [Aaron shall arrange]

bsb_verse_text: You are also to take fine flour and bake twelve loaves, using two-tenths of an ephah for each loaf,
ult_verse_text: And you shall take flour and you shall bake it {into} 12 loaves. Two-tenths {of an ephah} shall be the one loaf.

notes.note: See how you translated this expression in [23:13](../23/13.md).

The word **you** could refer to Moses (because Yahweh is talking directly to him) or Aaron (because starting in [verse 8](../24/08.md) the instructions are to Aaron and [verses 5-7](../24/05.md) seem to go with [verses 8-9](../24/08.md)). Some think it refers to Moses initially and then to Aaron and his sons later. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers so you may have to decide to specify who **you** refers to.

bsb_verse_text: and set them in two rows—six per row—on the table of pure gold before the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And you shall place them {in} two rows, six {in} the row, on the pure table to the face of Yahweh.

notes.note: See how you translated this expression in [24:3](../24/03.md). Alternate translation: [in the presence of]

bsb_verse_text: And you are to place pure frankincense near each row, so that it may serve as a memorial portion for the bread, a food offering to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And you shall put on the row pure frankincense, and it shall be for the bread as a memorial portion, a gift to Yahweh.

notes.note: Here, **on the row** means “on each row.” If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this clear for your readers. Alternate translation: [on each row]

bsb_verse_text: Every Sabbath day the bread is to be set out before the LORD on behalf of the Israelites as a permanent covenant.
ult_verse_text: On the day of the sabbath, on the day of the sabbath, he shall arrange it to the face of Yahweh continually from the sons of Israel, a covenant of eternity.

notes.note: This repetition means “on each sabbath.” If it would be more natural in your language, you could express this in a different way. Alternate translation: [Every sabbath day]
See how you translated this expression in [24:3](../24/03.md). Alternate translation: [in the presence of]

The text does not specify what comes **from the sons of Israel**. If it would be helpful in your language, you could be more explicit. Alternate translation: [, this bread that is from the sons of Israel]
If possible, translate this similar to how you translated “statute of eternity” in [24:3](../24/03.md). Alternate translation: [a permanent covenant]

bsb_verse_text: It belongs to Aaron and his sons, who are to eat it in a holy place; for it is to him a most holy part of the food offerings to the LORD—his portion forever.”
ult_verse_text: And it shall be for Aaron and for his sons, and they shall eat it in a holy place, for it {is} a holy of holies for him from the gifts of Yahweh, a statute of eternity.”

notes.note: The text does not specify what is **for Aaron and his sons**. If it would be helpful for your readers, you could make this explicit. Alternate translation: [And this bread shall be for Aaron and for his sons]

Here, **a holy of holies** is a common expression meaning something that is extremely holy. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [is most holy] or [is extremely sacred]
See how you translated this expression in [24:3](../24/03.md). Alternate translation: [a permanent law]

bsb_verse_text: Now the son of an Israelite mother and an Egyptian father went out among the Israelites, and a fight broke out in the camp between him and an Israelite.
ult_verse_text: And a son of an Israelite woman (and he {was} a son of an Egyptian man) went out among the sons of Israel. And they fought in the camp, the son of the Israelite woman and the Israelite man.

notes.note: A specific event occurs here which interrupts Yahweh’s giving instructions to Moses about the special feast and sabbaths. However, it also provides some of Israel’s important case law. Use a word, phrase, or other method in your language that is natural for introducing a new event.

bsb_verse_text: The son of the Israelite woman blasphemed the Name with a curse. So they brought him to Moses. (His mother’s name was Shelomith daughter of Dibri, of the tribe of Dan.)
ult_verse_text: And the son of the Israelite woman blasphemed the Name and cursed. And they brought him to Moses. And the name of his mother {was} Shelomith, daughter of Dibri, of the tribe of Dan.

notes.note: Here, **the Name** is a polite and respectful way of referring to Yahweh. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a polite way of referring to Yahweh, or you could state this directly. Alternate translation: [Yahweh]
The word **they** refers to the sons of Israel. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [And the Israelites brought]
This is the name of a man.

bsb_verse_text: They placed him in custody until the will of the LORD should be made clear to them.
ult_verse_text: And they placed him in custody to declare to them according to the mouth of Yahweh.

notes.note: Alternate translation: [until Yahweh would declare to them what he wanted them to do with the man who blasphemed]

Here, **according to the mouth of Yahweh** is a common expression meaning “according to Yahweh’s instructions.” If this phrase would not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [according to what Yahweh would command]

bsb_verse_text: “Take the blasphemer outside the camp, and have all who heard him lay their hands on his head; then have the whole assembly stone him.
ult_verse_text: “Bring out the curser to outside of the camp, and all the hearers shall lay their hands on his head, and all the congregation shall stone him.

notes.note: Here, **the curser** refers to the man who cursed Yahweh. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could include this information. Alternate translation: [the one who cursed]
Here, **hearers** refers to those who heard the man curse. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could include this information. Alternate translation: [those who heard him curse]

Here, laying **their hands on his head** was a symbolic action to show that they were witnesses to the fact that the man was guilty. If it would not be clear to your readers, you could explain the significance of this action in the text or in a footnote. Alternate translation: [and … shall place their hands on his head to show that they witnessed his guilty action]

bsb_verse_text: And you are to tell the Israelites, ‘If anyone curses his God, he shall bear the consequences of his sin.
ult_verse_text: And to the sons of Israel you shall speak, saying, ‘A man, a man if he curses his God, then he shall bear his sin.

notes.note: The word **saying** marks the beginning of a quotation within a quotation. If it would be clearer in your language, you could translate this so that there is not a quotation within a quotation. Alternate translation: [say that if a man, a man curses]

Here, **a man** is used to mean any person and not one particular person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a more natural expression. Alternate translation: [Any person] or [Anyone]

Here the masculine term **man** has a generic sense that includes both men and women. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that makes this clear. Alternate translation: [Any person] or [Anyone]
This presents a hypothetical situation. Use a natural form in your language for introducing a situation that could happen. Alternate translation: [Whoever curses his God]

When Israel entered and conquered the promised land Yahweh gave certain parts of it to each tribe and family. These parts were always to stay in that family. Sometimes families had to sell parts of that land because of debt or other poverty. But, except for certain circumstances, that land always had to go back to the original family in the 50th year. Because this is all discussed later in the chapter, there is no need to include this extra information here.

ult_verse_text: And a field of the pastureland of their cities shall not be sold, for it {is} a possession of perpetuity for them.

notes.note: See how you translated similar phrases in [25:30](../25/30.md) or [25:32](../25/32.md). Alternate translation: [is a permanent possession]

bsb_verse_text: Now if your countryman becomes destitute and cannot support himself among you, then you are to help him as you would a foreigner or stranger, so that he can continue to live among you.
ult_verse_text: And if your brother becomes poor, and his hand wavers with you, then you shall strengthen him; and {as} a sojourner and temporary resident he shall live with you.

notes.note: This introduces a hypothetical situation. Use a natural way in your language to introduce a situation that could happen. Alternate translation: [Suppose] or [When]

Here, **your brother** refers to any fellow Israelite, not only literal brothers. Use a natural way in your language to express this relationship. Alternate translation: [your fellow Israelite] or [your countryman]

Here, **brother** refers to any Israelite, whether male or female. Use a word in your language that makes this clear. Alternate translation: [your fellow Israelite] or [any countryman or countrywoman]

Here, **his hand wavers** is a common expression that means he becomes poor or struggles financially. If this phrase does not mean this in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and he becomes unable to support himself] or [and he falls into financial difficulty]

Here, **then you shall strengthen** refers specifically to providing financial or material support. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state this explicitly. Alternate translation: [help him by providing what he needs] or [support him financially]

bsb_verse_text: Do not take any interest or profit from him, but fear your God, that your countryman may live among you.
ult_verse_text: You shall not take from him interest or profit, but you shall fear from your God, and your brother shall live with you.

notes.orig_language_quote: אַל־תִּקַּ֤ח מֵֽ⁠אִתּ⁠וֹ֙ נֶ֣שֶׁךְ וְ⁠תַרְבִּ֔ית וְ⁠יָרֵ֖אתָ מֵֽ⁠אֱלֹהֶ֑י⁠ךָ וְ⁠חֵ֥י אָחִ֖י⁠ךָ עִמָּֽ⁠ךְ
notes.note: Here, fearing God is given as the reason for not charging interest and letting your brother live with you. If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases, since the second phrase gives the reason for the result the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [Because you must fear your God, you shall not take interest or profit from him, and your brother shall live with you] or [Since you must honor your God, do not charge him interest or profit, and let your brother live with you]

bsb_verse_text: You must not lend him your silver at interest or sell him your food for profit.
ult_verse_text: Your silver you shall not give to him with interest, and for profit you shall not give your food.

notes.note: Here the verse expresses a single idea by repeating it in a way that the middle parts match (**interest** and **profit**) and the outside parts (**silver** and **food**) match. The two parts emphasize that you should not profit from lending anything to a poor person. If your language has a natural way to express this kind of emphasis through repetition, you could use it. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could combine the ideas and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [Do not charge interest when you lend money or food to him] or [You must not make any profit when you lend either silver or food to him]

bsb_verse_text: I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt to give you the land of Canaan and to be your God.
ult_verse_text: I {am} Yahweh your God, who brought you out from the land of Egypt, to give to you the land of Canaan, to be God to you.

notes.note: Throughout this verse, **you** is plural and refers to all the Israelites. Use the plural form of “you” in your translation if your language marks that distinction. Alternate translation: [all of you … to all of you … to all of you]

bsb_verse_text: If a countryman among you becomes destitute and sells himself to you, then you must not force him into slave labor.
ult_verse_text: And if your brother with you becomes poor and sells himself to you, you shall not work him with the work of a slave.

notes.note: See how you translated this conditional phrase in [25:35](../25/35.md). Alternate translation: [Suppose]
See how you translated this term in [25:35](../25/35.md). Alternate translation: [your fellow Israelite]

The words **sells himself** indicates someone taking action on themselves. Use a way that is natural in your language to indicate that the same person is both the subject and the object of the action. Alternate translation: [and becomes your slave] or [and sells himself into your service]

bsb_verse_text: Because the Israelites are My servants, whom I brought out of the land of Egypt, they are not to be sold as slaves.
ult_verse_text: For they {are} my servants whom I brought them out from the land of Egypt. They shall not be sold {in} a sale of a slave.

notes.note: The word translated as **For** indicates that what is follows is the reason for the instructions in [verses 39-43](../25/39.md). Use a natural way in your language to make this clear.

bsb_verse_text: You are not to rule over them harshly, but you shall fear your God.
ult_verse_text: You shall not rule over him with harshness, but you shall fear from your God.

notes.note: Here, **harshness** is an abstract noun that refers to cruel or severe treatment. If your language does not use abstract nouns for the idea of **harshness**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [or treat him harshly] or [or act cruelly toward him]
See how you translated this phrase in [25:36](../25/36.md). Alternate translation: [but you shall honor your God]

bsb_verse_text: Your menservants and maidservants shall come from the nations around you, from whom you may purchase them.
ult_verse_text: And your male slave and your female slave who are to you—from the nations who {are} around you, from them you may buy a male slave and a female slave.

notes.note: This introduces a new, but related, topic. If the connection between this statement and the previous one is not clear, you may want to use a different connecting word to show how this statement relates to what comes before it. Alternate translation: [As for your male slave]

These are generic nouns referring to any slaves in these categories. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And any of your male slaves or your female slaves … male slaves or female slaves]

bsb_verse_text: You may leave them to your sons after you to inherit as property; you can make them slaves for life. But as for your brothers, the Israelites, no man may rule harshly over his brother.
ult_verse_text: And you may give them as an inheritance to your sons after you, to inherit {as} a possession. You may make them serve to perpetuity, but your brothers, the sons of Israel, a man with his brother, you shall not rule over him with harshness.

notes.note: See how you translated this phrase in [25:43](../25/43.md). Alternate translation: [harshly]

bsb_verse_text: If a foreigner residing among you prospers, but your countryman dwelling near him becomes destitute and sells himself to the foreigner or to a member of his clan,
ult_verse_text: And if the hand of a sojourner or temporary resident with you reaches, and your brother with him becomes poor and sells himself to the sojourner (a temporary resident) with you, or to a member of the clan of a sojourner,

notes.note: As you are translating [verses 47-55](../25/47.md) keep in mind that the situation described is that of an Israelite who has become a slave to a foreigner.
This entire verse is a hypothetical situation. Express this possible condition in a way that would be natural in your language.
See how you translated this common expression in [25:26](../25/26.md). Alternate translation: [a foreigner living among you becomes wealthy]

The words **sells himself** describes someone taking action on themselves. Use a way that is natural in your language to indicate that the same person is both the subject and the object of the action. Alternate translation: [and becomes a slave] or [and sells himself into slavery]

bsb_verse_text: he retains the right of redemption after he has sold himself. One of his brothers may redeem him:
ult_verse_text: after he is sold, redemption may be to him. One from his brothers may redeem him,

notes.note: This means he can be freed by someone paying a price. Alternate translation: [he can be redeemed] or [someone can buy back his freedom]

bsb_verse_text: either his uncle or cousin or any close relative from his clan may redeem him. Or if he prospers, he may redeem himself.
ult_verse_text: or his uncle or the son of his uncle may redeem him, or {someone} from the relatives of his flesh from his clan may redeem him, or if his hand reaches, then he may redeem himself.

notes.note: See how you translated this idiom in [25:26](../25/26.md). Alternate translation: [he becomes prosperous]

This phrase describes someone taking action on themselves. Use a way that is natural in your language to indicate that the same person is both the subject and the object of the action. Alternate translation: [then he may buy back his own freedom]

bsb_verse_text: He and his purchaser will then count the time from the year he sold himself up to the Year of Jubilee. The price of his sale will be determined by the number of years, based on the daily wages of a hired hand.
ult_verse_text: And he shall calculate with his buyer from the year of his selling himself to him until the Year of Jubilee, and the silver of his sale shall be by the number of years. Like the days of a hired worker he shall be with him.

notes.note: This phrase describes someone taking action on themselves. Use a way that is natural in your language to indicate that the same person is both the subject and the object of the action. Alternate translation: [his becoming a slave]
Here, **to him** refers to the buyer. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [to the buyer]

Here, **the silver of his sale** refers to the price that he needs to pay to buy back his freedom. This price should be calculated based on the number of years remaining until the Year of Jubilee. You could include this information if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and the price that he needs to pay to buy back his freedom should be calculated by the number of years until the Year of Jubilee]

This compares the way to calculate the redemption price to how a hired worker is paid. Just as a hired worker is paid for the days he works, the redemption price should be based on the years of service remaining. Alternate translation: [The price should be calculated as if he were a hired worker being paid for those years]

bsb_verse_text: If many years remain, he must pay for his redemption in proportion to his purchase price.
ult_verse_text: If {there are} still many in the years, to their mouth he shall pay back his redemption from the silver of his purchase.

notes.note: Here, this describes how to calculate the price of freedom. The person must pay back part of the original purchase price, based on how many years are left until the Year of Jubilee. If it would be clearer in your language, you could state this explicitly. Alternate translation: [he must pay back the portion of the original purchase price that matches the remaining years of service] or [he must repay part of what the buyer paid for him, calculated according to the remaining years]

This refers to having many years remaining until the Year of Jubilee. If it would be clearer in your language, you could express this explicitly. Alternate translation: [many years remaining] or [many years left]

See how you translated this common expression in [25:16](../25/16.md). This expression means “according to” or “in proportion to.” Use a natural expression in your language that communicates this meaning. Alternate translation: [according to the number of years] or [based on the remaining years]

Here, this describes how to calculate the price of freedom. The person must pay back part of the original purchase price, based on how many years are left until the Year of Jubilee. You could include this information if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [he must pay back the portion of the original purchase price that matches the remaining years of service] or [he must repay part of what the buyer paid for him, calculated according to the remaining years]

bsb_verse_text: If only a few years remain until the Year of Jubilee, he is to calculate and pay his redemption according to his remaining years.
ult_verse_text: But if few remain in the years until the Year of Jubilee, then he shall calculate with him. According to the mouth of his years he shall pay back his redemption.

notes.note: See how you translated this common expression in [25:51](../25/51.md). Alternate translation: [According to the number of years remaining]

bsb_verse_text: He shall be treated like a man hired from year to year, but a foreign owner must not rule over him harshly in your sight.
ult_verse_text: Like a hired worker year by year he shall be with him. He shall not rule over him with harshness before your eyes.

notes.note: In the first sentence, **he** refers to the slave and **him** refers to the foreign buyer. In the second sentence, **He** refers to the foreign buyer and **him** refers to the slave. Alternate translation: [the slave shall be with the owner. The owner shall not rule over the slave]

Here, **before your eyes** means that the other Israelites are to watch how Israelite slaves are treated by their masters. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [under your supervision] or [while you watch]

bsb_verse_text: Even if he is not redeemed in any of these ways, he and his children shall be released in the Year of Jubilee.
ult_verse_text: And if he is not redeemed by these {means}, then he shall go out in the Year of Jubilee, he and his sons with him.

notes.note: Here, **sons** refers to children of both genders. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use language in your translation that is clearly inclusive of both male and female children. Alternate translation: [and his children]

bsb_verse_text: For the Israelites are My servants. They are My servants, whom I brought out of the land of Egypt. I am the LORD your God.
ult_verse_text: For the sons of Israel {are} servants to me. They {are} my servants whom I brought them out from the land of Egypt. I {am} Yahweh your God.

notes.note: Here, **them** refers to the sons of Israel. In some languages, this pronoun may be redundant and can be omitted. Alternate translation: [the Israelites]

bsb_verse_text: “You must not make idols for yourselves or set up a carved image or sacred pillar; you must not place a sculpted stone in your land to bow down to it. For I am the LORD your God.
ult_verse_text: You shall not make for yourselves worthless little gods, and a carved image and a pillar you shall not raise up for yourselves, and a stone of imagery you shall not put in your land to bow down to it, for I {am} Yahweh your God.

notes.note: Here, **for I am Yahweh your God** gives the reason for the commands that precede it. Use a connector in your language that makes it clear that what follows is a reason for what came before. If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases. Alternate translation: [because I am Yahweh your God] or [Obey these commands because I am Yahweh your God]

bsb_verse_text: You must keep My Sabbaths and have reverence for My sanctuary. I am the LORD.
ult_verse_text: My Sabbaths you shall keep and my holy place you shall fear. I {am} Yahweh.

notes.note: See how you translated this in [26:1](../26/01.md). Here, **I am Yahweh** gives the reason for the command. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use a connecting word to make this relationship clear. Alternate translation: [because I am Yahweh]
This verse is identical to [19:30](../19/30.md). See how you translated it there.

bsb_verse_text: If you follow My statutes and carefully keep My commandments,
ult_verse_text: If you walk in my statutes and keep my commandments and do them,

notes.note: Here, **walk in my statutes** represents living according to God’s laws. Use a natural way in your language to express following or obeying laws. Alternate translation: [you live according to my laws]

notes.orig_language_quote: בְּ⁠חֻקֹּתַ֖⁠י תֵּלֵ֑כוּ וְ⁠אֶת־מִצְוֺתַ֣⁠י תִּשְׁמְר֔וּ וַ⁠עֲשִׂיתֶ֖ם אֹתָֽ⁠ם
notes.note: These three phrases mean basically the same thing. The second and third phrases emphasize the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. If it would be clearer in your language, you could combine these phrases and express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [you completely and faithfully follow my rules]

bsb_verse_text: I will give you rains in their season, and the land will yield its produce, and the trees of the field will bear their fruit.
ult_verse_text: then I will give your rains in their time, and the land will give its produce, and the tree of the field will give its fruit.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠נָתַתִּ֥י גִשְׁמֵי⁠כֶ֖ם בְּ⁠עִתָּ֑⁠ם וְ⁠נָתְנָ֤ה הָ⁠אָ֨רֶץ֙ יְבוּלָ֔⁠הּ וְ⁠עֵ֥ץ הַ⁠שָּׂדֶ֖ה יִתֵּ֥ן פִּרְיֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: Here, **I will give** leaves out “to you” which is understood. If your language requires this information to be stated explicitly, include it. Alternate translation: [then I will give to you your rains in their time, and the land will give its produce to you, and the tree of the field will give its fruit to you]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠נָתְנָ֤ה הָ⁠אָ֨רֶץ֙ יְבוּלָ֔⁠הּ וְ⁠עֵ֥ץ הַ⁠שָּׂדֶ֖ה יִתֵּ֥ן פִּרְיֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: Here, **the land** and **trees** are spoken of as if they were people who could give gifts. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and crops will grow in the land, and trees in the fields will produce fruit]

Here, **tree of the field** refers to any fruit-bearing tree and not a specific tree. Use a natural expression in your language that includes all such trees. Alternate translation: [and fruit trees will give their fruit] or [and trees that grow in your fields will give their fruit]

bsb_verse_text: Your threshing will continue until the grape harvest, and the grape harvest will continue until sowing time; you will have your fill of food to eat and will dwell securely in your land.
ult_verse_text: And threshing will reach grape harvest for you, and grape harvest will reach seed, and you will eat your bread to satisfaction, and you will dwell in security in your land.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הִשִּׂ֨יג לָ⁠כֶ֥ם דַּ֨יִשׁ֙ אֶת־בָּצִ֔יר וּ⁠בָצִ֖יר יַשִּׂ֣יג אֶת־זָ֑רַע
notes.note: Here, **threshing will reach** means the harvests will be so abundant that one crop’s processing will overlap with the next harvest. Express this abundance clearly in your language. Alternate translation: [And you will have such abundant harvests that you will still be threshing grain when it is time to harvest grapes, and still be harvesting grapes when it is time to plant seeds]
Here, **seed** represents the activity of planting. Use a phrase that clearly refers to the planting season. Alternate translation: [planting time] or [the time to plant]

If your language does not use abstract nouns for the ideas of **satisfaction** and **security**, you could express these ideas in a natural way in your language. Alternate translation: [until you are satisfied, and you will live safely]

bsb_verse_text: And I will give peace to the land, and you will lie down with nothing to fear. I will rid the land of dangerous animals, and no sword will pass through your land.
ult_verse_text: And I will give peace in the land, and you will lie down and there will be no one making {you} afraid. And I will remove harmful animals from the land, and a sword will not pass through in your land.

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **peace**, you could express this in a natural way in your language. Alternate translation: [I will make things peaceful] or [I will cause you to live peacefully]

Here, **sword** represents war or armed conflict. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and there will be no war in your land] or [and no army will attack your land]

bsb_verse_text: You will pursue your enemies, and they will fall by the sword before you.
ult_verse_text: And you will pursue your enemies, and they will fall to your faces to the sword.

notes.note: Here, **to your faces** means “before you” or “in front of you” in battle. Use an equivalent expression in your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [when you attack them] or [before your attack]

Here, **fall … to the sword** is a common expression meaning to die in battle. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, use a comparable expression in your translation that does have that meaning, or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and they will die in battle before you] or [and they will be killed to your faces]

bsb_verse_text: Five of you will pursue a hundred, and a hundred of you will pursue ten thousand, and your enemies will fall by the sword before you.
ult_verse_text: And five from you will pursue a hundred, and a hundred from you will pursue ten thousand, and your enemies will fall to your faces to the sword.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠רָדְפ֨וּ מִ⁠כֶּ֤ם חֲמִשָּׁה֙ מֵאָ֔ה וּ⁠מֵאָ֥ה מִ⁠כֶּ֖ם רְבָבָ֣ה יִרְדֹּ֑פוּ
notes.note: These parallel statements are expressed in a poetic, proverbial way to emphasize how God will empower a small number to defeat many enemies. If your language has poetic or proverbial ways to express this kind of dramatic contrast, use them. Alternate translation: [Five will chase a hundred, a hundred will chase ten thousand] or express it as a proverb like [Your fives will scatter hundreds, your hundreds will scatter thousands]
See how you translated this in [26:7](../26/07.md). Here, **fall to your faces to the sword** means to die in battle.

bsb_verse_text: I will turn toward you and make you fruitful and multiply you, and I will establish My covenant with you.
ult_verse_text: And I will turn to you and make you fruitful and multiply you, and I will establish my covenant with you.

notes.note: Here, **I will turn to you** is a common expression meaning to show favor. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will favor you] or [I will bless you]

See how you translated this in [Genesis 1:28](../../gen/01/28.md). Here, **make you fruitful and multiply you** means to cause the people to have many children and descendants. Alternate translation: [and cause you to have many children and descendants]

bsb_verse_text: You will still be eating the old supply of grain when you need to clear it out to make room for the new.
ult_verse_text: And you will eat old {grain that is} getting old, and you will bring out the old from the face of the new.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠אֲכַלְתֶּ֥ם יָשָׁ֖ן נוֹשָׁ֑ן וְ⁠יָשָׁ֕ן מִ⁠פְּנֵ֥י חָדָ֖שׁ תּוֹצִֽיאוּ
notes.note: Here, **old** is repeated three times to emphasize abundance, not staleness. Express this emphasis on abundance in a way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [You will still have plenty of last year’s grain when the new harvest comes]

Here, **from the face of** is a common expression meaning to make room for something. Use a natural way in your language to express making space available. Alternate translation: [to make room for the new grain] or [because you need space for the new crop]

Here, **old** and **new** leave out the word “grain” or “crop” which is understood. If your language requires this to be stated explicitly, include it. Alternate translation: [old grain … and … the old grain … the new grain] or [old crop … and … the old crop … the new crop]

bsb_verse_text: And I will make My dwelling place among you, and My soul will not despise you.
ult_verse_text: And I will put my dwelling place in your midst, and my soul will not reject you.

notes.note: Here, **my soul** represents all of God. Use a natural way in your language to refer to the whole person. Alternate translation: [I] or [I, myself]

bsb_verse_text: I will walk among you and be your God, and you will be My people.
ult_verse_text: And I will walk in your midst and be God to you, and you will be a people to me.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠הָיִ֥יתִי לָ⁠כֶ֖ם לֵֽ⁠אלֹהִ֑ים וְ⁠אַתֶּ֖ם תִּהְיוּ־לִ֥⁠י לְ⁠עָֽם
notes.note: Here, this means “I will be your God and you will be my people.” If your language requires the relationship to be stated more explicitly, you can do so. Alternate translation: [I will be your God and you will be my people]

Here God is described as walking among his people like a person would. Use a natural way in your language to express God’s presence among people. Alternate translation: [I will live among you] or [I will be present with you]

bsb_verse_text: I am the LORD your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt so that you would no longer be slaves to the Egyptians. I broke the bars of your yoke and enabled you to walk in uprightness.
ult_verse_text: I {am} Yahweh your God who brought you out from the land of Egypt from being slaves to them, and I broke the bars of your yoke and made you walk upright.

notes.note: Here, **bars of your yoke** represents slavery. Use a natural way in your language to express freedom from slavery. Alternate translation: [I freed you from slavery] or [I released you from bondage]

Here, **walk upright** represents freedom and dignity. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and made you free people] or [and gave you dignity]

bsb_verse_text: If, however, you fail to obey Me and to carry out all these commandments,
ult_verse_text: But if you will not listen to me and will not do all these commandments,

notes.note: Here, **But if** introduces a contrast between [verses 3](../26/03.md) and [4](../26/04.md). Use a natural way in your language to show this contrast. Alternate translation: [However, if]

Here, **listen to** represents obedience. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression in your translation or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you will not obey me] or [you refuse to do what I say]

bsb_verse_text: and if you reject My statutes, despise My ordinances, and neglect to carry out all My commandments, and so break My covenant,
ult_verse_text: and if you reject my statutes, and if your soul detests my judgments so as not to do all my commandments, {so} you break my covenant,

notes.note: Here, **your soul** represents the whole person. If it would be helpful to your readers, use a natural way in your language to refer to the whole person. Alternate translation: [you detest] or [you hate]
If your language does not use abstract nouns for these ideas, you could express the same ideas in other ways.

bsb_verse_text: then this is what I will do to you: I will bring upon you sudden terror, wasting disease, and fever that will destroy your sight and drain your life. You will sow your seed in vain, because your enemies will eat it.
ult_verse_text: {then} I also, I will do this to you: And I will appoint over you terror, the consumption and the fever, making eyes fail and causing life to pine away. And you shall sow your seed {in} vain, and your enemies shall eat it.

notes.note: Here the repetition of **I** emphasizes that God will certainly act. Use a way in your language to show emphasis on God’s certain action. Alternate translation: [then I will certainly do]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **terror**, you could express this idea with a verb or adjective. Use a natural way in your language to express extreme fear. Alternate translation: [things that terrify you] or [frightening things]

Here the second phrase gives the reason for the first. Use a connecting word that makes it clear that what follows is the reason for what came before. Alternate translation: [You will plant your seed uselessly because your enemies will eat what grows]

Here this begins a section describing the results of disobedience. Use a natural way in your language to show this is the consequence of their actions. Alternate translation: [As a result, I will send] or [Because of this, I will bring]

bsb_verse_text: And I will set My face against you, so that you will be defeated by your enemies. Those who hate you will rule over you, and you will flee when no one pursues you.
ult_verse_text: And I will set my face against you, and you shall be struck down to the face of your enemies. And those who hate you shall rule over you, and you shall flee when no one pursues you.

notes.note: Here, **set my face against** represents anger and opposition. Use a natural way in your language to express divine anger. Alternate translation: [I will oppose you] or [I will show my anger against you]
Here, **struck down** represents being killed. Use an equivalent expression for death or plain language in your translation. Alternate translation: [and you will be killed] or [and you will die]

Here, **to the face of** means “before” or “by” in battle. Use an equivalent expression or plain language to express being defeated by enemies. Alternate translation: [by your enemies] or [when your enemies attack you]
This verse describes the opposite situation from [verses 7-8](../26/07.md), where God’s people were victorious. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could make this contrast clear.

bsb_verse_text: And if after all this you will not obey Me, I will proceed to punish you sevenfold for your sins.
ult_verse_text: And if up to these {things} you will not listen to me, then I will continue to discipline you seven {times} for your sins.

notes.note: This means “if you still don’t obey after all this discipline.” Express this clearly in your language. Alternate translation: [If you still don’t obey me after all this punishment and] or [If you continue to disobey despite this discipline and]

Here, **seven times** could mean either complete punishment or greatly increased punishment. If you need to express the meaning of this expression in your language, consider following the interpretation of an accepted regional translation. Alternate translation: [completely] or [much more severely]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **sins**, you could express this as an action. Use a natural way in your language to express wrongdoing. Alternate translation: [your wrongdoing] or [your evil actions]

See how you translated this in [26:14](../26/14.md). Here, **listen to** represents obedience. Use a natural way in your language to express disobedience. Alternate translation: [you will not obey me] or [you refuse to do what I say]

bsb_verse_text: I will break down your stubborn pride and make your sky like iron and your land like bronze,
ult_verse_text: Then I will break the pride of your strength, and I will make your heavens like iron and your land like bronze.

notes.note: Here, **Then I will break the pride of your strength** introduces God’s goal for the discipline described in the rest of this verse and the next verse. He will make the heavens like iron and the land like bronze to humble the people. Express this purpose clearly in your language. Alternate translation: [And so I will make you humble] or [Because of this, I will destroy what makes you proud]

Here, **break** compares pride to something physical that can be broken, like a stick or rod. This represents how God will destroy their arrogance. Use a natural way in your language to express humbling someone. Alternate translation: [Then I will destroy your arrogance] or [Then I will take away what makes you proud]

These phrases **like iron** and **like bronze** compare the sky to iron and the land to bronze to show there will be no rain and the ground will be hard. Use natural comparisons in your language to express severe drought. Alternate translation: [the sky smooth as metal with no cloud blemishes and the ground as impenetrable to plant roots as metal]

This could mean either that they are very proud or that they are proud of their strength. Choose the interpretation that best fits your context. Alternate translation: [your strong pride] or [your pride in your power]

bsb_verse_text: and your strength will be spent in vain. For your land will not yield its produce, and the trees of the land will not bear their fruit.
ult_verse_text: And your strength shall be exhausted {in} vain, and your land shall not give its produce, and the tree of the land shall not give its fruit.

notes.note: This tells what will happen if the people continue to disobey. Use a natural way in your language to express this hypothetical situation. Alternate translation: [If you continue to disobey, then your strength will be used up for nothing] or [Then all your hard work will accomplish nothing]

The abstract concept **in vain** can be expressed as an action that produces no results. Use a natural way in your language to express futile effort. Alternate translation: [uselessly] or [without any result]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠לֹֽא־תִתֵּ֤ן אַרְצְ⁠כֶם֙ אֶת־יְבוּלָ֔⁠הּ וְ⁠עֵ֣ץ הָ⁠אָ֔רֶץ לֹ֥א יִתֵּ֖ן פִּרְיֽ⁠וֹ
notes.note: Here the **land** and **tree** are spoken of as if they were people who could give things. Use a natural way in your language to express failed crops. Alternate translation: [and nothing will grow in your land, and your trees will not produce any fruit] or [and nothing will grow in your land and on your trees]

bsb_verse_text: If you walk in hostility toward Me and refuse to obey Me, I will multiply your plagues seven times, according to your sins.
ult_verse_text: And if you walk with me {in} hostility and are not willing to listen to me, then I will add on you a plague seven {times} according to your sins.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אִם־תֵּֽלְכ֤וּ עִמִּ⁠י֙ קֶ֔רִי וְ⁠לֹ֥א תֹאב֖וּ לִ⁠שְׁמֹ֣עַֽ לִ֑⁠י וְ⁠יָסַפְתִּ֤י עֲלֵי⁠כֶם֙ מַכָּ֔ה שֶׁ֖בַע כְּ⁠חַטֹּאתֵי⁠כֶֽם׃
notes.note: Many parts of this verse are similar to [verse 18](../26/18.md). See how you translated those parts in [26:18](../26/18.md).

Here, **walk with me in hostility** is speaking of how a person lives as if it were a way or path that a person was walking along. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [you continue to oppose me] or [you persist in being hostile to me]

See how you translated this in [26:14](../26/14.md). Here, **listen to** represents obedience. Use a natural way in your language to express disobedience. Alternate translation: [and are not willing to obey me] or [and refuse to do what I say]
See how you translated this in [26:18](../26/18.md). Alternate translation: [much more severe]

See how you translated this in [26:18](../26/18.md). If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **sins**, it can be expressed as an action. Or you could use another way that is natural in your language to express wrongdoing. Alternate translation: [for your wrongdoing] or [for your evil actions]

bsb_verse_text: I will send wild animals against you to rob you of your children, destroy your livestock, and reduce your numbers, until your roads lie desolate.
ult_verse_text: And I will send the animal of the field against you, and it will bereave you, and it will cut off your cattle, and it will make you few, and your roads will be desolate.

notes.note: Here, **animal of the field** is not referring to a specific animal. It means animals in general. If it would be helpful for your readers, use a general term for wild animals or specify if your language has different terms for various wild animals. Alternate translation: [wild animals] or [the animals of the field]

Here, **and it will bereave you** is a polite way of saying “they will kill your children.” Use a direct term for killing to avoid ambiguity. Alternate translation: [and it will kill your children] or [and it will wipe out your children]

bsb_verse_text: And if in spite of these things you do not accept My discipline, but continue to walk in hostility toward Me,
ult_verse_text: And if by these {things} you will not accept my discipline but walk with me {in} hostility,

notes.note: **And if by these things** introduces a condition that could happen similar to [verse 18](../26/18.md). Use a connecting structure that clearly indicates this condition. Alternate translation: [If by these things] or [And if these things happen and]

Here, **walk with me in hostility** is a metaphor for living in opposition to Yahweh. Use a natural expression in your language to convey ongoing opposition or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [but continue to oppose me] or [but live in opposition to me]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **discipline**, use an appropriate term in your language that conveys the concept of punishment or correction. Alternate translation: [my punishment] or [my correction]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **hostility**, use an appropriate term in your language that conveys the concept of opposition or enmity. Alternate translation: [in opposition] or [in enmity]

bsb_verse_text: then I will act with hostility toward you, and I will strike you sevenfold for your sins.
ult_verse_text: then I myself will also walk with you in hostility, and I myself will also strike you seven {times} for your sins.\v 25 And I will bring upon you a sword avenging the vengeance of the covenant, and you will be gathered into your cities. And I will send pestilence into your midst, and you will be given into the hand of an enemy.

notes.note: The intensive pronoun **myself** represents the pronoun “I” that God uses in the original even though the verbs translated as **walk** and **strike** already include this meaning. Doing this adds emphasis to what he is saying. If your language uses explicit pronouns for emphasis, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of bringing out this emphasis. Alternate translation: [then I will also walk … and I will also punish] or [then I myself will walk … and I will personally strike]

Here, **walk with you in hostility** is a common expression that means “living in opposition.” Use a comparable expression in your language to convey ongoing opposition or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [I will continue to oppose you] or [I will persist in being hostile towards you]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **hostility**, you could express the same idea in another way to convey the concept of opposition or enmity. Alternate translation: [then I, I also will walk hostilely with you]

The phrase **strike you seven times** is a common expression indicating either greatly increased punishment or complete punishment. Choose the interpretation that fits your context. Alternate translation: [and I will strike you completely for your sins] or [and I will punish you sevenfold for your sins]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **sins**, you could express this idea in another way that conveys wrongdoing. Alternate translation: [because you sinned]

bsb_verse_text: And I will bring a sword against you to execute the vengeance of the covenant. Though you withdraw into your cities, I will send a plague among you, and you will be delivered into the hand of the enemy.

notes.note: Here, **a sword** represents “war.” Use an equivalent expression or plain language that appropriately conveys war. Alternate translation: [I will bring war upon you] or [I will wage war against you]

Here, **a sword** is spoken of as if it were a living thing that could be an agent of vengeance. Use a natural expression in your language that conveys the idea or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the avenging sword of] or [the sword which acts in avenging]

Here, **avenging the vengeance of the covenant** uses parallelism for emphasis. Use a similar parallel structure if it would be helpful to your readers, or express the emphasis in another way. Alternate translation: [punishing according to the covenant’s vengeance]

Here, **the vengeance of the covenant** refers to the curses associated with violating the covenant. Use your language’s term for these consequences. Alternate translation: [the covenant’s curses] or [the curses of the covenant]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **vengeance**, you could express the same idea in a way that conveys punishment in your language. Alternate translation: [the punishments of] or [the retributions of]

If your language does not use a passive form like **and you will be gathered into your cities**, you could express the same idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [and you will gather to hide in your cities]

Here, **and you will be gathered into your cities** means that people will flee to their cities for safety. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [and you will flee to your cities to seek safety] or [and you will gather in your cities for protection]

Here, **And I will send pestilence** connects to the previous clause to show continued discipline. Use a connecting word to show how this statement relates to what comes before it. Alternate translation: [Furthermore, I will send pestilence] or [Moreover, I will send pestilence]

The expression **you will be given into the hand of an enemy** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. If you need to say who does the action, the context indicates that it is God. Alternate translation: [and I will give you into the hand of an enemy]

Here, **the hand of an enemy** represents being captured or killed by the enemy. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and you will be captured by the enemy] or [and you will be killed by the enemy]
Here, **an enemy** is not referring to a specific enemy but enemies in general. Use a general term for enemies.

bsb_verse_text: When I cut off your supply of bread, ten women will bake your bread in a single oven and dole out your bread by weight, so that you will eat but not be satisfied.
ult_verse_text: When I break to you the staff of bread, then ten women will bake your bread in one oven, and they will return your bread by weight, and you will eat but not be satisfied.

notes.note: Here, **the staff of bread** is a common expression meaning “famine.” Use a comparable expression from your language that conveys the same meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [When I cause famine] or [When I bring famine upon you]

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ֠⁠אָפוּ עֶ֣שֶׂר נָשִׁ֤ים לַחְמְ⁠כֶם֙ בְּ⁠תַנּ֣וּר אֶחָ֔ד
notes.note: Here, **then ten women will bake your bread in one oven** implies severe food scarcity. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [then ten women will bake your bread in one oven due to scarcity] or [then ten women will bake your bread in a single oven because of famine]

Here, **and they will return your bread by weight** means that bread will be distributed carefully to families. Use an expression that conveys precise distribution. Alternate translation: [and they will carefully measure and distribute your bread to their families] or [and they will return your bread in measured portions to their families]

Here, **but not be satisfied** shows a contrast between expectation and reality, indicating that people will not be content despite receiving some bread. In your translation, indicate this contrast in a way that is natural in your language . Alternate translation: [but you will not be satisfied] or [yet you will not be content]

bsb_verse_text: But if in spite of all this you do not obey Me, but continue to walk in hostility toward Me,
ult_verse_text: And if in spite of this you will not listen to me but walk with me in hostility,

notes.note: If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **hostility**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [as my enemy] or [by rebelling against me]

bsb_verse_text: then I will walk in fury against you, and I, even I, will punish you sevenfold for your sins.
ult_verse_text: then I will walk with you in the heat of hostility, and I myself will also discipline you seven {times} for your sins.

notes.note: Here, **in the heat of hostility** is an expression comparing strong feelings of hostility to the intensity of a fire. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [amid strong hostility] or [in the midst of fierce opposition]
If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **hostility**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [opposition] or [enmity]

The intensive pronoun **myself** represents the pronoun “I” that God uses in the original even though the verb translated as **discipline** already includes this meaning. Doing this adds emphasis to what he is saying. If your language uses explicit pronouns for emphasis, you may want to use that construction in your translation. If not, your language may have other ways of bringing out this emphasis. Alternate translation: [and I will personally discipline you seven times]

bsb_verse_text: You will eat the flesh of your own sons and daughters.
ult_verse_text: And you will eat the flesh of your sons, and the flesh of your daughters you will eat.

notes.orig_language_quote: וַ⁠אֲכַלְתֶּ֖ם בְּשַׂ֣ר בְּנֵי⁠כֶ֑ם וּ⁠בְשַׂ֥ר בְּנֹתֵי⁠כֶ֖ם תֹּאכֵֽלוּ
notes.note: These two phrases mean basically the same thing. The second emphasizes the meaning of the first by repeating the same idea with different words. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could connect the phrases with a word other than **and** in order to show that the second phrase is repeating the first one, not saying something additional. Alternate translation: [And you will eat the flesh of your sons and daughters]

bsb_verse_text: I will destroy your high places, cut down your incense altars, and heap your lifeless bodies on the lifeless remains of your idols; and My soul will despise you.
ult_verse_text: And I will destroy your high places, and I will cut down your incense altars, and I will pile your corpses on the corpses of your idols, and my soul will detest you.

notes.note: Here, **my soul** represents the speaker (Yahweh). Use a natural expression in your language that maintains the emphasis on personal detestation. Alternate translation: [and my soul will hate you] or [and I will deeply despise you]

bsb_verse_text: I will reduce your cities to rubble and lay waste your sanctuaries, and I will refuse to smell the pleasing aroma of your sacrifices.
ult_verse_text: And I will make your cities a waste, and I will make desolate your holy places, and I will not smell your pleasing aromas.

notes.note: Here, **pleasing aromas** represents sacrifices, as God often refers to the pleasant smells of burnt offerings and incense. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [the pleasant scents of your sacrifices] or [the delightful aromas of your offerings]

bsb_verse_text: And I will lay waste the land, so that your enemies who dwell in it will be appalled.
ult_verse_text: And I, I will make the land desolate, and your enemies, the dwellers in it, will be appalled at it.

notes.note: See how you translated this in [26:16](../26/16.md). Alternate translation: [I will also make the land desolate] or [I, myself, will make the land desolate]

Here, the connector **and** implies that the reason that the enemies will be appalled is because the land is so desolate. If the connection between this statement and the previous one is not clear, you may want to use a different connecting word to show how this statement relates to what comes before it.
