Alternate translation: [furthermore, your enemies who dwell in it will be appalled] or [additionally, your enemies residing there will be appalled]

bsb_verse_text: But I will scatter you among the nations and will draw out a sword after you as your land becomes desolate and your cities are laid waste.
ult_verse_text: And you I will scatter among the nations, and I will draw out a sword after you, and your land will be a desolation, and your cities will be a waste.

notes.note: Here, **a sword** represents war. Use a term that appropriately conveys war or conflict in your language. Alternate translation: [and I will wage war against you] or [and I will bring war upon you]

bsb_verse_text: Then the land shall enjoy its Sabbaths all the days it lies desolate, while you are in the land of your enemies. At that time the land will rest and enjoy its Sabbaths.
ult_verse_text: Then the land will enjoy its sabbaths all the days of its desolation, and you {will be} in the land of your enemies. Then the land will rest and enjoy its sabbaths.

notes.orig_language_quote: תִּרְצֶ֨ה הָ⁠אָ֜רֶץ אֶת־שַׁבְּתֹתֶ֗י⁠הָ & תִּשְׁבַּ֣ת הָ⁠אָ֔רֶץ וְ⁠הִרְצָ֖ת אֶת־שַׁבְּתֹתֶֽי⁠הָ
notes.note: Here, **the land** is spoken of as if it were a living thing that could rest and enjoy its sabbaths. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the land will observe its sabbaths and rest … the land will honor its sabbaths by resting]

bsb_verse_text: As long as it lies desolate, the land will have the rest it did not receive during the Sabbaths when you lived in it.
ult_verse_text: All the days of its desolation it will rest, what it did not rest in your sabbaths, when you dwelt on it.

notes.orig_language_quote: אֵ֣ת אֲשֶׁ֧ר לֹֽא־שָׁבְתָ֛ה בְּ⁠שַׁבְּתֹתֵי⁠כֶ֖ם בְּ⁠שִׁבְתְּ⁠כֶ֥ם עָלֶֽי⁠הָ
notes.note: Here, **what it did not rest in your sabbaths** means that the land will rest in compensation for the sabbaths the Israelites did not observe. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [what it did not rest during your sabbaths] or [the land will rest for the sabbaths you neglected]

bsb_verse_text: As for those of you who survive, I will send a faintness into their hearts in the lands of their enemies, so that even the sound of a windblown leaf will put them to flight. And they will flee as one flees the sword, and fall when no one pursues them.
ult_verse_text: And the remaining in you, and I will bring faintness into their heart in the land of their enemies. And the sound of a driven leaf will chase them, and they will flee {as} fleeing from a sword, and they will fall when there is no pursuer.

notes.note: This indicates that as for those who survive, Yahweh will bring additional discipline. Use a grammatical structure that clearly connects the survival of some people with the forthcoming actions. Alternate translation: [As for those of you who survive, I will bring] or [And for the remaining among you, I will bring]

Here, **their heart** represents where a person’s thoughts, feelings, and fears exist. You may have a comparable expression in your language, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [fearfulness into their hearts] or [deep anxiety within them]

Here, **their heart** shifts Yahweh’s perspective from addressing the survivors directly to speaking about them in the third person. Follow a clear and natural use of pronouns in your language. Alternate translation: [within their hearts] or [inside their hearts]

Here, **the sound of a driven leaf** is spoken of as a living thing actively chasing people. If it would be helpful in your translation, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [The sound of a blowing leaf will pursue them] or [The noise of a driven leaf will chase after them]

The expression **a driven leaf** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use this form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [a leaf that the wind drives] or [a leaf that the wind blows]

Here, **a sword** represents a person who is going to harm them. If it would be helpful in your translation, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [a warrior] or [an aggressor]

bsb_verse_text: They will stumble over one another as before the sword, though no one is behind them. So you will not be able to stand against your enemies.
ult_verse_text: And they will stumble, one on his brother, as from the face of a sword but there is no pursuer, and to you there will be no power to stand to the face of your enemies.

notes.note: This is a common expression in the writer’s culture that describes people falling over each other in panic while trying to flee. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [They will fall over each other while running away] or [They will trip over one another as they flee]

Here, **from the face of** is a common expression of the culture meaning “before” or “in front of.” If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression from your language that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [as from before a sword] or [as from someone threatening them with a sword]

The point of this comparison is that just as people flee from an armed enemy, so will these people flee even though no one is actually pursuing them. If it would be helpful in your language, you could make this point explicitly. Alternate translation: [as if someone were chasing them with a sword] or [like people running from an armed enemy]

Here, **power to stand** means to successfully resist or fight back against enemies. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [strength to resist] or [ability to defend yourselves]
See how you translated this expression earlier in this verse. Here it means “before” or “against.” Alternate translation: [against your enemies] or [when your enemies attack]

The text shifts from talking about the people in the third person (**they**) to addressing them directly (**you**). If it would be helpful for your readers, you could use the same pronoun throughout. Alternate translation: [And you will stumble … you will have] or [And they will stumble … they will have]

bsb_verse_text: You will perish among the nations, and the land of your enemies will consume you.
ult_verse_text: And you will perish in the nations, and the land of your enemies will consume you.

notes.note: This talks about **the land of your enemies** as if it were a living thing that could consume people. If it would be helpful in your language, you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and the land of your enemies will devour you]

bsb_verse_text: Those of you who survive in the lands of your enemies will waste away in their iniquity and will decay in the sins of their fathers.
ult_verse_text: And the remaining in you will rot away in their iniquity in the lands of your enemies, and also in the iniquities of their fathers they will rot away with them.

notes.note: This could mean: 1) they will not prosper spiritually, 2) they will not prosper materially, and 3) they will literally die, and their bodies will rot away. Try to use a term broad enough to cover all three meanings in your language. Alternate translation: [will perish … they will perish] or [will decay … they will decay]

If your language does not use an abstract noun for the idea of **iniquity** or **iniquities**, you could express the same idea in another way. Alternate translation: [in their sins … in the sins of] or [in their wrongdoings … in the wrongdoings of]

Here, **fathers** represents ancestors. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [their ancestors] or [their forefathers]

bsb_verse_text: But if they will confess their iniquity and that of their fathers in the unfaithfulness that they practiced against Me, by which they have also walked in hostility toward Me—
ult_verse_text: And they confess their iniquity and the iniquity of their fathers in their unfaithfulness which they were unfaithful to me, and also that they walked with me in hostility,

notes.note: Here, **And they confess** introduces a strong contrast. In your translation, indicate this contrast in a way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [But if they confess] or [However, if they confess]

notes.orig_language_quote: אֶת־עֲוֺנָ⁠ם֙ וְ⁠אֶת־עֲוֺ֣ן אֲבֹתָ֔⁠ם בְּ⁠מַעֲלָ֖⁠ם אֲשֶׁ֣ר מָֽעֲלוּ־בִ֑⁠י & בְּ⁠קֶֽרִי
notes.note: If your language does not use abstract nouns for the ideas of **iniquity**, **unfaithfulness**, and **hostility**, you could express those same ideas in another way. Alternate translation: [the ways they sinned and the ways their ancestors sinned and did not faithfully obey me … hostilely]
Here, **fathers** represents ancestors. See how you translated this in [26:39](../26/39.md). Alternate translation: [their ancestors] or [their forefathers]
See how you translated this in [26:21](../26/21.md). Alternate translation: [they lived in hostility]

bsb_verse_text: and I acted with hostility toward them and brought them into the land of their enemies—and if their uncircumcised hearts will be humbled and they will make amends for their iniquity,
ult_verse_text: (I also, I walked with them in hostility and brought them into the land of their enemies)—if then their uncircumcised heart is humbled, and they accept their iniquity,

notes.note: See how you translated this repetition in [26:16](../26/16.md). Alternate translation: [I, too, walked]
See how you translated this in [26:24](../26/24.md). Alternate translation: [I walked with hostility toward them]

The expression **their uncircumcised heart is humbled** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [they humble their uncircumcised hearts]

Here, **heart** represents where a person’s emotions, feelings, and desires exist, and the **uncircumcised heart** represents people who are unwilling to obey God. Since physical circumcision was a sign of being in covenant with God, an uncircumcised heart represents resistance to God’s covenant. You may have a comparable expression in your language, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [their stubborn inner nature] or [their rebellious attitude]

This could mean either: 1) they accept the punishment that their wrongdoing deserves, or 2) they acknowledge and admit their guilt. If you can translate this in a way that can capture both meanings do that, otherwise you could follow how your local major language translations understand this phrase. Alternate translation: [they accept their punishment] or [they admit their guilt]

bsb_verse_text: For the land will be abandoned by them, and it will enjoy its Sabbaths by lying desolate without them. And they will pay the penalty for their iniquity, because they rejected My ordinances and abhorred My statutes.
ult_verse_text: And the land will be deserted by them and will enjoy its sabbaths in its desolation from them. And they, they will accept their iniquity because, even because they rejected my judgments and their soul detested my statutes.

notes.note: The expression **And the land will be deserted by them** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And they will desert the land, and the land will enjoy] or [And they will leave the land deserted, and it will enjoy]
The pronoun **them** refers to the Israelites who will be taken away from the land. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [by the Israelites] or [by those people]

Here, **in its desolation from them** implies that the land is empty without them. You could include this information if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [while it is empty without them] or [as it becomes desolate without them]

Here, the repetition of **they** shifts focus from the land to the people. Use a way that is natural in your language to make this clear. Alternate translation: [And they will accept] or [They, they will accept]
See how you translated this in [26:41](../26/41.md). Here it seems more clear that they are accepting the punishment for their wrongdoing. Alternate translation: [they accept their punishment]

Here, **because, even because** emphatically marks the reason for the result that came before. If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of these phrases since the second phrase gives the reason for the result that the first phrase describes. Alternate translation: [because] or [even because]

bsb_verse_text: Yet in spite of this, when they are in the land of their enemies, I will not reject or despise them so as to destroy them and break My covenant with them; for I am the LORD their God.
ult_verse_text: And yet for all that, when they are in the land of their enemies, I will not reject them, nor will I detest them to destroy them completely, to break my covenant with them, for I {am} Yahweh their God.

notes.note: Here, **for I am Yahweh their God** provides a reason for the result. If it would be more natural in your language, you could reverse the order of this phrase to appear at the beginning of the sentence. Alternate translation: [because I am Yahweh their God] or [since I am Yahweh their God]

bsb_verse_text: But for their sake I will remember the covenant with their fathers, whom I brought out of the land of Egypt in the sight of the nations, that I might be their God. I am the LORD.”
ult_verse_text: But I will remember for them the covenant of the first, whom I brought them out from the land of Egypt to the eyes of the nations to be God to them. I am Yahweh.’”

notes.note: Here, **the covenant of the first** refers to “the first covenant” or “the covenant with the first generation of Israelites”. You could use a comparable expression that accurately reflects this meaning in your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [the first covenant with them] or [the covenant with the first generation of Israelites]

Here, the phrase **to the eyes of the nations** represents the people that observed God’s actions. If it would be helpful in your translation, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [in the sight of the nations] or [before the nations]

Here, **to be God to them** represents the goal or purpose of bringing them out of Egypt. Use an expression in your language that makes it clear that this is the purpose. Alternate translation: [to serve as their God] or [to be their God]

bsb_verse_text: These are the statutes, ordinances, and laws that the LORD established between Himself and the Israelites through Moses on Mount Sinai.
ult_verse_text: These {are} the statutes and the judgments and the laws which Yahweh gave between him and between the sons of Israel on Mount Sinai by the hand of Moses.

notes.note: This verse provides a closing summary of at least [chapters 17-26](../17/01.md), if not an initial closing for the entire book. Use the natural form in your language for expressing the conclusion to the previous section.

If your language does not use abstract nouns for the ideas of **the statutes and the judgments and the laws**, you could express the same ideas in different ways. Alternate translation: [the commands, rules, and instructions] or [all that God commanded and instructed]

notes.orig_language_quote: בֵּינ֕⁠וֹ וּ⁠בֵ֖ין בְּנֵ֣י יִשְׂרָאֵ֑ל בְּ⁠הַ֥ר סִינַ֖י בְּ⁠יַד־מֹשֶֽׁה
notes.note: Here, **between him and between the sons of Israel on Mount Sinai by the hand of Moses** means that this covenant agreement, which consisted of the statutes, judgments, and laws, was made between Yahweh and the Israelites on Mount Sinai with Moses as mediator and scribe. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [to the Israelites at Mount Sinai, which Moses wrote down as their mediator]

Here, **by the hand of Moses** represents Moses acting as a mediator and scribe. If it would be helpful in your translation, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [through Moses as mediator] or [with Moses serving as mediator and writing these things down]

bsb_verse_text: “Speak to the Israelites and say to them, ‘When someone makes a special vow to the LORD involving the value of persons,
ult_verse_text: “Speak to the sons of Israel and say to them, ‘A man when he makes extraordinary a vow, by your valuation of persons to Yahweh,

notes.note: In Hebrew, they introduced speech by using two similar phrases. If this kind of repetition would not be natural in your language, you could combine them. Alternate translation: [Say to the sons of Israel]
Here, **sons of Israel** refers to the entire Israelite people, not just the male descendants or the original 12 sons of Jacob. Alternate translation: [the people of Israel] or [the Israelites]

Here, **a man** refers to any person, not a specific man. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Anyone] or [Any person]

This is a common expression meaning to make a special kind of vow. Your language may have a comparable expression that you can use in your translation, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [he makes a special vow] or [he makes a solemn promise]

The phrase **your valuation** occurs 19 times in the chapter. For people, the valuation is set here by Yahweh. For more information see the introduction to [chapter 5](../05/01.md) and how you you translated this in [5:15](../05/15.md). Alternate translation: [by the valuation of persons that I, Yahweh, give you]

bsb_verse_text: if the valuation concerns a male from twenty to sixty years of age, then your valuation shall be fifty shekels of silver, according to the sanctuary shekel.
ult_verse_text: and your valuation of the male from a son of 20 years and until a son of 60 years will be {thus}, and your valuation will be 50 shekels of silver by the shekel of the holy place.

notes.orig_language_quote: מִ⁠בֶּן֙ עֶשְׂרִ֣ים שָׁנָ֔ה וְ⁠עַ֖ד בֶּן־שִׁשִּׁ֣ים שָׁנָ֑ה
notes.note: Here, **son of** is a common expression in the culture which refers to a person who has some characteristic. In this instance, it is referring to males who have age ranges from 20-59. If this would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from age twenty to age fifty-nine]

In ancient times the silver **shekel of the holy place** was the standard weight kept by the priests in the Dwelling and later the temple. Alternate translation: [according to the standard shekel kept at the holy place]

bsb_verse_text: Or if it is a female, then your valuation shall be thirty shekels.
ult_verse_text: And if {it is} a female, then your valuation will be 30 shekels.

notes.note: The ages from [verse 3](../27/03.md), (twenty to fifty-nine years) carry over to this verse. You could include this information if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [And if it is a female between twenty and fifty-nine years old]

bsb_verse_text: And if the person is from five to twenty years of age, then your valuation for the male shall be twenty shekels, and for the female ten shekels.
ult_verse_text: And if {it is} from a son of five years and until a son of 20 years, then your valuation will be {for} the male 20 shekels, and for the female ten shekels.

notes.note: This is a common expression referring to ages 5-19. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from age five to age nineteen]

bsb_verse_text: Now if the person is from one month to five years of age, then your valuation for the male shall be five shekels of silver, and for the female three shekels of silver.
ult_verse_text: And if from a son of a month and until a son of five years, then your valuation will be {for} the male five shekels of silver, and for the female your valuation {will be} three shekels of silver.

notes.note: This is a common expression referring to ages one month to four years. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from one month old to four years old]

bsb_verse_text: And if the person is sixty years of age or older, then your valuation shall be fifteen shekels for the male and ten shekels for the female.
ult_verse_text: And if from a son of 60 years and upward, if a male, then your valuation will be 15 shekels, and for the female ten shekels.

notes.note: This is a common expression referring to ages sixty and older. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an equivalent expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [sixty years old and older]

bsb_verse_text: But if the one making the vow is too poor to pay the valuation, he is to present the person before the priest, who shall set the value according to what the one making the vow can afford.
ult_verse_text: And if he is too poor from your valuation, then he shall stand him before the face of the priest, and the priest shall value him. Upon the mouth of what the hand of the one vowing can reach, the priest shall value him.

notes.note: Here **too poor from your valuation** means unable to pay the standard amount. You could make this explicit in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [And if he is too poor to pay the standard valuation]

Here, **he** refers to the person making the vow (who is poor), and **him** refers to the person that has been promised to Yahweh that the vower is trying to redeem. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [then the person making the vow shall present the one promised to Yahweh]

Here, **before the face of the priest** represents being in front of the priest. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [in front of the priest] or [in the priest’s presence]

This is a common expression meaning according to what someone can pay. If this phrase does not have that meaning in your language, you could use a comparable expression that does have that meaning, or you could state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [Based on how much the one making the vow can afford]

bsb_verse_text: If he vows an animal that may be brought as an offering to the LORD, any such animal given to the LORD shall be holy.
ult_verse_text: And if {it is} an animal which they will present from it an offering to Yahweh, all which he will give from it to Yahweh will be holy.

notes.orig_language_quote: וְ⁠אִם־בְּהֵמָ֔ה אֲשֶׁ֨ר יַקְרִ֧יבוּ מִמֶּ֛⁠נָּה קָרְבָּ֖ן לַֽ⁠יהוָ֑ה
notes.note: The meaning of this verse may be unclear due to its complex structure. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation, if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [And if someone is presenting a portion of an animal as an offering to Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: He must not replace it or exchange it, either good for bad or bad for good. But if he does substitute one animal for another, both that animal and its substitute will be holy.
ult_verse_text: He shall not exchange it and he shall not substitute it, good with bad or bad with good. And if substituting, he substitutes animal with animal, then it shall be {that} it and its substitute shall be holy.

notes.note: The words **exchange** and **substitute** mean very similar things and are used together for emphasis. If your language would not use two similar words this way, you could combine them into a single clear expression. Alternate translation: [He must not trade it for another animal]

Some words are left out that in many languages a sentence would need in order to be complete. You could supply these words from the context if it would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [not a good animal for a worse one or a bad animal for a better one]

This Hebrew expression uses repetition of the verb “substitute” to intensify the idea. If your language does not repeat words for intensification, you could have another way of expressing the same idea. Alternate translation: [And if indeed he substitutes]

bsb_verse_text: But if the vow involves any of the unclean animals that may not be brought as an offering to the LORD, the animal must be presented before the priest.
ult_verse_text: And if {it is} any unclean animal which they shall not present from it a present to Yahweh, then he shall stand the animal to the face of the priest,

notes.note: Here, **to the face of** represents being in front of the person. If it would be helpful in your language, you could use an equivalent expression or plain language. Alternate translation: [in front of the priest] or [in the priest’s presence]

bsb_verse_text: The priest shall set its value, whether high or low; as the priest values it, the price will be set.
ult_verse_text: and the priest shall value it between good and between bad. According to your valuation, O priest, so it shall be.

notes.note: Here, **your valuation** refers to the value that the priest determines for the poor person’s offering. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [The value that you, the priest, determine]

bsb_verse_text: If, however, the owner decides to redeem the animal, he must add a fifth to its value.
ult_verse_text: And if redeeming he will redeem it, then he shall add its fifth upon your valuation.

notes.note: This Hebrew expression **redeeming he will redeem it** uses repetition to intensify expression of the idea. If your language does not repeat words for intensification, you could express this idea in another way. Alternate translation: [indeed he redeems it]
See how you translated this in [5:16](../05/16.md).

bsb_verse_text: Now if a man consecrates his house as holy to the LORD, then the priest shall value it either as good or bad. The price will stand just as the priest values it.
ult_verse_text: And a man when he consecrates his house holy to Yahweh, then the priest will value it between good and between bad. Just as the priest will value it, so it will stand.

notes.note: Here, **a man** refers to any person, not a specific man. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could use an expression that would be more natural in your language. Alternate translation: [Anyone] or [Any person]

The phrase **between good and between bad** means the priest will assess the condition of the house to determine its value. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [according to the condition of the house]

bsb_verse_text: But if he who consecrated his house redeems it, he must add a fifth to the assessed value, and it will belong to him.
ult_verse_text: And if the one consecrating would redeem his house, then he shall add a fifth of the silver of your valuation upon it, and it will be to him.

notes.note: In the phrase **the one consecrating**, the words “his house” are left out but understood from the previous verse. You could supply these words if it would be clearer in your language. Alternate translation: [the one consecrating his house]
See how you translated this in [27:13](../27/13.md).

Here, **and it will be to him** is a common expression meaning that ownership will be transferred to him. You could use a comparable expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and it will belong to him]

Here, **your valuation** refers to the value that the priest determined based on the condition of the house. You could say that explicitly if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [the value you determined]

bsb_verse_text: If a man consecrates to the LORD a parcel of his land, then your valuation shall be proportional to the seed required for it—fifty shekels of silver for every homer of barley seed.
ult_verse_text: And if from the field of his possession a man consecrates to Yahweh, then your valuation will be to the mouth of its seed, seed of a homer of barley at 50 shekels of silver.

notes.note: The phrase **field of his possession** refers to inherited property that was originally given to Israelite families when they entered Canaan. This property generally returned to the family every 49 years at Jubilee. Alternate translation: [from his inherited field]

This means the amount of seed. It could mean either 1) the amount of seed needed to plant the field or 2) the amount of seed the field produces. Alternate translation: [according to how much seed it takes to plant] or [according to how much seed to produce]

A **homer** was a unit of volume that may have been about 220 liters. If it would be helpful to your readers, you could express this in terms of modern measurement. Alternate translation: [about 220 liters of]

bsb_verse_text: But if he consecrates his field after the Jubilee, the priest is to calculate the price in proportion to the years left until the next Year of Jubilee, so that your valuation will be reduced.
ult_verse_text: But if after the jubilee he consecrates his field, then the priest shall calculate for him the silver upon the mouth of the years remaining until the year of the jubilee, and it shall be subtracted from your valuation.

notes.note: The phrase **upon the mouth of the years** is a common expression meaning based on the number of years. You could use a comparable expression from your language that has the same meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [according to the number of years]

bsb_verse_text: And if the one who consecrated the field decides to redeem it, he must add a fifth to the assessed value, and it shall belong to him.
ult_verse_text: And if redeeming he will redeem the field, the one consecrating it, then he shall add a fifth of the silver of your valuation upon it, and it will stand to him.

notes.note: The phrase **redeeming he will redeem** uses repetition to intensify the idea. If your language does not use repetition for intensification, you could use another way that is natural in your language to convey this meaning. Alternate translation: [if indeed he redeems]
See how you translated this in [27:13](../27/13.md).

The phrase **it will stand to him** is a common expression meaning ownership will revert to him. You could use a comparable expression from your language that has the same meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [and it will belong to him again]

bsb_verse_text: If, however, he does not redeem the field, or if he has sold it to another man, it may no longer be redeemed.
ult_verse_text: And if he does not redeem the field, and if he sells the field to another man, it shall not be redeemed again.

notes.note: This verse presents a case where someone tries to profit twice from the same field by dedicating it and then selling it. As a result, they lose the right to the field permanently. You could say this explicitly if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [he will permanently lose the right to redeem it]

The expression **it shall not be redeemed again** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express this in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [no one will be able to redeem it again]

bsb_verse_text: When the field is released in the Jubilee, it will become holy, like a field devoted to the LORD; it becomes the property of the priests.
ult_verse_text: And the field shall be, in its going out in the Jubilee, holy to Yahweh, as a field of devotion. It shall be to the priest, his possession.

notes.note: This is a common expression referring to when property ownership changes at the Year of Jubilee. You could use a natural expression in your language that has the same meaning or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [when ownership transfers in the Year of Jubilee]

A **field of devotion** refers to land that is completely and permanently dedicated to Yahweh. This is a stronger term than “consecrated.” You could use a term in your language that communicates this permanent, irrevocable dedication. Alternate translation: [as a field permanently and completely given to Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: Now if a man consecrates to the LORD a field he has purchased, which is not a part of his own property,
ult_verse_text: And if he consecrates to Yahweh a field of his purchase which {is} not from the field of his possession,

notes.note: The phrase **a field of his purchase** refers to a field someone has bought rather than inherited. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [a field that he has purchased]

A **field of possession** refers to inherited land that was originally given to Israelite families. You could state this explicitly if it would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [which is not part of his inherited family land]

bsb_verse_text: In the Year of Jubilee the field shall return to the one from whom it was bought—the original owner of the land.
ult_verse_text: In the year of the jubilee the field will return to him from whom he bought it, to whom to him {is} the possession of the land.

notes.note: Here both instances of **him** refer to the original owner who has inheritance rights, while **he** refers to the person who bought and then dedicated the field. It may be helpful to clarify this for your readers. Alternate translation: [to the original owner from whom the buyer bought it, to whom]

This refers to the person who permanently owns the land through inheritance rights. You could say this explicitly, if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [to the one who permanently owns the land by inheritance]

bsb_verse_text: Every valuation will be according to the sanctuary shekel, twenty gerahs to the shekel.
ult_verse_text: And all your valuation shall be by the shekel of the holy place; the shekel shall be 20 gerahs.

notes.note: See how you translated this in [27:3](../27/03.md).
A **gerah** was a unit of weight equal to about one-half gram. You could use a known unit of weight in your language. Alternate translation: [units each equal to about one-half gram]

bsb_verse_text: But no one may consecrate a firstborn of the livestock, because a firstborn belongs to the LORD. Whether it is an ox or a sheep, it is the LORD’s.
ult_verse_text: However, a firstborn (which firstborn {belongs} to Yahweh) among animals, a man shall not consecrate it, whether ox or sheep, it {belongs} to Yahweh.

notes.orig_language_quote: בְּכ֞וֹר אֲשֶׁר־יְבֻכַּ֤ר לַֽ⁠יהוָה֙ בִּ⁠בְהֵמָ֔ה לֹֽא־יַקְדִּ֥ישׁ אִ֖ישׁ אֹת֑⁠וֹ אִם־שׁ֣וֹר אִם־שֶׂ֔ה לַֽ⁠יהוָ֖ה הֽוּא
notes.note: The assumption is that readers will know that Yahweh automatically owns all firstborn animals from the time of the Passover, so no one can consecrate them. You could say that explicitly if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [no one may consecrate a firstborn animal to Yahweh, whether ox or sheep, because all firstborn animals already belong to Yahweh]

bsb_verse_text: But if it is among the unclean animals, then he may redeem it according to your valuation and add a fifth of its value. If it is not redeemed, then it shall be sold according to your valuation.
ult_verse_text: And if {it is} among the unclean animals, then he shall ransom {it} by your valuation and add its fifth upon it. And if it is not redeemed, then it shall be sold at your valuation.

notes.note: See how you translated this in [27:13](../27/13.md)

The phrase **if it is not redeemed, then it shall be sold** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [And if no one redeems it, then you must sell it at the value you determined]

bsb_verse_text: Nothing that a man sets apart to the LORD from all he owns—whether a man, an animal, or his inherited land—can be sold or redeemed; everything so devoted is most holy to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: However, any devoted thing which a man will devote to Yahweh from all which {belongs} to him, from man and animal and from field of his possession, it shall not be sold and it shall not be redeemed. Every devoted thing, it {is} a holy thing of holy things to Yahweh.

notes.note: A **devoted thing** refers to something that is completely and permanently dedicated to Yahweh. This is a stronger term than “consecrated.” See how you translated this in [27:21](../27/21.md). Alternate translation: [thing permanently and completely given to Yahweh]

This refers to anything someone might own that could be devoted to Yahweh. You could indicate this explicitly in your translation if that would be helpful to your readers. Alternate translation: [whether a person, an animal, or an inherited field]
See how you translated this in [2:3](../02/03.md).

bsb_verse_text: No person set apart for destruction may be ransomed; he must surely be put to death.
ult_verse_text: All devoted ones who are devoted to destruction from mankind shall not be ransomed; dying he shall be put to death.

notes.note: All **devoted ones** refers to someone who is completely and permanently dedicated to Yahweh. When someone is **devoted to destruction**, it means they must be executed because they are enemies of Israel or have severely broken Yahweh’s covenant. Alternate translation: [people who must be executed because they are permanently condemned]

If your language does not use a passive verbal form in this way, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [All those whom Yahweh has condemned to death]

The expression **shall not be ransomed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use this form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [no one may pay to save their lives]

The expression **he shall be put to death** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use that form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [you must certainly execute them]

bsb_verse_text: Thus any tithe from the land, whether from the seed of the land or the fruit of the trees, belongs to the LORD; it is holy to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And all tithe of the land from the seed of the land, from the fruit of the tree, {belongs} to Yahweh. It {is} holy to Yahweh.

notes.note: Here, **seed** represents all food crops that grow from seeds. If it would be helpful in your translation, you could use an equivalent expression or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [from the crops of the land] or [from what grows in the fields]

bsb_verse_text: If a man wishes to redeem part of his tithe, he must add a fifth to its value.
ult_verse_text: And if redeeming, a man will redeem from his tithe, its fifth he shall add upon it.

notes.note: See how you translated a similar phrase about redeeming property in [27:19](../27/19.md). Alternate translation: [indeed someone redeems part of his tithe]

bsb_verse_text: Every tenth animal from the herd or flock that passes under the shepherd’s rod will be holy to the LORD.
ult_verse_text: And all tithe of cattle and flock, all which passes under the rod, the tenth will be holy to Yahweh.

notes.note: This is a common expression that refers to how shepherds would count their animals by making them pass under a rod one by one. You could use a comparable expression from your language or state the meaning plainly. Alternate translation: [all that is counted in the flock]

bsb_verse_text: He must not inspect whether it is good or bad, and he shall not make any substitution. But if he does make a substitution, both the animal and its substitute shall become holy; they cannot be redeemed.’”
ult_verse_text: He shall not examine between good to bad, and he shall not substitute it. And if substituting, he substitutes it, then it shall be {that} it and its substitute shall be holy. It shall not be redeemed.’”

notes.orig_language_quote: לֹ֧א יְבַקֵּ֛ר בֵּֽין־ט֥וֹב לָ⁠רַ֖ע וְ⁠לֹ֣א יְמִירֶ֑⁠נּוּ
notes.note: See how you translated this in [27:10](../27/10.md). Alternate translation: [He must not inspect them to trade a good one for a bad one]

The phrase **It shall not be redeemed** is a passive verbal form. If your language would not use this form, you could express the idea in active form or in another way that is natural in your language. Alternate translation: [No one may redeem it]
